headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today, we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today, we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated presentation has been posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during the call today. 
As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. 
So today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities in the Gulf from John Lambuth, Senior VP of Exploration; and then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on our operations, including production and well cost. Cimarex CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of our recent results and update you on some of the delineation that we have underway in 2016. Joe will provide an operational overview. 
I'd like to give up the call with some overview remarks in our direction in 2016 and beyond. During 2015, we put a lot of energy into long-range planning, and we developed capabilities for running detailed iterations on current and future years CapEx, cash flow and balance sheet configuration. We scrubbed our assets and developed net asset value models that help us to fully understand our outside and plan accordingly. Today, we're making decisions for 2016 with a close eye on 2017, 2018 and beyond. Cimarex is better positioned for the future by slowing down a bit, preserving our cash and assets and living within our means. Our focus is on preservation of our assets and balance sheet. We don't have any special insight on when or how commodity prices will recover. We do know that we will probably be as surprised by the recovery as we were by the collapse. When prices recover, Cimarex will be ready and will be stronger and healthier as ever. We have never been more bullish on our assets, our inventory and our organizational capability. Our Delaware Basin and Meramec Woodford assets are top tier. We continue to be pleased with our well results and associated returns on investment. On the call today, you'll hear updates on our Wolfcamp spacing pilots and the implications for future development. We continue to be extremely pleased with our Wolfcamp well performance and have room to run in achieving further performance improvements. You will hear an update on the Meramec Woodford spacing pilots that is underway in Cana. We're testing a combined 19 wells per section in the Meramec and Woodford. The Meramec continues to surprise to the upside. We're currently flowing back Woodford spacing pilots that are testing 10 and 12 Woodford wells per section. Results are very encouraging. Furthermore, our improved Woodford results are showing remarkable consistency across the Cana core. In both the Delaware and Woolford Meramec, long horizontal wells are an increasingly important part of our story, and our assets are well configured to allow for them. We have a manageable lease exploration issue, and we will preserve all of our prime acreage. 
In spite of the downturn of activity, we're emphasizing our core strengths and idea generation and innovation. Our teams are hard at work developing new plays and new concepts. During the downturn of 2009, our activity level dropped from 43 operated rigs to 3. At that time, we challenged the organization to be innovative, creative and to find ways to make a living in spite of the downturn. We were not victims. During 2008, we developed plays that were going to carry us on ensuing years and are still among our core programs today. In 2016, our challenge to organization is to do it again. We are built for these times, however difficult they may be. We will make the tough decisions around capital investments and activity level. We will remain disciplined and preserve our assets and the deep inventory that is our future. We will also seek to build new things and to take advantage of this downturn. No one is hanging their head at Cimarex. We are hard at work to control our own destiny. 
I recently heard a CEO describe some advice that one of his board members have given them. The board member was a retired military officer who told the CEO that he had always told his troops that, "When the map doesn't match the terrain, go with the terrain." Here at Cimarex, we're going with the terrain. During 2015, we increased our rig count to a high of 12 rigs, with an original plan to keep 12 operated rigs throughout 2016. As the year wore and the commodity outlook continued to worsen, we determined that a 12-rig program was no longer prudent. Although we have the inventory to justify the higher activity level at current prices, we've decided to slow down and preserve our cash on hand. Production growth will have to take a backseat to flexibility and balance sheet preservation. Our focus is on a multiyear outlook. We currently have 11 operated rigs running and will be decreasing our rig count to 4 rigs in the coming months. Our 2016 program is designed to preserve our assets on leasehold and finish up delineation and spacing pilots are underway. We plan to invest between $600 million and $650 million in exploration and development. The range of investment is driven by timing of completions in one of the projects currently underway, the Woodford infill well in the eastern core of Cana. Whatever we do not spend in 2016 will be pushed into early 2017. We will also continue to delineate the Meramec drill spacing test in the Wolfcamp in the Delaware Basin and hold leasehold. In the fourth quarter of 2015, we were impacted by severe weather events and took direct hits at both the Western Delaware Basin and in our core Cana field. Furthermore, a planned outage in Delaware Basin added to our problems. I cannot overstate how pleased we were with the response to these events by our organization. Although they had a significant impact on our production volumes, our teams worked valiantly and safely in an extremely hostile conditions in order to restore our production and find creative workarounds to market interruptions. These extraordinary actions don't always evidence themselves in top line reported production numbers, but they humble us and make us deeply proud to be part of an organization that is so dedicated and focused. 
With that, I will turn the call over to John to provide further details on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and development. This brought the total to $877 million for the full year. About 55% was invested in the Permian region with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region. Company-wide, we brought 65 gross, 28 net wells on production during the quarter, which brought the total for 2015 to 219 gross, 99 net wells. 
Cimarex continues to push the envelope on well completions. In the Permian, we completed 2 upper Wolfcamp wells in the fourth quarter using a larger stimulation. As you can see on Slide 14 of our presentation, these wells have seen a 34% higher cumulative production in the first 120 days versus the previous upper Wolfcamp wells. In fact, in one of the wells, [indiscernible] 38 unit #1-H had an average 30-day peak production rate of 2,020 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 51% was gas, 30 -- excuse me, 51% oil, 30% gas and 19% NGL. A record IP from a 7,500-foot Upper Wolfcamp lateral in Culberson County. 
As discussed previously, we started downspacing pilot in the upper Wolfcamp and Culberson County in the fourth quarter. Drilling on these wells will finish this month with completion scheduled to begin in April. First production is expected by the end of May. This fixed well, 7,500-foot lateral pilot will test 2 different spacing designs. One testing 8 wells per section, while the other will test 6 wells per section. Both will be drilled in a staggered pattern. The larger completion I just discussed will be used on this pilot. 
For the rest of 2016, the vast majority of the capital that we will spend in the Permian will be earmarked for acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. Part of this obligation drilling will include 6, 2-mile-long infield wells in Reeves County. These infill wells are located next to a our temper well, the best Wolfcamp well we drilled in rescanning. Similar to our Anaconda pilot, these wells will be drilled using a back staggered pattern, resulting in equivalent of 12 wells per section. We currently have 6 rigs running in the Permian, with one of them drilling a saltwater disposal well in Culberson County. By June, we will be down to 2 rigs for the remainder of the year. 
Now onto the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling on the Cana Woodford row 4 infill development program in the fourth quarter of 2014. Completion from the 7 sections are now finished and all 57 gross wells are producing. Cimarex operated 2 of these sections. Typical development in the Woodford calls for 8 new wells in addition to the parent well on a section. The [indiscernible] section was infield with 9 additional wells, while the Philip section was infilled with 11 new well. For the [indiscernible] section, the average 30-day peak production [indiscernible] was 9.1 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 61% gas, 8% oil, 31% NGL. And the Philips wells produce an average 30-day peak rate of 9.3 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 54% gas, 13% oil, 33% NGL. As you can see on Slide 20 of our presentation, these increased density infill sections are performing very similar to previously infill Woodford section with only 8 new wells. A very encouraging results for us. 
In the fourth quarter 2015, we commenced drilling another Woodford infill well in the East side of the core. This development covers 6 sections, of which Cimarex again operates 2 sections. The entire infill project consists of 50 gross, 23 net wells. Depending on the timing of completions, something that will be worked out with our partner, production from this Cana development is expected to come on line as early as October or perhaps as late as the first quarter of 2017. 
In our emerging Meramec play, we now have production data on 17 operated 5,000-foot laterals. In addition, our second 10,000-foot lateral in the Meramec has been on production since early October. This well, called the vessels 1H-3526x have a 30-day peak IP rate of 14 million cubic feet equivalent per day, including 791 barrels of oil per day. Page 1 and 2 [ph] of the presentation illustrates the average uplift we've seen from the 2 long laterals versus the 5,000-foot laterals drilled to date. They have outperformed the shorter laterals by 69% within 120 days. While we are very encouraged by the initial uplift in IP that we're seeing in these 10,000-foot laterals, we will be carefully monitoring the decline profile in order to determine the ultimate EURs for these long lateral wells. 
To better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have designed a downspacing pilot with commenced drilling in the fourth quarter 2015. See Slide 23 for an illustration of this design. Due to the commodity price environment, this pilot has been downsized, and will now consist of 8 new wells to be stacked and staggered in both the Meramec and Woodford formations. The spacing of the Meramec will be the equivalent of 10 wells per section made up of 5 upper and 5 lower staggered Meramec wells. The Woodford will be drilled with our standard 9 wells per section development plan. Drilling should be finished by mid-April with first production expected late in the second quarter. Once Drilling is finished on the pilot and infill sections, we will be focused on holding our Meramec acreage. Since late 2014, we've added 12,250 net acres in the Meramec at an average cost of $1,650 per acre. We'll need to drill approximately 40 to 45 wells over the next 3 years in order to HPV our position. In 2016, we will drill 12 operated wells to hold this acreage position, with 10 of the 12 wells being 10,000-foot laterals. We currently have 5 rigs operating in the Mid-Continent region, with plans to go down to 1 rig by July of this year. 
with that, I'll turn the call over to the Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. Our f
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. 
Our fourth quarter total company net equivalent production came in at 985.7 million a day, up 4% from the 949.5 million a day that we posted in Q4 '14 and within our guidance of 0.98 to 1.01 Bcfe per day. Late in the quarter, as Tom mentioned, winter weather and facility disruptions negatively impacted our production by approximately 30 million cubic feet a day equivalent, with the majority of that occurring in the Permian. Late December winter storms caused significant downtime in not only the Delaware Basin, but also impacted our Cana production as well, albeit to a lesser degree. When we adjust for the estimated impact of the weather and the facility downtime, we would have exceeded the upper end of our guidance by more than 5 million a day. With Q4 now on the books, our full year 2015 equivalent production came in at 985 million a day. That's up 13% over 2014 average of 869 million a day. During Q4, our Permian equivalent production averaged 520 million a day. That's down 42 million a day from Q3 '15. But as I mentioned, a significant portion of the decrease was a result of not only the -- was a result of the weather and facility downtime, but we also completed fewer Permian wells during the latter half of the year than we did in the first half as we've talked about in our previous call. As expected, with our Cana row 4 wells coming online, we saw a very nice bump in our Q4 Mid-Continent production, with our Mid-Continent volumes coming in at 461 million a day. That's up 14% or 56 million a day from the 405 million a day that we reported just prior in Q3. For 2016, with a number of moving parts, the most sensitive of which is the timing of our 2016 completions, we've issued full year total company equivalent production guidance of 890 million to 930 million equivalents today. With our focus on preserving our assets and protecting our balance sheet and the low price environment we're in, we've opted to slow down and more consistently spread out or completion activity throughout the year. As John mentioned, we also find ourselves needing to coordinate the timing of our Cana Woodford completion activity with the completion timing of our offset operator. As a result, there is considerable variability in the inventory of uncompleted wells that we will have on the books at the end of the year. As we best can project at this time, we anticipate and we've modeled that our Cana infill frac-ing operations will begin in late the third -- late third to fourth quarter and continue into 2017 with first production from the project not hitting our books until early 2017. This program represents a lion's share of our 2016 Mid-Continent activity, consisting of 50 gross and 23 net wells. With our current modeling, we expect to see first production from approximately 50 gross or 16 net Mid-Continent wells during '16, and that's down from 134 gross or 39 net wells that we completed in 2015. With the anticipated Cana infill completion delay, we expect to next year the 57 gross or 24 net wells awaiting completion, hence, moving associated production from those wells into early 2017. 
In the Permian, we also planned for a slower place of completion activity, which will likely only require to utilize just 1 completion crew the majority of the year. We are forecasting approximately 31 net Permian wells to come online in 2016. That's down about half of the 60 net wells that we completed in 2015. As we progress through the year, we project the number of Permian drilled and uncompleted wells to increase to approximately 18 net wells by midyear and then drop off to just 6 net wells by the end of the year, primarily a result of dropping to the 2 [ph] rigs that John mentioned in the Permian in the middle of the year. 
I want to take a moment to make a special point that a quick glance at our 2016 full year guidance could very easily imply a decline in our 2016 exit rate. What's not so easy to see is the forecast of production increase associated with the delayed Cana infill programs back-to-back completion activity in early 2017, which, along with a handful of carryover permit completions, is forecasted to bring our total company production back up to Q4 '15 levels by as early as Q2 '17. It's all about the timing of our completions. 
As far as our Q1 total company production is concerned, incorporating anticipated Permian pipeline and facility curtailments of about 30 million a day for the first quarter, our projected guidance for Q1 comes in at 925 million to 955 million a day. 
Jumping over to CapEx. With our production groups continued focus on trimming operating costs, our Q4 lifting cost came in at $0.85 per Mcfe. That's in line with our guidance of $0.77 to $0.87 and was down 19% from the $1.05 that we posted in Q4 '14. For the year, our 2015 lifting cost came in at $0.83 per Mcfe. That's down a respectable 23% from our 2014 average of $1.08. As we look forward into 2016, our full year lifting cost guidance range of $0.80 and $0.90 per Mcfe takes into account our regional forecasts of production mix as well as a variable nature of work expenses. 
You may have also noted that our Q4 '15 transportation and processing expense came in at $0.58. So it's slightly above our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.55. As I mentioned, our current production modeling forecast a slowdown in our completion activity during the year, which resulted in a onetime accrual of approximately $8 million for anticipated minimum volume agreement shortfalls, which increased our reported cost on a nonrecurring basis by approximately $0.09 per Mcfe. 
We've made great strides cutting our LOE, and we'll continue our efforts to reduce them further. As we mentioned last call, important by-product of our LOE reductions is the additional funding we're providing our drilling program. Our Q4 '15 average monthly LOE came in at $25.7 million a month. And that's $5 million below our Q4 '14 average of $30.7 million a month. But if we average over 12-month time period, has freed up nearly $60 million of the direct to our drawing program. 
A few comments on our drilling and completion cost. Although we continue to push hard for further cost relief, any cost reductions we've seen have been small, single-digit reductions and modest in nature. That said, we continue our focus on operating efficiencies. On the drilling side, we hydrated the rigs, we're bidding out each and every service. We're consolidating our equipment and resources everywhere we can, all the while we're staying focused on reducing drilling days. On the completion side, we're focused on optimizing the cost of water sourcing by more efficient frac-ing our wells, in particular, when we're completing multi-well pads. The bottom line is that while we continue to experience -- experiment with various frac designs, our generic well [indiscernible] has remained relatively flat. Our current Cana core 1 mile lateral Woodford [indiscernible] continues to run in the range of 6.6 million to 7 million. That's unchanged from the last call. While at the Meramec, our current 1-mile lateral AFB is also -- is in the range of $7 million to $7.4 million. That's also unchanged from last quarter. In the Permian, as we've mentioned last call, we've made great progress with our drilling efficiencies, cutting our Wolfcamp 2-mile laterals rig release times down 20% from 35 days in 2014 to 28 days in 2015, with a record of 20.5 days. We're accomplishing similar drill time reductions at our 1-mile lateral Bone Spring and Avalon program as well, cutting average days from spud-to-rig release 35% from 23 days in '14 to just '15 in Q4 '15. We continue to get more done with fewer rigs. 
And with all that, our current 2-mile lateral Wolfcamp AFE is running $10.8 million to $11.6 million. That's flat again to the figures we quoted last call. 
So in closing, we had another great quarter. We fought a significant Q4 downstream weather -- downtime to stay within guidance and provide us with a strong springboard for production into 2016. We posted solid year-over-year production gains over 2014. We've made significant strides cutting our LOE, our drilling group stays focused in cost reductions and efficiencies. And as an organization, we remain vigilant to keep our cost and check, protect our assets and optimize our investment program results. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to question-and-answer.

componenttext: That's a great question. Mark, I'm going to bounce pass that question to you. [indiscernible] it's hard to make a definitive statement, but I will say this, though, before Mark comments, remain highly flexible. And if we see daylight, we're going to run for it. Obviously, in building a company and preserving a balance sheet, you can have all kinds of optimism, but you can't run a company on that optimism to the extent that you're not preserving your balance sheet. But Mark, you know how to answer that.

componenttextpreview: Well, this is Joe. As far as organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in or along existing section, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled and modeled as fa
componenttext: Well, this is Joe. As far as organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in or along existing section, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled and modeled as far as an organization of activity and we came back from it. A getting back on the traction not be that difficult for us. We took a rig out of the yard. We got asked a question last year, and we took a rig out of the yard that on its first wells start setting records for us. So we're not terribly concerned about our ability to ramp up. And I would anticipate there are first place to ramp up would be the Permian.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot had t
componenttext: Yes, this is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot had talked about. Our long lateral Bone Spring play, up in White City, is very, very strong, economics. And even part of our Woodford development in the eastern core, which is more liquid-rich, especially as we look at from a long lateral perspective, which our acreage allows us to the, looks pretty attractive to us, but we would like us a little bit more encouragement from the commodity price before we want to deploy capital in those programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I just want to finish your question, but I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, we
componenttext: Yes, and I just want to finish your question, but I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, we're going to look at it. I don't know want to throw any particular number down and say, "That's the number." We have the flexibility. We have the balance sheet to do it. I mean it's meant to be what our vision is. I mean if there was some structural changes in all markets and reason for long-term optimism, we would be prepared to go after that.

componenttext: Okay, great. Last one for me. Can you guys discuss if you reached or surpassed the economic limits of advance conditions across the various areas throughout the Permian and the Mid-Con?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And the simple answer, no. No way that we feel like we reach the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that going to the frac design. And quite frankly, I'm [indiscernible] amazed how certain tw
componenttext: Well, this is John. And the simple answer, no. No way that we feel like we reach the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that going to the frac design. And quite frankly, I'm [indiscernible] amazed how certain tweaks lead to even better and better wells. So no, we are not at all feel like we've reached the point where we can get more reserves out of these laterals. And quite honestly, at some of our charge right now, given the environment we find, for every  dollar we invest in those wells, we need to get more out of those wells. And so far, I'm very pleased that we've been able to achieve that with a number of our programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I want to -- this is Tom. Just want to follow up to that. John, in this morning, 7:00 in my office just arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point. But one of nice things about having assets and the most active
componenttext: Yes, and I want to -- this is Tom. Just want to follow up to that. John, in this morning, 7:00 in my office just arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point. But one of nice things about having assets and the most active, prolific years in the country, is there's a lot of activity. And we study our competition really hard. It's pretty important if you can have an innovative culture, you can't have a needs to be invented mentality. So we're always looking to see what others are doing. And I think we have a lot of room for improvement. I would say in both our corridors, the Delaware Basin and Meramec, the things others are doing that, yes, we have opinions on. And at the end of the day, this is just trial and error and we need to try something.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So if we can take that one off the table. So as we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset, and I'd love to sit here in the call, put lipstick on and say, "You
componenttext: Well, you kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So if we can take that one off the table. So as we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset, and I'd love to sit here in the call, put lipstick on and say, "You know what, it's one thing." But as you look ahead in running the company, we have to look at the ins and outs of cash flow balance. And so we look into what -- as said in my opening remarks, we spent a lot of time last year looking at our assets and looking at the future drilling inventory and the value that adds. And we've made a tremendous amount of progress in our flexibility and our ability to do real-time modeling of future increases in price, future increases in activity and actually modeling the impact that has fully looking at our cash flow and our balance sheet. But when you do that, one of the reasons that we're doing that is because if prices don't pick up at any point, we want to make sure that Cimarex stays healthy and stays competitive. And we don't want to put ourselves in a situation where we've lost our flexibly. So inherently, that modeling is kind of a downside model. It's really easy to run an upside model. But you have to kind of plan of the downside. And so we're -- as we look ahead to the next few years, I would say that if things don't materially improve over the current strip, Cimarex will be just fine. We'll be healthy financially and will be in a position where we attempt to throttle into that future without increasing debt. But if things increase, if commodity prices pick up, we are ready to roll. I know I'm not giving you -- I'm not giving you detailed answer on what our 2017 and beyond model looks like, but we're making decisions to keep Cimarex competitive and to preserve our assets. Mark, do you want to add to that?

componenttext: I appreciate all the clarity around that. There's one more, and it might -- John, you reminded at all us about Alawite. Might not be appreciating the amount of production that can come on from 50 Cana wells and the infill towards the end of the year beginning of next. And you said 2Q of '17 could be back up the levels of 4Q '15 conceptually. You're running 4 other rigs total, much of that is for HBP and acreage. So as you think about going in 2017 and 2018, is -- would future rig activity or incremental rig activity be devoted to doing a very large pad our multi-sectioned developments where we would have this sort of persistent lumpiness until things smooth out where you have a larger rig fleet that's called up everything?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point in want to get back to where true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity rigs and paths and so forth. But we just don't know at what p
componenttext: Yes, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point in want to get back to where true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity rigs and paths and so forth. But we just don't know at what point we will be back there. Here's what I know. For this year, going forward, our main goal, as Tom alluded to, is both the balance sheet and more importantly protecting investments we made in the acreage that we picked up in both the Anadarko as well as the Permian Basin. We have a wonderful acreage, and we've got it at a very attractive price and essentially for this year's program, as we go up to the end of the year, that's where our capital is going to be geared toward is preserving that acreage position so that we are in a very good position. Whenever the time is right, then go back to that full scale development. When that will be? I can't tell you at this point.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I've find myself doing a spent a lot of time looking at just flat price returns, I just don't spend much
componenttext: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I've find myself doing a spent a lot of time looking at just flat price returns, I just don't spend much time looking at strip right now. And then we look at those flat prices, and we ask ourselves, "Is this a good investment?" Especially these wells we're drilling to hold acreage. And in this environment, it's tough, I will admit. But when we look at that and look at the future potential that section we're holding, we still feel like we're making very good investment and drilling those wells. So right now, again, we definitely look at the ROE. And quite frankly, that means some of the acreage that we have will not be held because no matter what scenario, whatever flat price I look at, it's hard to envision how holding a certain set of acreage is in best interest of Cimarex. That said, we have a lot of good acreage to hold there on, and I'm very pleased that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Janine, this is Tom. We're down to around $30 on NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices, and we will the [indiscernible] whatever market to get a wellhead. And we like to see our cost of capital or better at that flat pric
componenttext: Janine, this is Tom. We're down to around $30 on NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices, and we will the [indiscernible] whatever market to get a wellhead. And we like to see our cost of capital or better at that flat price. And then we'll also look at the strip. And let me just answer your question this way. If we were forced to increase activity and we had an ATAX 25 hurdle rate, we have lots to do in our portfolio. If we weren't tasked with holding acreage and we can just go drill at will and there were no other considerations, when we look at these long laterals in the Wolfcamp, the long laterals in the Cana, Meramec play, we have lots of them that generate, what I would say, are acceptable returns at current strip. But as John said, we have a lot of considerations currently. We don't think prices will stay here forever, and we have some outstanding acreage that we'd like to hold, not all of which can be developed at long laterals. We have partner considerations. And then we also have some science that we want to get done that will really set up the future. So it's a balancing act. One thing we will not do, one thing we will absolutely not do is liquidate this company because we're in a $30 oil environment. So we'll make judgment calls as we see fit.

componenttext: Drew, this is Tom. I want to be clear, and I think have been, we've actually made this tactical decision to try to keep as much cash in our balance sheet so that we we're well positioned when the situation turns around. We think that the best activity level for Cimarex in 2016 is preservation mode. We want to make sure we preserve our assets. We preserve our obligations and we preserve our flexibility. But our goal is to keep as much cash as we can in the balance sheet as we look ahead so that we are well positioned to strike when we see some daylight.

componenttext: Well, I can tell you, we look at our programs, we look at different frac prices like the one Tom mentioned. And we are very anxious to get that spacing pilot in so we can start to hone in on exactly what the full potential is for that zone for us from a development standpoint.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarification questions. On the theoretical 2017 production with the timing of the Cana completion, I just wanted to clarify when thinking about the exit rate Q4 '15 of about 985 million a day, would the thought be that with the Cana completions, the total corporate production could reach that level again by kind of Q2 2017, if everything kind of stays on plan as you guys envision it at the moment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of the worst case where production doesn't start first half or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17. And if we speed up
componenttext: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of the worst case where production doesn't start first half or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17. And if we speed up things, we might find ourselves in maybe the Q1 time period. So again, it's all timing. And somebody with the questions alluded to the fact that these are big projects. You've got multiple wells all coming on at once. And you saw what go forward you did it for us from Q3 to Q4, significant increase in the Cana production, 405 in Mid-Continent, 405 million to 461 million a day. So those are big swings. You can see the difference between our Q4 -- if you apply Q4 exit rate of -- with a typical decline or whatever. We're going to be in the high 800s. And all of a sudden, 2 quarters later, we're 100 million a day higher than that. So it's just the nature of the beast, and it's all about timing.

And you have a downspacing pilot this year, but any plans to test the flanks of your acreage position there at all in 2016? headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be essentially to hold our acreage. A part of it will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised, not just by our results, but
componenttext: Yes, this is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be essentially to hold our acreage. A part of it will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised, not just by our results, but as Tom alluded to, a lot of competitor results that are kind of changing the landscape within the map in the, Meramec. Especially as we look towards where the Western side. It's looking much more attractive to us. And fortunately for us, what we have a pretty nice position there. In fact, that's where a lot of the new leasing that we picked up is in more of that area. So yes, throughout the rest of this year will be geographically spreading across that map quite a bit with the was that we be drilling and that will just help us further delineate the full potential for this interval.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's Tom. Just want to follow up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair availability of results with landing zone. Landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that has surp
componenttext: Jason, it's Tom. Just want to follow up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair availability of results with landing zone. Landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that has surprised as compared to the Woodford below it. And so I think as we go forward, you're probably going to hear us talking more and more about the Mississippi as opposed to the Meramec. Yet on the lower section, you hear the Osage being talked about is a target. And that's looking more and more interesting to us. There are some really good wells up there that are hard to explain if you only have the Meramec to explain it with. And so as John said, there's a tremendous amount of upside for us not only in our acreage but also in our operational improvements as we test landing zones and then also completions. We're pretty bullish on that play right now and our position and although we generally rule competition everywhere, they [indiscernible] than it's giving us a lot of good information, and it's just trying to give us a very good positive light of our competition.

componenttext: No, absolutely right. I'll just point out the Bone Spring component, essentially those wells are drilled, and so they'll be completed in the first half. And then all of the rigs for the rest of the year will be dedicated to a Wolfcamp toward finishing up the pilots. And then the rest of the time, it's all about acreage holding. So yes, there's a component of Bone Spring, but that's early in the year, and everything else and the rest of the year is Wolfcamp.

componenttext: Well, this is John. And I would just say, as I've alluded to in my comments, we have a partner, and we develop these rows. We coordinate with our partner from a standpoint of the frac calendar. We recognize that to achieve the optimal result, we have to work together. We have to time our frac schedule appropriately as we bring these wells on. Our partner has indicated to us that, at this time, they would like to delay that frac schedule. And so we are working with them and coordinating with them to the best of our ability. We have emphasized we'd like to move it up some, if we could. We decide to position they're taking, but I think we would like to move it up in the year if we could. And we're having those ongoing discussions right now. And we'll see where it ends. I think what we've done is we presented you maybe, if you could call it the worse case scenario where they get pushed all the way to early '17. But as a chance perhaps we can push them earlier into '16. That would be our preference.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today, we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today, we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated presentation has been posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during the call today. 
As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. 
So today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, Senior VP of Exploration; and then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on our operations, including production and well cost. Cimarex CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of our recent results and update you on some of the delineation that we have underway in 2016. Joe will provide an operational overview. 
I would like to kick off the call with some overview remarks and our direction in 2016 and beyond. During 2015, we put a lot of energy into long-range planning and we developed capabilities for running detailed iterations on current and future years CapEx, cash flow and balance sheet configuration. We scrubbed our assets and developed net asset value models that help us to fully understand our upside and plan accordingly. 
Today, we are making decisions for 2016 with a close eye on 2017, 2018 and beyond. Cimarex is better positioned for the future by slowing down a bit, preserving our cash and assets and living within our means. Our focus is on preservation of our assets and balance sheet. We don't have any special insight on when or how commodity prices will recover. We do know that we will probably be as surprised by the recovery as we were by the collapse. When prices recover, Cimarex will be ready and will be stronger and healthier as ever. 
We have never been more bullish on our assets, our inventory and our organizational capability. Our Delaware Basin and Meramec/Woodford assets are top tier. We continue to be pleased with our well results and associated returns on investment. On the call today, you'll hear updates on our Wolfcamp spacing pilots and the implications for future development. 
We continue to be extremely pleased with our Wolfcamp well performance and have room to run in achieving further performance improvements. You will hear an update on the Meramec/Woodford spacing pilots that is underway in Cana. We're testing a combined 19 wells per section in the Meramec and Woodford. The Meramec continues to surprise to the upside. We are currently flowing back Woodford spacing pilots that are testing 10 and 12 Woodford wells per section. Results are very encouraging. 
Furthermore, our improved Woodford results are showing remarkable consistency across the Cana core. In both the Delaware and Woodford/Meramec, long horizontal wells are an increasingly important part of our story and our assets are well configured to allow for them. We have a manageable lease exploration issue and we will preserve all of our prime acreage. 
In spite of the downturn of activity, we're emphasizing our core strengths and idea generation and innovation. Our teams are hard at work developing new plays and new concepts. During the downturn of 2009, our activity level dropped from 43 operated rigs to 3. At that time, we challenged the organization to be innovative, creative and to find ways to make a living in spite of the downturn. We were not victims. 
During 2009, we developed plays that were going to carry us on the ensuing years and are still among our core programs today. In 2016, our challenge to the organization is to do it again. We are built for these times, however difficult they may be. We will make the tough decisions around capital investments and activity level. We will remain disciplined and preserve our assets and the deep inventory that is our future. We will also seek to build new things and to take advantage of this downturn. No one is hanging their head at Cimarex. We are hard at work to control our own destiny. 
I recently heard a CEO describe some advice that one of his board members have given them. The board member was a retired military officer who told the CEO that he had always told his troops that, "When the map doesn't match the terrain, go with the terrain." Here at Cimarex, we're going with the terrain. During 2015, we increased our rig count to a high of 12 rigs, with an original plan to keep 12 operated rigs throughout 2016. As the year wore on and the commodity outlook continued to worsen, we determined that a 12-rig program was no longer prudent. 
Although we have the inventory to justify the higher activity level even at current prices, we have decided to slow down and preserve our cash on hand. Production growth will have to take a backseat to flexibility and balance sheet preservation. Our focus is on a multiyear outlook. We currently have 11 operated rigs running and we'll be decreasing our rig count to 4 rigs in the coming months. Our 2016 program is designed to preserve our assets on leasehold and finish up some delineation and spacing pilots that are underway. 
We plan to invest between $600 million and $650 million in exploration and development. The range of investment is driven by timing of completions in one of the projects currently underway, the Woodford infill well in the Eastern core of Cana. Whatever we do not spend in 2016 will be pushed into early 2017. We will also continue to delineate the Meramec drill spacing test in the Wolfcamp in the Delaware Basin and hold leasehold. 
In the fourth quarter of 2015, we were impacted by severe weather events and took direct hits at both the Western Delaware Basin and in our core Cana field. Furthermore, a planned outage in Delaware Basin added to our problems. I cannot overstate how pleased we were with the response to these events by our organization. Although they had a significant impact on our production volumes, our teams worked valiantly and safely in extremely hostile conditions in order to restore our production and find creative workarounds to market interruptions. These extraordinary actions don't always evidence themselves in top line reported production numbers, but they humble us and make us deeply proud to be part of an organization that is so dedicated and focused. 
With that, I will turn the call over to John to provide further details on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and development. This brought the total to $877 million for the full year. About 55% was invested in the Permian region with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region. Company-wide, we brought 65 gross, 28 net wells on production during the quarter, which brought the total for 2015 to 219 gross, 99 net wells. 
Cimarex continues to push the envelope on well completions. In the Permian, we completed 2 Upper Wolfcamp wells in the fourth quarter using a larger stimulation. As you can see on Slide 14 of our presentation, these wells have seen a 34% higher cumulative production in the first 120 days versus the previous Upper Wolfcamp wells. In fact, one of the wells, Mine That Bird 38 Unit #1-H had an average 30-day peak production rate of 2,020 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 51% was gas, 30% -- excuse me, 51% oil, 30% gas and 19% NGL. A record IP from a 7,500-foot Upper Wolfcamp lateral in Culberson County. 
As discussed previously, we spud a downspacing pilot in the Upper Wolfcamp and Culberson County in the fourth quarter. Drilling on these wells will be finished this month with completion scheduled to begin in April. First production is expected by the end of May. This fixed well, 7,500-foot lateral pilot will test 2 different spacing designs. One testing 8 wells per section, while the other will test 6 wells per section. Both will be drilled in a staggered pattern. The larger completion I just discussed will be used on this pilot. 
For the rest of 2016, the vast majority of the capital that we will spend in the Permian will be earmarked for acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. Part of this obligation drilling will include 6, 2-mile-long infill wells in Reeves County. These infill wells are located next to our Big Timber well, the best Wolfcamp well we drilled in Reeves County. 
Similar to our Anaconda pilot, these wells will be drilled using a stacked/staggered pattern, resulting in equivalent of 12 wells per section. We currently have 6 rigs running in the Permian, with one of them drilling a saltwater disposal well in Culberson County. By June, we will be down to 2 rigs for the remainder of the year. 
Now on to the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling on the Cana-Woodford Row 4 infill development program in the fourth quarter of 2014. Completion from the 7 sections are now finished and all 57 gross wells are producing. Cimarex operated 2 of these sections. Typical development in the Woodford calls for 8 new wells in addition to the parent well on a section. The Armacost section was infilled with 9 additional wells, while the Phillips section was infilled with 11 new wells. 
For the Armacost section, the average 30-day peak production was 9.1 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 61% gas, 8% oil, 31% NGL. And the Phillips wells produced an average 30-day peak rate of 9.3 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 54% gas, 13% oil, 33% NGL. As you can see on Slide 20 of our presentation, these increased density infill sections are performing very similar to previously infilled Woodford section with only 8 new wells. A very encouraging results for us. 
In the fourth quarter 2015, we commenced drilling another Woodford infill well in the East side of the core. This development covers 6 sections, of which Cimarex again operates 2 sections. The entire infill project consists of 50 gross, 23 net wells. Depending on the timing of completions, something that will be worked out with our partner, production from this East Cana development row is expected to come on line as early as October or perhaps as late as the first quarter of 2017. 
In our emerging Meramec play, we now have production data on 17 operated 5,000-foot laterals. In addition, our second 10,000-foot lateral in the Meramec has been on production since early October. This well, called the Vessels 1H-3526X has a 30-day peak IP rate of 14 million cubic feet equivalent per day, including 791 barrels of oil per day. 
Page 22 of the presentation illustrates the average uplift we've seen from the 2 long laterals versus the 5,000-foot laterals drilled to date. They have outperformed the shorter laterals by 69% within 120 days. While we are very encouraged by the initial uplift in IP that we're seeing in these 10,000-foot laterals, we will be carefully monitoring the decline profile in order to determine the ultimate EURs for these long lateral wells. 
To better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have designed a downspacing pilot with commenced drilling in the fourth quarter 2015. See Slide 23 for an illustration of this design. Due to the commodity price environment, this pilot has been downsized. It will now consist of 8 new wells to be stacked and staggered in both the Meramec and Woodford formations. The spacing of the Meramec would be the equivalent of 10 wells per section made up of 5 upper and 5 lower staggered Meramec wells. The Woodford will be drilled with our standard 9 wells per section development plan. Drilling should be finished by mid-April with first production expected late in the second quarter. 
Once drilling is finished on the pilot and infill sections, we will be focused on holding our Meramec acreage. Since the late 2014, we've added 12,250 net acres in the Meramec at an average cost of $1,650 per acre. We'll need to drill approximately 40 to 45 wells over the next 3 years in order to HBP our position. In 2016, we will drill 12 operated wells to hold this acreage position, with 10 of the 12 wells being 10,000-foot laterals. We currently have 5 rigs operating in the Mid-Continent region, with plans to go down the 1 rig by July of this year. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. Our f
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. 
Our fourth quarter total company net equivalent production came in at 985.7 million a day, up 4% from the 949.5 million a day that we posted in Q4 '14 and within our guidance of 0.98 to 1.01 Bcfe per day. Late in the quarter, as Tom mentioned, winter weather and facility disruptions negatively impacted our production by approximately 30 million cubic feet a day equivalent, with the majority of that occurring in the Permian. 
Late December winter storms caused significant downtime in not only the Delaware Basin, but also impacted our Cana production as well, albeit to a lesser degree. When we adjust for the estimated impact of the weather and the facility downtime, we would have exceeded the upper end of our guidance by more than 5 million a day. With Q4 now on the books, our full year 2015 equivalent production came in at 985 million a day, that's up 13% over 2014 average of 869 million a day. 
During Q4, our Permian equivalent production averaged 520 million a day, that's down 42 million a day from Q3 '15. But as I mentioned, a significant portion of the decrease was a result of not only the -- was a result of the weather and facility downtime, but we also completed fewer Permian wells during the latter half of the year than we did in the first half as we've talked about in our previous calls. As expected, with our Cana Row 4 wells coming online, we saw a very nice bump in our Q4 Mid-Continent production, with our Mid-Continent volumes coming in at 461 million a day, that's up 14% or 56 million a day from the 405 million a day that we reported just prior in Q3. 
For 2016, with a number of moving parts, the most sensitive of which is the timing of our 2016 completions, we've issued full year total company equivalent production guidance of 890 million to 930 million equivalents today. With our focus on preserving our assets and protecting our balance sheet in the low price environment we're in, we've opted to slow down and more consistently spread out or completion activity throughout the year. As John mentioned, we also find ourselves needing to coordinate the timing of our Cana-Woodford completion activity with the completion timing of our offset operator. 
As a result, there is considerable variability in the inventory of uncompleted wells that we will have on the books at the end of the year. As we best can project at this time, we anticipate and we've modeled that our Cana infill fracking operations will begin in late to third -- late third to fourth quarter and continue into 2017, with first production from the project not hitting our books until early 2017. This program represents a lion's share of our 2016 Mid-Continent activity consisting of 50 gross and 23 net wells. 
With our current modeling, we expect to see first production from approximately 50 gross or 16 net Mid-Continent wells during '16, and that's down from 134 gross or 39 net wells that we completed in 2015. With the anticipated Cana infill completion delay, we expect to exit the year the 57 gross or 24 net wells awaiting completion. Hence, moving associated production for those wells into early 2017. 
In the Permian, we also planned for a slower pace of completion activity, which will likely only require us to utilize just one completion crew for the majority of the year. We're forecasting approximately 31 net Permian wells to come online in 2016, that's down about half of the 60 net wells that we completed in 2015. As we progress through the year, we project the number of Permian drilled and uncompleted wells to increase to approximately 18 net wells by midyear and then drop off to just 6 net wells by the end of the year, primarily a result of us dropping to the 2 rigs that John mentioned in the Permian in the middle of the year. 
I want to take a moment to make a special point that a quick glance at our 2016 full year guidance could very easily imply a decline in our 2016 exit rate. What's not so easy to see is the forecast of production increase associated with the delayed Cana infill programs back-to-back completion activity in early 2017 which, along with a handful of Permian carryover completions, is forecasted to bring our total company production back up to Q4 '15 levels by as early as Q2 '17. It's all about the timing of our completions. 
As far as our Q1 total company production is concerned, incorporating anticipated Permian pipeline and facility curtailments of about 30 million a day for the first quarter, our projected guidance for Q1 comes in at 925 million to 955 million a day. 
Jumping over to CapEx. With our production groups continued focus on trimming operating costs, our Q4 lifting cost came in at $0.85 per Mcfe. That's in line with our guidance of $0.77 to $0.87 and was down 19% from the $1.05 that we posted in Q4 '14. For the year, our 2015 lifting cost came in at $0.83 per Mcfe. That's down a respectable 23% from our 2014 average of $1.08. As we look forward into 2016, our full year lifting cost guidance range of $0.80 to $0.90 per Mcfe takes into account our regional forecasted production mix as well as the variable nature of workover expenses. 
You may have also noted that our Q4 '15 transportation and processing expense came in at $0.58. So it's slightly above our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.55. As I mentioned, our current production modeling forecast a slowdown in our completion activity during the year, which resulted in a onetime accrual of approximately $8 million for anticipated minimum volume agreement shortfalls, which increased our reported cost on a nonrecurring basis by approximately $0.09 per Mcfe. 
We've made great strides cutting our LOE and we'll continue our efforts to reduce them further. As we mentioned last call, the important by-product of our LOE reductions is the additional funding we're providing our drilling program. Our Q4 '15 average monthly LOE came in at $25.7 million a month and that's $5 million below our Q4 '14 average of $30.7 million a month, which if we average that over a 12-month time period has freed up nearly $60 million that we can direct to our drilling program. 
A few comments on our drilling and completion cost. Although we continue to push hard for further cost relief, any cost reductions we've seen have been small, single-digit reductions and modest in nature. That said, we continue our focus on operating efficiencies. On the drilling side, we've high-graded our rigs, we're bidding out each and every service, we're consolidating our equipment and resources everywhere we can, all the while we're staying focused on reducing drilling days. 
On the completion side, we're focused on optimizing the cost of water sourcing by more efficiently fracking our wells, in particular, when we're completing multi-well pads. The bottom line is that while we continue to experience -- experiment with various frac designs, our generic well AFEs have remained relatively flat. Our current Cana core 1-mile lateral Woodford AFE continues to run in the range of $6.6 million to $7 million, that's unchanged from the last call. While in the Meramec, our current 1-mile lateral AFE is also -- is in the range of $7 million to $7.4 million, that's also unchanged from last quarter. 
In the Permian, as we've mentioned last call, we've made great progress with our drilling efficiencies, cutting our Wolfcamp 2-mile laterals, but the rig release time is down 20% from 35 days in 2014 to 28 days in 2015 with a record of 20.5 days. We're accomplishing similar drill time reductions in a 1-mile lateral Bone Spring and Avalon program as well, cutting average days from spud-to-rig release 35% from 23 days in '14 to just '15 in Q4 '15. We continue to get more done with fewer rigs. And with all that, our current 2-mile lateral Wolfcamp AFE is running $10.8 million to $11.6 million, that's flat again to the figures we quoted last call. 
So in closing, we had another great quarter. We fought a significant Q4 downstream weather -- downtime to stay within guidance and provide us with a strong springboard for production in 2016. We posted solid year-over-year production gains over 2014. We've made significant strides cutting our LOE. Our drilling group stays focused on cost reductions and efficiencies. And as an organization, we remain vigilant to keep our cost in check, protect our assets and optimize our investment program results. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to question-and-answer.
