But just curious when you think you would add rigs back since you do have some the lowest cost production throughout the U.S.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. That's a great question. Mark, I'm going to bounce pass that to you. We run tens of models and it's hard to make a definitive statement. I will say this though, before Mark comments, we remain highly flexible. And if we see daylight, we're go
componenttext: This is Tom. That's a great question. Mark, I'm going to bounce pass that to you. We run tens of models and it's hard to make a definitive statement. I will say this though, before Mark comments, we remain highly flexible. And if we see daylight, we're going to run for it. Obviously, in building a company and preserving a balance sheet, you can have all kinds of optimism, but you can't run a company on that optimism to the extent that you're not preserving your balance sheet. But Mark, you know how to answer that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Dan, certainly, what Tom is referring to -- there's 2 primary concerns we have right now watching our return on our investments, making sure we get adequate return which isn't the highest, isn't the biggest concern, it's more -- was not preserving o
componenttext: Sure. Dan, certainly, what Tom is referring to -- there's 2 primary concerns we have right now watching our return on our investments, making sure we get adequate return which isn't the highest, isn't the biggest concern, it's more -- was not preserving our balance sheet. So we have cash flow sufficient to really support a larger program, which we're really trying to constrain our investment to make sure we preserve a very strong balance sheet, preserve our cash position and [indiscernible] through this. But I think if you saw our price environment stabilize, settling in around $45 to $50, you would probably see us having cash flow supporting a larger program. But if below $30 environment we find ourselves in, that's where we're constraining our investment to the extent that we are which is -- it probably have to be some clarity and certainty around that $45 to $50 price for us to see that mix in upward adjustments in our investment pace.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess are there any limiting factors in terms of how quickly you could add whether that be personal or infrastructure? And then I guess, what area would your first incremental rigs target should we get to that $40 to $50 environment?
componenttext: Okay. I guess are there any limiting factors in terms of how quickly you could add whether that be personal or infrastructure? And then I guess, what area would your first incremental rigs target should we get to that $40 to $50 environment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Joe. As far as our organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in and along our existing infrastructure, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled a
componenttext: Well, this is Joe. As far as our organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in and along our existing infrastructure, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled and modeled as far as our organizational activity, and we just peered back from it. So getting back on the track should not be that difficult for us.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We took a rig out of the yard. We got asked that question last year and we took a rig out of the yard that on its first well, it started setting records for us. So we're not terribly concerned about our ability to ramp up. And I would anticipate that our
componenttext: We took a rig out of the yard. We got asked that question last year and we took a rig out of the yard that on its first well, it started setting records for us. So we're not terribly concerned about our ability to ramp up. And I would anticipate that our first place to ramp up would be the Permian.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we'd love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot I t
componenttext: Yes. This is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we'd love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot I talked about. Our long lateral Bone Spring play, up in White City is very, very strong economics. And even part of our Woodford development in the Eastern core, which is more liquid-rich especially if we look at it from a long lateral perspective, which our acreage allows us to the, looks pretty attractive to us. But we would like to see a little bit more encouragement from the commodity price before we want to go and deploy capital in these programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I just want to finish your question by -- I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, w
componenttext: Yes. And I just want to finish your question by -- I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, we're going to look at it. I don't know want to throw any particular number down and say that's the number. We have the flexibility. We have the balance sheet to do it. I mean it's going to be what our vision is. I mean if there was some structural changes in the oil markets and there are reasons for long-term optimism, we would be prepared to act to that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Last one for me. Can you guys discuss if you feel you've reached or surpassed the productive and economic limits of enhanced completions across your various areas throughout the Permian and the Mid-Con?
componenttext: Okay. Great. Last one for me. Can you guys discuss if you feel you've reached or surpassed the productive and economic limits of enhanced completions across your various areas throughout the Permian and the Mid-Con?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And a simple answer, no. No way do we feel like we've reached the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that go into that frac design. And quite frankly, I'm constantly amazed how certain tweaks
componenttext: Well, this is John. And a simple answer, no. No way do we feel like we've reached the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that go into that frac design. And quite frankly, I'm constantly amazed how certain tweaks lead to even better and better wells. So no, we are not at all feel like we've reached the point where we can get more reserves out of these laterals. And quite honestly, that's some -- that's our charge right now. Given the environment we find, for every  dollar we invest in those wells, we need to get more out of those wells. And so far, I'm been very pleased that we've been able to achieve that with a number of our programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I want to -- this is Tom. I want to follow up to that. John and I started off first thing this morning at 7:00 in my office arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point that one of nice things about having assets
componenttext: Yes. And I want to -- this is Tom. I want to follow up to that. John and I started off first thing this morning at 7:00 in my office arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point that one of nice things about having assets in 3 of the most active, prolific areas of the country, is there's a lot of activity. And we study our competition really hard. It's pretty important if you're going to have an innovative culture, you can't have a needs-to-be-invented-here mentality. And so we're always looking to see what others are doing. And I think we have a lot of room for improvement. I would say in both our core areas, the Delaware Basin and Meramec. There's lots of things others are doing that we have opinions on. But at the end of the day, some of this is just trial and error and we need to try some things.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question will come from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on all the commentary. Tom, in your opening remarks, you said you're looking very closely at '16, '17 and '18 as a -- I guess, putting some color around that, is it looking closely at what -- what sort of goals would you like to achieve
componenttext: Just to follow-up on all the commentary. Tom, in your opening remarks, you said you're looking very closely at '16, '17 and '18 as a -- I guess, putting some color around that, is it looking closely at what -- what sort of goals would you like to achieve at the field level, looking closely at what your debt metrics are, looking closely at how much cash you have or a production growth scenario?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you've kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So all that if we can take that one off the table. As we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset. And I love to sit here on the call, put lipstick on and sa
componenttext: Well, you've kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So all that if we can take that one off the table. As we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset. And I love to sit here on the call, put lipstick on and say, "You know what, it's one thing." But as you look ahead in running a company, we have to look at the ins and outs of cash flow balance. And so we look into what -- I said in my opening remarks, we spent a lot of time last year looking at our assets and looking at the future drilling inventory and the value that adds. And we've made a tremendous amount of progress in our flexibility and our ability to do real-time modeling of future increases in price, future increases in activity and actually modeling the impact that has fully looking at our cash flow and our balance sheet. But when you do that, one of the reasons that we're doing that is because if prices don't pick up at any point, we want to make sure that Cimarex stays healthy and stays competitive. And we don't want to put ourselves in a situation where we've lost our flexibly. So inherently, that model is kind of a downside model. It's really easy to run an upside model, but you have to kind of plan on the downside. And so we're -- as we look ahead to the next few years, I will say that if things don't materially improve over the current strip, Cimarex will be just fine. We'll be healthy financially and we'll be in a position where we attempt to model into that future without increasing debt. But if things increase, if commodity prices pick up, we are ready to roll. I know I'm not giving you -- I'm not giving you detailed answer on what our 2017 and beyond model looks like, but we're making decisions to keep Cimarex competitive and to preserve our assets. Mark, do you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that's right, Tom. When we look at these different scenarios today we -- it's obviously, some book entries and strip influences a lot of our thinking right now in the 4 strips in the low-40s to '17 and only 45 by '18 in a recent stripping holding
componenttext: Yes. No, that's right, Tom. When we look at these different scenarios today we -- it's obviously, some book entries and strip influences a lot of our thinking right now in the 4 strips in the low-40s to '17 and only 45 by '18 in a recent stripping holding. And looking at what our activity levels could be at those different price picks, conserving our balance sheet strength and seeing what fits within that cash flow without really having to incur -- in preserving some portion of our cash balance and not incurring incremental debt looking -- look like into the future years. And it is -- in this current strip environment, low-40s and 30s are very challenging for us to find the pace of -- our cash flow can support our pace development. So what iterations we're running all the time, looking at different sensitivities and different programs. And as Joe remarks in his comments, even for this year, there's an impact of those well completions, can have very big impacts on our timing of our production. And so we're running a lot of iterations just looking at what the outlook could be for this year and from the years out.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the clarity around that. Just one more, if it might. John, you reminded all of us about kind of we might not be appreciating the amount of production that can come on from 50 Cana wells and the infill towards the end of the year, beginnin
componenttext: I appreciate all the clarity around that. Just one more, if it might. John, you reminded all of us about kind of we might not be appreciating the amount of production that can come on from 50 Cana wells and the infill towards the end of the year, beginning of next. And you said 2Q of '17 could be back up the levels of 4Q '15 conceptually. You're running 4 other or 4 rigs total, much of that is for HBP and acreage. So as you think about going in 2017 and 2018, is -- would future rig activity or incremental rig activity be devoted to doing a very large pad or multi-sectioned developments where we would have this sort of persistent lumpiness until things smooth out where you have a larger rig fleet that's caught up to everything?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point that we want to get back toward true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity of rigs and pads and so forth. But we just don't know at
componenttext: Well, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point that we want to get back toward true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity of rigs and pads and so forth. But we just don't know at what point we will be back there. Here's what I know, I know for this year and going forward, our main goal, as Tom alluded to, is both the balance sheet and more importantly protecting investments we made in the acreage that we picked up in both the Anadarko as well as the Permian Basin. We have a wonderful acreage and we've got it at a very attractive price. And essentially for this year's program, as we go up to the end of the year, that's where our capital is going to be geared toward is preserving that acreage position so that we are in a very good position. Whenever the time is right to then go back to that full scale development. When that will be? I can't tell you at this point.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Jeanine Wai of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Jeanine Wai of Citi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about your forecasted outspend for 2016 on whenever price deck you're using, it sounds like the strip. There appears to be a fair amount of non-D&C spend that might be driving some of the outspend.
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about your forecasted outspend for 2016 on whenever price deck you're using, it sounds like the strip. There appears to be a fair amount of non-D&C spend that might be driving some of the outspend.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeanine, this is Mark here. Yes, so in our 2016 outspend, about $600 million, $650 million of capital using a recent strip price around $34, $2.20 gas. We're looking at coming into your $739 million of cash. We're looking at exiting the year somewhere aro
componenttext: Jeanine, this is Mark here. Yes, so in our 2016 outspend, about $600 million, $650 million of capital using a recent strip price around $34, $2.20 gas. We're looking at coming into your $739 million of cash. We're looking at exiting the year somewhere around $400 million of cash in 2016.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you give a little bit of clarity on what that non-DNC is?
componenttext: And can you give a little bit of clarity on what that non-DNC is?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the non-D&C drilling is comprised of about $35 million we're targeting for a leasehold acquisition, $720 million roughly for capitalized overhead and about $40 million for production capital or production group capital for recompletion and then we
componenttext: Yes. So the non-D&C drilling is comprised of about $35 million we're targeting for a leasehold acquisition, $720 million roughly for capitalized overhead and about $40 million for production capital or production group capital for recompletion and then well maintenance, deep wells.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then you mentioned that ROR is not the only factor in determining activity for this year, but can you give us a little sense of whether you have an after-tax IRR hurdle in this environment? Or kind of what the after-tax returns are on som
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then you mentioned that ROR is not the only factor in determining activity for this year, but can you give us a little sense of whether you have an after-tax IRR hurdle in this environment? Or kind of what the after-tax returns are on some of the plays that you mentioned that are performing very well in the current environment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're a little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I find myself doing is spend a lot of time looking at just flat price returns. I just don't spend much
componenttext: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're a little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I find myself doing is spend a lot of time looking at just flat price returns. I just don't spend much time looking at the strip right now. And then we look at those flat prices and we ask ourselves, "Is this a good investment?" Especially these wells we're drilling to hold acreage. And in this environment, it's tough, I will admit. But when we look at that and look at the future potential of that section we're holding, we still feel like we're making very good investment and drilling those wells. So right now, again, we do definitely look at the ROR. And quite frankly, that means some of the acreage that we have will not be held because no matter what scenario, whatever flat price I look at, it's hard to envision how holding a certain set of acreage is in the best interest of Cimarex. That said, we have a lot of good acreage to hold to, and I'm very pleased that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeanine, this is Tom. We run everything currently down to $30 NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices and then we will deduct whatever market deduct to get back to the wellhead. And we'd like to see our cost to capital are
componenttext: Jeanine, this is Tom. We run everything currently down to $30 NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices and then we will deduct whatever market deduct to get back to the wellhead. And we'd like to see our cost to capital are better at that flat price. And then we'll also look at the strip. And let me just answer your question this way. If we were forced to increase activity and we had an A-tax 25 hurdle rate, we have lots to do in our portfolio. If we weren't tasked with holding acreage and we can just go drill at will and there were no other considerations, when we look at these long laterals in the Wolfcamp, the long laterals in the Cana, Meramec play, we have lots of them that generate, what I would say, are acceptable returns at current strip. But as John said, we have a lot of considerations currently. We don't think prices will stay here forever and we have some outstanding acreage that we'd like to hold, not all of which can be developed with long laterals. We have partner considerations. And then we also have some science that we want to get done that will really set up the future. So it's a balancing act. One thing that we will not do, one thing we will absolutely not do is liquidate this company because we're in a $30 oil environment. So we're going to make judgment calls as we see fit.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you could provide some clarity just on whether you're targeting on leverage ratio or if you're still thinking about spending the remainder of the secondary offering proceeds? Or how you're setting the budget really?
componenttext: If you could provide some clarity just on whether you're targeting on leverage ratio or if you're still thinking about spending the remainder of the secondary offering proceeds? Or how you're setting the budget really?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Mark. Yes. As I mentioned and what we're looking at planning for '16 right now, with our current $600 million, $650 million of cash capital plan for '16 and a recent strip price forecast for cash flow, we think we'd use up from the $739 mill
componenttext: Drew, this is Mark. Yes. As I mentioned and what we're looking at planning for '16 right now, with our current $600 million, $650 million of cash capital plan for '16 and a recent strip price forecast for cash flow, we think we'd use up from the $739 million we exited '15 with, we expect that in '16 around $400 million of cash in the balance sheet. So no, we didn't expect to use the remainder of the proceeds in '16 and we're going to see how the environment flattens out before we strip activity further. But no, we do not plan to use in '16 and even in '17 we're still looking at difference scenarios and how outlook will be in '17.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, is there a target leverage ratio? Or is that not really a primary consideration?
componenttext: Mark, is there a target leverage ratio? Or is that not really a primary consideration?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, we really have one financial covenant which we really -- in our credit facility which the debt to cap covenant, which is limited to a debt cap of 65%. And we exited the fourth quarter at 35%. And going into '16, we don't see us having any issue with
componenttext: Drew, we really have one financial covenant which we really -- in our credit facility which the debt to cap covenant, which is limited to a debt cap of 65%. And we exited the fourth quarter at 35%. And going into '16, we don't see us having any issue with that covenant, even with potential future impairments, which are likely with the fact that prices are continuing to still -- drilling 12 months average is still declining through '16, but we'll have to watch that metric. Our debt-to-EBITDA metric be typically within 1.5x or less, but with the dropping commodity prices that metrics, obviously, more challenged. We exit the year, [indiscernible] price debt-to-EBITDA of 1.9x. Going into '16, we expect that probably likely will go into a low-3s or so into '16, but EBITDA still fall in lower prices. These are hard and fast rules. We have a covenant we watch carefully, Drew. But the rest of the covenants we just -- we are objected [indiscernible] expected incurring incremental debt in this [indiscernible] and leading in he futures for sometime. It looks that we just have the $1.5 billion of senior unsecured notes outstanding. We don't expect anything borrowing into the near future.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, this is Tom. I want to be clear, and I think have been, but we've actually made this tactical decision to try to keep as much cash on our balance sheet so that we we're well positioned when the situation turns around. We think that the best act
componenttext: Yes. Drew, this is Tom. I want to be clear, and I think have been, but we've actually made this tactical decision to try to keep as much cash on our balance sheet so that we we're well positioned when the situation turns around. We think that the best activity level for Cimarex in 2016 is preservation mode. We want to make sure we preserve our assets, we preserve our obligations and we preserve our flexibility. But our goal is to keep as much cash as we can on the balance sheet as we look ahead so that we are well positioned to strike when we see some daylight.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, all that makes sense, I think [indiscernible]. I guess, along that vein, does it make sense to layer on hedges albeit I realized the forward curve is not really where you'd like it to be, but maybe for -- even for 2017? Is that -- does that ma
componenttext: Right. Yes, all that makes sense, I think [indiscernible]. I guess, along that vein, does it make sense to layer on hedges albeit I realized the forward curve is not really where you'd like it to be, but maybe for -- even for 2017? Is that -- does that make sense strategically?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, we have, for some time now, we're working towards having a quarterly progression in our hedging program. And we did take steps in the first quarter, hedged 40 million a day for 15 months for second quarter '16 to second quarter of '17. And now
componenttext: Yes. Drew, we have, for some time now, we're working towards having a quarterly progression in our hedging program. And we did take steps in the first quarter, hedged 40 million a day for 15 months for second quarter '16 to second quarter of '17. And now a layer that will put in, targeting about 10% of our 4 production roughly in that neighborhood. And we look at it again. And we're targeting 4,000, 5,000 barrels a day would be our target for the first quarter. As you mentioned, the 4 strip in oil prevented us from taking that step on oil. But each quarter, we're going to look at that 4 projection of our volumes and look at layering in maybe 10% of our volumes each quarter. And over a period of time, we hope to get to about 50% of our volume recovered. But we have been inhibited by the low oil price through taking that step on oil.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could circle back on the new Wolfcamp A completions. Is the plan to implement that new style on the rest of your program, I know you said you would use it on the density pilot. But all of you're drilling in 2016, is that applicable to the Wolfc
componenttext: Okay. If I could circle back on the new Wolfcamp A completions. Is the plan to implement that new style on the rest of your program, I know you said you would use it on the density pilot. But all of you're drilling in 2016, is that applicable to the Wolfcamp C and D as well?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Well, it's certainly applicable to come up with the next new innovation of it, yes. I mean, we plan to use that current design on that spacing pilot. We have a little bit different design for the lowered. Suffice it to say that, even with th
componenttext: This is John. Well, it's certainly applicable to come up with the next new innovation of it, yes. I mean, we plan to use that current design on that spacing pilot. We have a little bit different design for the lowered. Suffice it to say that, even with that design, as we talked earlier with one of the early questions, we're still looking to see how we can even improve upon that, to be honest. Very pleased with the results from that frac design. What I really like about those wells, and we are looking at the other day, is just how well they're holding in over time from a decline perspective. I mean, they're very attractive wells for us. But again, it doesn't mean that that's where we're going to stay -- standstill with that design. We're going to keep asking ourselves, "How can we make it even better as we go forward?"

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, how do the returns compete with the rest of the portfolio assuming that this uplift is repeatable?
componenttext: John, how do the returns compete with the rest of the portfolio assuming that this uplift is repeatable?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can simply tell you, we look at our programs, we look at a different flat prices like the one Tom mentioned. And certainly, right now, the 2-mile Upper Wolfcamp in Culberson that area, is one of our top-tier programs right now, especially with the
componenttext: Well, I can simply tell you, we look at our programs, we look at a different flat prices like the one Tom mentioned. And certainly, right now, the 2-mile Upper Wolfcamp in Culberson that area, is one of our top-tier programs right now, especially with the most recent well results. So it looks very, very good to us. And we're very anxious to get that spacing pilot in so we can start to hone-in on exactly what the full potential is for that zone for us from a development standpoint.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Matt Portillo of TPH.
componenttext: The next question will come from Matt Portillo of TPH.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick clarification questions. On the theoretical 2017 production with the timing of the Cana completion. I just wanted to clarify when thinking about the exit rate Q4 '15 of about 985 million a day, would the thought be that with the Can
componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarification questions. On the theoretical 2017 production with the timing of the Cana completion. I just wanted to clarify when thinking about the exit rate Q4 '15 of about 985 million a day, would the thought be that with the Cana completions, the total corporate production could reach that level again by kind of Q2 2017, if everything kind of stays on plan as you guys envision it at the moment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of a worse case, where that production doesn't start until the first half of -- or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17
componenttext: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of a worse case, where that production doesn't start until the first half of -- or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17. And if we speed up things, we might find ourselves in maybe the Q1 time period. So again, it's all timing. And somebody with their questions alluded to the fact that these are big projects, you've got multiple wells all coming on at once. And you saw what rolled forward it for us from Q3 to Q4, significant increase in our Cana production from 405 million -- in Mid-Continent, from 405 million to 461 million a day. So those are big swings. You could see the difference between our Q4. If you apply our Q4 exit rate with a typical decline or whatever, you might think we're going to be in the high-800s. And all of a sudden, 2 quarters later, we're 100 million a day higher than that. So it's just the nature of the beast and it's all about timing.

componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. I'll answer that one as well. The gist of it is we're modeling and this is going to transpire here in Q1. We've been able to work some other marketing arrangements in and around the downstream curtailment that we have right now and hope to have those plus the remedy itself of the facility that was impacted with the fire that you are aware of. Finalized by March, late March and then of course we have our Hidalgo plant coming on not too far after that and then there's a number of other process and alternatives that are on the map and pretty close to completion that we feel like mid- to late this year, we're going to be very good shape.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be to essentially hold our acreage. A part of that will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised not just by our results, bu
componenttext: Yes. This is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be to essentially hold our acreage. A part of that will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised not just by our results, but as Tom alluded to, a lot of competitor results that are kind of changing the landscape of the map in the Meramec. And it's given us some encouragement, especially as we look more to the Western side, it's looking much more attractive to us. And fortunately for us, we have a pretty nice position there. In fact, that's where a lot of the new leasing that we have picked up is in more of that area. So yes, throughout the rest of this year we'll be geographically spreading across that map quite a bit with the wells that we'd be drilling and that will just help us further delineate the full potential for this interval.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's Tom. Just really a follow-up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair availability of results with landing zone. A landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that it ha
componenttext: Jason, it's Tom. Just really a follow-up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair availability of results with landing zone. A landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that it has surprised us compared to the Woodford below it. And so I think as we go forward, you're probably going to hear us talking more and more about the Mississippian as opposed to the Meramec. Yet some of the lower section, you hear the Osage being talked about as a target. And that's looking more and more interesting to us. There are some really good wells out there that are hard to explain if you only have the Meramec to explain it with. And so as John said, there's a tremendous amount of upside for us not only in our acreage but also operational improvements since we've test landing zones and then also completions. We're pretty bullish on that play right now and our position. And although we generally rule competition everywhere, there's some competition out there that's giving us a lot of good information and it's just shining a very good positive light on our competition.

componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And I'll just say as I alluded to in my comments, we have a partner and we develop these rows. We coordinate with our partner from a standpoint of the frac calendar. We recognized that to achieve the optimal result, we have to work tog
componenttext: Well, this is John. And I'll just say as I alluded to in my comments, we have a partner and we develop these rows. We coordinate with our partner from a standpoint of the frac calendar. We recognized that to achieve the optimal result, we have to work together, we have to time our frac schedule appropriately as we bring these wells on. Our partner has indicated to us that, at this time, they would like to delay their frac schedule. And so we are working with them and coordinating with them to the best of our ability. We have emphasized we'd like to move it up some, if we could. We understand the position they're taking, but we would like to move it up in the year if we could. And we're having those ongoing discussions right now. And we'll see where it ends. I think what we've done is we presented you -- maybe you could call the worse case scenario where they get pushed all the way to early '17. But there's a chance perhaps we can push them up earlier into '16. I think that would be our preference.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter and full year conference call. In addition to last year's results, today we will be discussing our 2016 capital plans, which were released separately yesterday afternoon. An updated presentation has been posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during the call today. 
As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. 
So today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, Senior VP of Exploration; and then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on our operations, including production and well cost. Cimarex CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will give a rundown of our recent results and update you on some of the delineation that we have underway in 2016. Joe will provide an operational overview. 
I would like to kick off the call with some overview remarks and our direction in 2016 and beyond. During 2015, we put a lot of energy into long-range planning and we developed capabilities for running detailed iterations on current and future years' CapEx, cash flow and balance sheet configuration. We scrubbed our assets and developed net asset value models that help us to fully understand our upside and plan accordingly. 
Today, we are making decisions for 2016 with a close eye on 2017, 2018 and beyond. Cimarex is better positioned for the future by slowing down a bit, preserving our cash and assets and living within our means. Our focus is on preservation of our assets and balance sheet. We don't have any special insight on when or how commodity prices will recover. We do know that we will probably be as surprised by the recovery as we were by the collapse. When prices recover, Cimarex will be ready and will be stronger and healthier as ever. 
We have never been more bullish on our assets, our inventory and our organizational capability. Our Delaware Basin and Meramec/Woodford assets are top tier. We continue to be pleased with our well results and associated returns on investment. On the call today, you'll hear updates on our Wolfcamp spacing pilots and the implications for future development. 
We continue to be extremely pleased with our Wolfcamp well performance and have room to run in achieving further performance improvements. You will hear an update on the Meramec/Woodford spacing pilot that is underway in Cana. We're testing a combined 19 wells per section in the Meramec and Woodford. The Meramec continues to surprise to the upside. We are currently flowing back Woodford spacing pilots that are testing 10 and 12 Woodford wells per section. Results are very encouraging. 
Furthermore, our improved Woodford results are showing remarkable consistency across the Cana core. In both the Delaware and Woodford/Meramec, long horizontal wells are an increasingly important part of our story and our assets are well configured to allow for them. We have a manageable lease exploration issue and we will preserve all of our prime acreage. 
In spite of the downturn of activity, we're emphasizing our core strengths and idea generation and innovation. Our teams are hard at work developing new plays and new concepts. During the downturn of 2009, our activity level dropped from 43 operated rigs to 3. At that time, we challenged the organization to be innovative, creative and to find ways to make a living in spite of the downturn. We were not victims. 
During 2009, we developed plays that were going to carry us on the ensuing years and are still among our core programs today. In 2016, our challenge to the organization is to do it again. We are built for these times, however difficult they may be. We will make the tough decisions around capital investments and activity level. We will remain disciplined and preserve our assets and the deep inventory that is our future. We will also seek to build new things and to take advantage of this downturn. No one is hanging their head at Cimarex. We are hard at work to control our own destiny. 
I recently heard a CEO describe some advice that one of his board members have given him. The board member was a retired military officer who told the CEO that he had always told his troops that, "When the map doesn't match the terrain, go with the terrain." Here at Cimarex, we're going with the terrain. During 2015, we increased our rig count to a high of 12 rigs, with an original plan to keep 12 operated rigs throughout 2016. As the year wore on and the commodity outlook continued to worsen, we determined that a 12-rig program was no longer prudent. 
Although we have the inventory to justify the higher activity level even at current prices, we have decided to slow down and preserve our cash on hand. Production growth will have to take a backseat to flexibility and balance sheet preservation. Our focus is on a multiyear outlook. We currently have 11 operated rigs running and we'll be decreasing our rig count to 4 rigs in the coming months. Our 2016 program is designed to preserve our assets on leasehold and finish up some delineation and spacing pilots that are underway. 
We plan to invest between $600 million and $650 million in exploration and development. The range of investment is driven by timing of completions in one of the projects currently underway, the Woodford infill well in the Eastern core of Cana. Whatever we do not spend in 2016 will be pushed into early 2017. We will also continue to delineate the Meramec drill spacing test in the Wolfcamp in the Delaware Basin and hold leasehold. 
In the fourth quarter of 2015, we were impacted by severe weather events and took direct hits at both the Western Delaware Basin and in our core Cana field. Furthermore, a plant outage in Delaware Basin added to our problems. I cannot overstate how pleased we were with the response to these events by our organization. Although they had a significant impact on our production volumes, our teams worked valiantly and safely in extremely hostile conditions in order to restore our production and find creative workarounds to market interruptions. These extraordinary actions don't always evidence themselves in top line reported production numbers, but they humble us and make us deeply proud to be part of an organization that is so dedicated and focused. 
With that, I will turn the call over to John to provide further details on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $191 million during the fourth quarter on exploration and development. This brought the total to $877 million for the full year. About 55% was invested in the Permian region with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region. Company-wide, we brought 65 gross, 28 net wells on production during the quarter, which brought the total for 2015 to 219 gross, 99 net wells. 
Cimarex continues to push the envelope on well completions. In the Permian, we completed 2 Upper Wolfcamp wells in the fourth quarter using a larger stimulation. As you can see on Slide 14 of our presentation, these wells have seen a 34% higher cumulative production in the first 120 days versus the previous Upper Wolfcamp wells. In fact, one of the wells, Mine That Bird 38 Unit #1-H had an average 30-day peak production rate of 2,020 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 51% was gas, 30% -- excuse me, 51% oil, 30% gas and 19% NGL, a record IP from a 7,500-foot Upper Wolfcamp lateral in Culberson County. 
As discussed previously, we spud a downspacing pilot in the Upper Wolfcamp and Culberson County in the fourth quarter. Drilling on these wells will be finished this month with completion scheduled to begin in April. First production is expected by the end of May. This fixed well, 7,500-foot lateral pilot will test 2 different spacing designs, one testing 8 wells per section, while the other will test 6 wells per section. Both will be drilled in a staggered pattern. The larger completion I just discussed will be used on this pilot. 
For the rest of 2016, the vast majority of the capital that we will spend in the Permian will be earmarked for acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. Part of this obligation drilling will include 6, 2-mile-long infill wells in Reeves County. These infill wells are located next to our Big Timber well, the best Wolfcamp well we've drilled in Reeves County. 
Similar to our Anaconda pilot, these wells will be drilled using a stacked/staggered pattern, resulting in equivalent of 12 wells per section. We currently have 6 rigs running in the Permian, with one of them drilling a saltwater disposal well in Culberson County. By June, we will be down to 2 rigs for the remainder of the year. 
Now on to the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling on the Cana-Woodford Row 4 infill development program in the fourth quarter of 2014. Completion from the 7 sections are now finished and all 57 gross wells are producing. Cimarex operated 2 of these sections. Typical development in the Woodford calls for 8 new wells in addition to the parent well on a section. The Armacost section was infilled with 9 additional wells, while the Phillips section was infilled with 11 new wells. 
For the Armacost section, the average 30-day peak production from was 9.1 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 61% gas, 8% oil, 31% NGL. And the Phillips wells produced an average 30-day peak rate of 9.3 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 54% gas, 13% oil, 33% NGL. As you can see on Slide 20 of our presentation, these increased density infill sections are performing very similar to previously infilled Woodford sections with only 8 new wells. A very encouraging results for us. 
In the fourth quarter 2015, we commenced drilling another Woodford infill well in the east side of the core. This development covers 6 sections, of which Cimarex again operates 2 sections. The entire infill project consists of 50 gross, 23 net wells. Depending on the timing of completions, something that will be worked out with our partner, production from this East Cana development row is expected to come on line beginning as early as October or perhaps as late as the first quarter of 2017. 
In our emerging Meramec play, we now have production data on 17 operated 5,000-foot laterals. In addition, our second 10,000-foot lateral in the Meramec has been on production since early October. This well, called the Vessels 1H-3526X, has a 30-day peak IP rate of 14 million cubic feet equivalent per day, including 791 barrels of oil per day. 
Page 22 of the presentation illustrates the average uplift we've seen from the 2 long laterals versus the 5,000-foot laterals drilled to date. They have outperformed the shorter laterals by 69% within 120 days. While we are very encouraged by the initial uplift in IP that we're seeing in these 10,000-foot laterals, we will be carefully monitoring their decline profile in order to determine the ultimate EURs for these long lateral wells. 
To better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have designed a downspacing pilot with commenced drilling in the fourth quarter 2015. See Slide 23 for an illustration of this design. Due to the commodity price environment, this pilot has been downsized. It will now consist of 8 new wells to be stacked and staggered in both the Meramec and Woodford formations. The spacing of the Meramec would be the equivalent of 10 wells per section made up of 5 upper and 5 lower staggered Meramec wells. The Woodford will be drilled with our standard 9 wells per section development plan. Drilling should be finished by mid-April with first production expected late in the second quarter. 
Once drilling is finished on the pilot and infill sections, we will be focused on holding our Meramec acreage. Since late 2014, we've added 12,250 net acres in the Meramec at an average cost of $1,650 per acre. We'll need to drill approximately 40 to 45 wells over the next 3 years in order to HBP our position. In 2016, we will drill 12 operated wells to hold this acreage position, with 10 of the 12 wells being 10,000-foot laterals. We currently have 5 rigs operating in the Mid-Continent region, with plans to go down to 1 rig by July of this year. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. Our f
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our fourth quarter production, our Q1 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll finish with a few comments on LOE and service cost. 
Our fourth quarter total company net equivalent production came in at 985.7 million a day, up 4% from the 949.5 million a day that we posted in Q4 '14 and within our guidance of 0.98 to 1.01 Bcfe per day. Late in the quarter, as Tom mentioned, winter weather and facility disruptions negatively impacted our production by approximately 30 million cubic feet a day equivalent, with the majority of that occurring in the Permian. 
Late December winter storms caused significant downtime in not only the Delaware Basin, but also impacted our Cana production as well, albeit to a lesser degree. When we adjust for the estimated impact of the weather and the facility downtime, we would have exceeded the upper end of our guidance by more than 5 million a day. With Q4 now on the books, our full year 2015 equivalent production came in at 985 million a day, that's up 13% over our 2014 average of 869 million a day. 
During Q4, our Permian equivalent production averaged 520 million a day, that's down 42 million a day from Q3 '15. But as I mentioned, a significant portion of the decrease was a result of not only the -- was a result of the weather and facility downtime, but we also completed fewer Permian wells during the latter half of the year than we did in the first half as we've talked about in our previous calls. As expected, with our Cana Row 4 wells coming online, we saw a very nice bump in our Q4 Mid-Continent production, with our Mid-Continent volumes coming in at 461 million a day. That's up 14% or 56 million a day from the 405 million a day that we reported just prior in Q3. 
For 2016, with a number of moving parts, the most sensitive of which is the timing of our 2016 completions, we've issued full year total company equivalent production guidance of 890 million to 930 million equivalents per day. With our focus on preserving our assets and protecting our balance sheet in the low price environment we're in, we've opted to slow down and more consistently spread out our completion activity throughout the year. As John mentioned, we also find ourselves needing to coordinate the timing of our Cana-Woodford completion activity with the completion timing of our offset operator. 
As a result, there is considerable variability in the inventory of uncompleted wells that we will have on the books at the end of the year. As we best can project at this time, we anticipate and we've modeled that our Cana infill fracking operations will begin in late to third -- late third to fourth quarter and continue into 2017, with first production from the project not hitting our books until early 2017. This program represents the lion's share of our 2016 Mid-Continent activity consisting of 50 gross and 23 net wells. 
With our current modeling, we expect to see first production from approximately 50 gross or 16 net Mid-Continent wells during '16, and that's down from 134 gross or 39 net wells that we completed in 2015. With the anticipated Cana infill completion delay, we expect to exit the year with 57 gross or 24 net wells awaiting completion, hence moving associated production for those wells into early 2017. 
In the Permian, we also planned for a slower pace of completion activity, which will likely only require us to utilize just one completion crew for the majority of the year. We're forecasting approximately 31 net Permian wells to come online in 2016; that's down about half of the 60 net wells that we completed in 2015. As we progress through the year, we project the number of Permian drilled and uncompleted wells to increase to approximately 18 net wells by midyear and then drop off to just 6 net wells by the end of the year, primarily a result of us dropping to the 2 rigs that John mentioned in the Permian in the middle of the year. 
I want to take a moment to make a special point that a quick glance at our 2016 full year guidance could very easily imply a decline in our 2016 exit rate. What's not so easy to see is the forecast of production increase associated with the delayed Cana infill programs back-to-back completion activity in early 2017 which, along with a handful of Permian carryover completions, is forecasted to bring our total company production back up to Q4 '15 levels by as early as Q2 '17. It's all about the timing of our completions. 
As far as our Q1 total company production is concerned, incorporating anticipated Permian pipeline and facility curtailments of about 30 million a day for the first quarter, our projected guidance for Q1 comes in at 925 million to 955 million a day. 
Jumping over to CapEx. With our production groups' continued focus on trimming operating costs, our Q4 lifting cost came in at $0.85 per Mcfe. That's in line with our guidance of $0.77 to $0.87 and was down 19% from the $1.05 that we posted in Q4 '14. For the year, our 2015 lifting cost came in at $0.83 per Mcfe. That's down a respectable 23% from our 2014 average of $1.08. As we look forward into 2016, our full year lifting cost guidance range of $0.80 to $0.90 per Mcfe takes into account our regional forecasted production mix as well as the variable nature of workover expenses. 
You may have also noted that our Q4 '15 transportation and processing expense came in at $0.58. So it's slightly above our guidance range of $0.45 to $0.55. As I mentioned, our current production modeling forecasts a slowdown in our completion activity during the year, which resulted in a onetime accrual of approximately $8 million for anticipated minimum volume agreement shortfalls, which increased our reported cost on a nonrecurring basis by approximately $0.09 per Mcfe. 
We've made great strides cutting our LOE and we'll continue our efforts to reduce them further. As we mentioned last call, the important by-product of our LOE reductions is the additional funding we're providing our drilling program. Our Q4 '15 average monthly LOE came in at $25.7 million a month and that's $5 million below our Q4 '14 average of $30.7 million a month, which if we average that over a 12-month time period has freed up nearly $60 million that we can direct to our drilling program. 
A few comments on our drilling and completion cost. Although we continue to push hard for further cost relief, any cost reductions we've seen have been small, single-digit reductions and modest in nature. That said, we continue our focus on operating efficiencies. On the drilling side, we've high-graded our rigs, we're bidding out each and every service, we're consolidating our equipment and resources everywhere we can, all the while we're staying focused on reducing drilling days. 
On the completion side, we're focused on optimizing the cost of water sourcing by more efficiently fracking our wells, in particular, when we're completing multi-well pads. The bottom line is that while we continue to experience -- experiment with various frac designs, our generic well AFEs have remained relatively flat. Our current Cana core 1-mile lateral Woodford AFE continues to run in the range of $6.6 million to $7 million. That's unchanged from the last call. While in the Meramec, our current 1-mile lateral AFE is also -- is in the range of $7 million to $7.4 million; that's also unchanged from last quarter. 
In the Permian, as we've mentioned last call, we've made great progress with our drilling efficiencies, cutting our Wolfcamp 2-mile lateral spud-to-rig release times down 20%, from 35 days in 2014 to 28 days in 2015, with a record of 20.5 days. We're accomplishing similar drill time reductions in a 1-mile lateral Bone Spring and Avalon program as well, cutting average days from spud-to-rig release 35%, from 23 days in '14 to just 15 in Q4 '15. We continue to get more done with fewer rigs. And with all that, our current 2-mile lateral Wolfcamp AFE is running $10.8 million to $11.6 million; that's flat again to the figures we quoted last call. 
So in closing, we had another great quarter. We fought off significant Q4 downstream weather -- downtime to stay within guidance and provide us with a strong springboard for production in 2016. We posted solid year-over-year production gains over 2014. We've made significant strides cutting our LOE. Our drilling group stays focused on cost reductions and efficiencies. And as an organization, we remain vigilant to keep our costs in check, protect our assets and optimize our investment program results. 
So with that, I'll turn the call over to question-and-answer.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Dan Guffey of Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Dan Guffey of Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, you guys have conveyed budgets are a snapshot of the current environment, and the company does remain flexible. I guess key question here is, at what price would you want to bring rigs back? Obviously, with the extreme volatility in crude, it
componenttext: In the past, you guys have conveyed budgets are a snapshot of the current environment, and the company does remain flexible. I guess key question here is, at what price would you want to bring rigs back? Obviously, with the extreme volatility in crude, it may make that decision a little more cumbersome. But just curious when you think you would add rigs back since you do have some the lowest cost production throughout the U.S.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. That's a great question. Mark, I'm going to bounce pass that to you. We run tons of models and it's hard to make a definitive statement. I will say this though, before Mark comments, we remain highly flexible. And if we see daylight, we're go
componenttext: This is Tom. That's a great question. Mark, I'm going to bounce pass that to you. We run tons of models and it's hard to make a definitive statement. I will say this though, before Mark comments, we remain highly flexible. And if we see daylight, we're going to run for it. Obviously, in building a company and preserving a balance sheet, you can have all kinds of optimism, but you can't run a company on that optimism to the extent that you're not preserving your balance sheet. But Mark, you know how to answer that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Dan, certainly, what Tom is referring to -- there's 2 primary concerns we have right now, watching our return on our investments, making sure we get adequate return, which isn't the highest, isn't the biggest concern, it's more -- was not preserving
componenttext: Sure. Dan, certainly, what Tom is referring to -- there's 2 primary concerns we have right now, watching our return on our investments, making sure we get adequate return, which isn't the highest, isn't the biggest concern, it's more -- was not preserving our balance sheet. So we have cash flow sufficient to really support a larger program, which we're really trying to constrain our investment to make sure we preserve a very strong balance sheet, preserve our cash position and better weather [ph] through this. But I think if you saw our price environment stabilize, settling in around $45 to $50, you would probably see us having cash flow supporting a larger program. But in this below $30 environment we find ourselves in, that's where we're constraining our investment to the extent that we are, which is -- it'd probably have to be some clarity and certainty around that $45 to $50 price for us to see that to make some upward adjustments in our investment pace.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess are there any limiting factors in terms of how quickly you could add, whether that be personnel or infrastructure? And then I guess, what area would your first incremental rigs target should we get to that $40 to $50 environment?
componenttext: Okay. I guess are there any limiting factors in terms of how quickly you could add, whether that be personnel or infrastructure? And then I guess, what area would your first incremental rigs target should we get to that $40 to $50 environment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Joe. As far as our organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in and along our existing infrastructure, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled a
componenttext: Well, this is Joe. As far as our organization is concerned, we can act quickly. And depending on where we're drilling, if it's in and along our existing infrastructure, that shouldn't be a problem. You got to remember that we had a bigger plan scheduled and modeled as far as our organizational activity, and we just pared back from it. So getting back on the track should not be that difficult for us.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We took a rig out of the yard. We got asked that question last year and we took a rig out of the yard that, on its first well, it started setting records for us. So we're not terribly concerned about our ability to ramp up. And I would anticipate that our
componenttext: We took a rig out of the yard. We got asked that question last year and we took a rig out of the yard that, on its first well, it started setting records for us. So we're not terribly concerned about our ability to ramp up. And I would anticipate that our first place to ramp up would be the Permian.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we'd love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot I t
componenttext: Yes. This is John. Without a doubt, we are ready to go. Our Upper Wolfcamp wells in Culberson, as I talked about earlier, are really coming and performing very well. And we'd love to get back to drilling into that program beyond just the spacing pilot I talked about. Our long lateral Bone Spring play up in White City is very, very strong economics. And even part of our Woodford development in the Eastern core, which is more liquid-rich, especially if we look at it from a long lateral perspective, which our acreage allows us to do, looks pretty attractive to us. But we would like to see a little bit more encouragement from the commodity price before we want to go and deploy capital in those programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I just want to finish your question by -- I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, w
componenttext: Yes. And I just want to finish your question by -- I don't want to throw a marker down that's $45 oil price. If we see a recovery in oil price, it looks better and better to us. So I would even say if prices get north of $35 and our outlook is stronger, we're going to look at it. I don't want to throw any particular number down and say that's the number. We have the flexibility. We have the balance sheet to do it. I mean it's going to be what our vision is. I mean if there were some structural changes in the oil markets and there were reasons for long-term optimism, we would be prepared to act to that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Last one for me. Can you guys discuss if you feel you've reached or surpassed the productive and economic limits of enhanced completions across your various areas throughout the Permian and the Mid-Con?
componenttext: Okay. Great. Last one for me. Can you guys discuss if you feel you've reached or surpassed the productive and economic limits of enhanced completions across your various areas throughout the Permian and the Mid-Con?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And a very simple answer, no. No way do we feel like we've reached the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that go into that frac design. And quite frankly, I'm constantly amazed how certain t
componenttext: Well, this is John. And a very simple answer, no. No way do we feel like we've reached the limits. We constantly are debating entirely about all the different components that go into that frac design. And quite frankly, I'm constantly amazed how certain tweaks lead to even better and better wells. So no, we are not at all feel like we've reached the point where we can't get even more reserves out of these laterals. And quite honestly, that's some -- that's our charge right now. Given the environment we find, for every  dollar we invest in those wells, we need to get more out of those wells. And so far, I'm been very pleased in that we've been able to achieve that with a number of our programs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I want to -- this is Tom. I want to follow up to that. John and I started off first thing this morning at 7:00 in my office arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point that one of the nice things about having as
componenttext: Yes. And I want to -- this is Tom. I want to follow up to that. John and I started off first thing this morning at 7:00 in my office arguing about just this thing. Not arguing with one another, arguing the point that one of the nice things about having assets in 2 of the most active, prolific areas of the country, is there's a lot of activity. And we study our competition really hard. It's pretty important if you're going to have an innovative culture, you can't have a needs-to-be-invented-here mentality. And so we're always looking to see what others are doing. And I think we have a lot of room for improvement, I would say, in both our core areas, the Delaware Basin and Meramec. There's lots of things others are doing that we have opinions on. But at the end of the day, some of this is just trial and error and we need to try some things.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question will come from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on all the commentary. Tom, in your opening remarks, you said you're looking very closely at '16, '17 and '18 as a -- I guess, putting some color around that, is it looking closely at what -- what sort of goals would you like to achieve
componenttext: Just to follow-up on all the commentary. Tom, in your opening remarks, you said you're looking very closely at '16, '17 and '18 as a -- I guess, putting some color around that, is it looking closely at what -- what sort of goals would you like to achieve at the field level, looking closely at what your debt metrics are, looking closely at how much cash you have or a production growth scenario?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you've kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So all that, we can take that one off the table. As we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset. And I'd love to sit here on the call, put lipstick on it and
componenttext: Well, you've kind of run through the gamut there. We're not changing our logo. So all that, we can take that one off the table. As we look ahead, I think the industry is having a sobering reset. And I'd love to sit here on the call, put lipstick on it and say, "You know what, it's one thing." But as you look ahead in running a company, we have to look at the ins and outs of cash flow balance. And so we look into, what I said in my opening remarks, we spent a lot of time last year looking at our assets and looking at the future drilling inventory and the value that adds. And we've made a tremendous amount of progress in our flexibility and our ability to do real-time modeling of future increases in price, future increases in activity and actually modeling the impact that has fully looking at our cash flow and our balance sheet. But when you do that, one of the reasons that we're doing that is because if prices don't pick up at any point, we want to make sure that Cimarex stays healthy and stays competitive. And we don't want to put ourselves in a situation where we've lost our flexibility. So inherently, that model is kind of a downside model. It's really easy to run an upside model, but you have to kind of plan on the downside. And so we're -- as we look ahead to the next few years, I will say that if things don't materially improve over the current strip, Cimarex will be just fine. We'll be healthy financially and we'll be in a position where we attempt to model into that future without increasing debt. But if things increase, if commodity prices pick up, we are ready to roll. I know I'm not giving you -- I'm not giving you a detailed answer on what our 2017 and beyond model looks like, but we're making decisions to keep Cimarex competitive and to preserve our assets. Mark, do you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, that's right, Tom. When we look at these different scenarios today we -- it's obviously, some book entries and strip influences a lot of our thinking right now in the 4 strips in the low-40s to '17 and only 45 by '18 in a recent strip being pulle
componenttext: Yes. No, that's right, Tom. When we look at these different scenarios today we -- it's obviously, some book entries and strip influences a lot of our thinking right now in the 4 strips in the low-40s to '17 and only 45 by '18 in a recent strip being pulled. And looking at what our activity levels could be at those different price picks, conserving our balance sheet strength and seeing what fits within that cash flow without really having to incur -- in preserving some portion of our cash balance and not incurring incremental debt looking -- look like into the future years. And it is -- in this current strip environment, low-40s and 30s are very challenging for us to find the pace of best -- what our cash flow can support our pace development. So what iterations we're running all the time, looking at different sensitivities and different programs. And as Joe remarks in his comments, even for this year, there's an impact of the deferral of completions, can have very big impacts on our timing of our production. And so we're running a lot of iterations just looking at what the outlook could be for this year and for the years out.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the clarity around that. Just one more, if I might. John, you reminded all of us about kind of we might not be appreciating the amount of production that can come on from the 50 Cana wells and the infill towards the end of the year, begin
componenttext: I appreciate all the clarity around that. Just one more, if I might. John, you reminded all of us about kind of we might not be appreciating the amount of production that can come on from the 50 Cana wells and the infill towards the end of the year, beginning of next. And you said 2Q of '17 could be back up the levels of 4Q '15 conceptually. You're running 4 other -- or 4 rigs total; much of that is for HBP and acreage. So as you think about going into 2017 and 2018, is -- would future rig activity or incremental rig activity be devoted to doing a very large pad or multi-sectioned developments where we would have this sort of persistent lumpiness until things smooth out where you have a larger rig fleet that's caught up to everything?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point that we want to get back toward true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity of rigs and pads and so forth. But we just don't know at
componenttext: Well, this is John. I think it's safe to say that when we reach that point that we want to get back toward true development drilling, then certainly, that's going to lead toward that high intensity of rigs and pads and so forth. But we just don't know at what point we will be back there. Here's what I know, I know for this year and going forward, our main goal, as Tom alluded to, is both the balance sheet and, more importantly, protecting investments we made in the acreage that we picked up in both the Anadarko as well as the Permian Basin. We have wonderful acreage and we've gotten it at a very attractive price. And essentially for this year's program, as we go up to the end of the year, that's where our capital is going to be geared toward, is preserving that acreage position so that we are in a very good position whenever the time is right to then go back to that full scale development. When that will be, I can't tell you at this point.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Jeanine Wai of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Jeanine Wai of Citi.

componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about your forecasted outspend for 2016 on whenever price deck you're using, it sounds like the strip. There appears to be a fair amount of non-D&C spend that might be driving some of the outspend.
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about your forecasted outspend for 2016 on whenever price deck you're using, it sounds like the strip. There appears to be a fair amount of non-D&C spend that might be driving some of the outspend.
