componenttextpreview: Jeanine, this is Mark here. Yes, so in our 2016 outspend, about $600 million, $650 million of capital using a recent strip price around $34, $2.20 gas. We're looking at coming into your $779 million of cash. We're looking at exiting the year somewhere aro
componenttext: Jeanine, this is Mark here. Yes, so in our 2016 outspend, about $600 million, $650 million of capital using a recent strip price around $34, $2.20 gas. We're looking at coming into your $779 million of cash. We're looking at exiting the year somewhere around $400 million of cash in 2016.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you give a little bit of clarity on what that non-D&C is?
componenttext: And can you give a little bit of clarity on what that non-D&C is?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the non-D&C drilling is comprised of about $35 million we're targeting for a leasehold acquisition, another $120 million roughly for capitalized overhead, and there's about $40 million for production capital -- or production group capital for reco
componenttext: Yes. So the non-D&C drilling is comprised of about $35 million we're targeting for a leasehold acquisition, another $120 million roughly for capitalized overhead, and there's about $40 million for production capital -- or production group capital for recompletion and then well maintenance, deep wells.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then I know that you mentioned that ROR is not the only factor in determining activity for this year, but can you give us a little sense of whether you have an after-tax IRR hurdle in this environment? Or kind of what the after-tax return
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then I know that you mentioned that ROR is not the only factor in determining activity for this year, but can you give us a little sense of whether you have an after-tax IRR hurdle in this environment? Or kind of what the after-tax returns are on some of the plays that you mentioned that are performing very well in the current environment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're a little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I find myself doing is spend a lot of time looking at just flat price returns. I just don't spend much
componenttext: Well, this is John. And yes, we always have a way to return hurdles. They're a little bit challenging right now. What we find ourselves -- I guess what I find myself doing is spend a lot of time looking at just flat price returns. I just don't spend much time looking at the strip right now. And then we look at those flat prices and we ask ourselves, "Is this a good investment?" Especially these wells we're drilling to hold acreage. And in this environment, it's tough, I will admit. But when we look at that and look at the future potential of that section we're holding, we still feel like we're making a very good investment in drilling those wells. So right now, again, we do definitely look at the ROR. And quite frankly, that means some of the acreage that we have will not be held because no matter what scenario, whatever flat price I look at, it's hard to envision how holding a certain set of acreage is in the best interest of Cimarex. That said, we have a lot of good acreage to hold to, and I'm very pleased with that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeanine, this is Tom. We run everything currently down to $30 NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices and then we will deduct whatever market deduct to get back to the wellhead. And we'd like to see our cost to capital are
componenttext: Jeanine, this is Tom. We run everything currently down to $30 NYMEX oil and $2 NYMEX gas held flat forever. So those are index prices and then we will deduct whatever market deduct to get back to the wellhead. And we'd like to see our cost to capital are better at that flat price. And then we'll also look at the strip. And let me just answer your question this way. If we were forced to increase activity and we had an A-tax 25 hurdle rate, we have lots to do in our portfolio. If we weren't tasked with holding acreage and we can just go drill at will and there were no other considerations, when we look at these long laterals in the Wolfcamp, the long laterals in the Cana, Meramec play, we have lots of them that generate, what I would say, are acceptable returns at current strip. But as John said, we have a lot of considerations currently. We don't think prices will stay here forever and we have some outstanding acreage that we'd like to hold, not all of which can be developed with long laterals. We have partner considerations. And then we also have some science that we want to get done that will really set up the future. So it's a balancing act. One thing that we will not do, one thing we will absolutely not do is liquidate this company because we're in a $30 oil environment. So we're going to make judgment calls as we see fit.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: If you could provide some clarity just on whether you're targeting a leverage ratio or if you're still thinking about spending the remainder of the secondary offering proceeds? Or how you're setting the budget really?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Mark. Yes. As I mentioned and what we're looking at planning for '16 right now, with our current $600 million, $650 million to cash capital plan for '16 and a recent strip price forecast for cash flow, we think we'd use up from the $739 mill
componenttext: Drew, this is Mark. Yes. As I mentioned and what we're looking at planning for '16 right now, with our current $600 million, $650 million to cash capital plan for '16 and a recent strip price forecast for cash flow, we think we'd use up from the $739 million we exited '15 with, we expect that in '16 around $400 million of cash in the balance sheet. So no, we didn't expect to use the remainder of the proceeds in '16 and we're going to see how the environment flattens out before we strip activity further. But no, we do not plan to use it in '16, and even in '17 we're still looking at different scenarios and how outlook will be in '17.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, is there a target leverage ratio? Or is that not really a primary consideration?
componenttext: Mark, is there a target leverage ratio? Or is that not really a primary consideration?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, we only really have one financial covenant which we really -- in our credit facility which is the debt to cap covenant, which is limited to a debt cap of 65%. And we exited the fourth quarter at 35%. And going into '16, we don't see us having any is
componenttext: Drew, we only really have one financial covenant which we really -- in our credit facility which is the debt to cap covenant, which is limited to a debt cap of 65%. And we exited the fourth quarter at 35%. And going into '16, we don't see us having any issue with that covenant, even with potential future impairments, which are likely with the fact that prices are continuing to still -- drilling 12 months average is still declining through '16, but we'll have to watch that metric. Our debt-to-EBITDA metric be typically within 1.5x or less, but with the drop in commodity prices, that metric's obviously more challenged. As we exited the year, trailing 12-month price debt-to-EBITDA of 1.9x. Going into '16, we expect that probably likely will go into a low-3s or so into '16, but EBITDA still falls in lower prices. Those are hard and fast rules. We have a covenant we watch carefully, Drew. But the rest of the covenants we just -- we are subjected to [indiscernible]  expecting incurring incremental debt in this environment and even in the future for sometime. We would expect to just have the $1.5 billion of senior unsecured notes outstanding. We don't expect any bank borrowings in the near future.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, this is Tom. I want to be clear, and I think I have been, but we've actually made this tactical decision to try to keep as much cash on our balance sheet so that we we're well positioned when the situation turns around. We think that the best a
componenttext: Yes. Drew, this is Tom. I want to be clear, and I think I have been, but we've actually made this tactical decision to try to keep as much cash on our balance sheet so that we we're well positioned when the situation turns around. We think that the best activity level for Cimarex in 2016 is preservation mode. We want to make sure we preserve our assets, we preserve our obligations and we preserve our flexibility. But our goal is to keep as much cash as we can on the balance sheet as we look ahead so that we are well positioned to strike when we see some daylight.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, all that makes sense, I think it's a great move. I guess, along that vein, does it make sense to layer on hedges, albeit I realized the forward curve is not really where you'd like it to be, but maybe for -- even for 2017? Is that -- does that
componenttext: Right. Yes, all that makes sense, I think it's a great move. I guess, along that vein, does it make sense to layer on hedges, albeit I realized the forward curve is not really where you'd like it to be, but maybe for -- even for 2017? Is that -- does that make sense strategically?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Drew, we have, for some time now, we're working towards having a quarterly progression in our hedging program. And we did take steps in the first quarter, hedged 40 million a day for 15 months for second quarter '16 to second quarter of '17. And now
componenttext: Yes. Drew, we have, for some time now, we're working towards having a quarterly progression in our hedging program. And we did take steps in the first quarter, hedged 40 million a day for 15 months for second quarter '16 to second quarter of '17. And now with a layer that we'll put in, targeting about 10% of our forward production roughly in that neighborhood. And we'll look at it again. And we're targeting 4,000, 5,000 barrels a day, well, it would be our target for the first quarter. However, as you mentioned, the forward strip in oil has prevented us from taking that step on oil. But each quarter, we're going to look at that forward projection of our volumes and look at layering in maybe 10% of our volumes each quarter. And over a period of time, we hope to get to about 50% of our volume recovered. But we have been inhibited by the low oil price through taking that step on oil.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could circle back on the new Wolfcamp A completions. Is the plan to implement that new style on the rest of your program? I know you said you would use it on the density pilot. But all of you're drilling in 2016, is that applicable to the Wolfc
componenttext: Okay. If I could circle back on the new Wolfcamp A completions. Is the plan to implement that new style on the rest of your program? I know you said you would use it on the density pilot. But all of you're drilling in 2016, is that applicable to the Wolfcamp C and D as well?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Well, it's certainly applicable to come up with the next new innovation of it, yes. I mean, we plan to use that current design on that spacing pilot. We have a little bit different design for the lowerage [ph] . Suffice it to say that, even
componenttext: This is John. Well, it's certainly applicable to come up with the next new innovation of it, yes. I mean, we plan to use that current design on that spacing pilot. We have a little bit different design for the lowerage [ph] . Suffice it to say that, even with that design, as we talked earlier with one of the early questions, we're still looking to see how we can even improve upon that, to be honest. Very pleased with the results from that frac design. What I really like about those wells, and we are looking at the other day, is just how well they're holding in over time from a decline perspective. I mean, they're very attractive wells for us. But again, it doesn't mean that that's where we're going to stay -- stand still with that design. We're going to keep asking ourselves, "How can we make it even better as we go forward?"

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, how do the returns compete with the rest of the portfolio assuming that this uplift is repeatable?
componenttext: John, how do the returns compete with the rest of the portfolio assuming that this uplift is repeatable?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can simply tell you, we look at our programs, we look at a different flat prices like the one Tom mentioned. And certainly, right now, the 2-mile Upper Wolfcamp in Culberson, that area is one of our top-tier programs right now, especially with the
componenttext: Well, I can simply tell you, we look at our programs, we look at a different flat prices like the one Tom mentioned. And certainly, right now, the 2-mile Upper Wolfcamp in Culberson, that area is one of our top-tier programs right now, especially with the most recent well results. So it looks very, very good to us. And we're very anxious to get that spacing pilot in so we can start to hone in on exactly what the full potential is for that zone for us from a development standpoint.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Matt Portillo of TPH.
componenttext: The next question will come from Matt Portillo of TPH.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick clarification questions. On the theoretical 2017 production with the timing of the Cana completion. I just wanted to clarify when thinking about the exit rate Q4 '15 of about 985 million a day, would the thought be that with the Can
componenttext: Just a couple of quick clarification questions. On the theoretical 2017 production with the timing of the Cana completion. I just wanted to clarify when thinking about the exit rate Q4 '15 of about 985 million a day, would the thought be that with the Cana completions, the total corporate production could reach that level again by kind of Q2 2017 if everything kind of stays on plan as you guys envision it at the moment?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of a worse case, where that production doesn't start until the first half of -- or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17
componenttext: Matt, this is Joe. I'll answer that. What we've modeled is kind of a worse case, where that production doesn't start until the first half of -- or first part of '17. And in that scenario, we're about up to the same corporate total company levels by Q2 '17. And if we speed up things, we might find ourselves in maybe the Q1 time period. So again, it's all timing. And somebody with their questions alluded to the fact that these are big projects; you've got multiple wells all coming on at once. And you saw what rolled forward it for us from Q3 to Q4, significant increase in our Cana production from 405 million -- in Mid-Continent, from 405 million to 461 million a day. So those are big swings. You could see the difference between our Q4. If you apply our Q4 exit rate with a typical decline or whatever, you might think we're going to be in the high-800s. And all of a sudden, 2 quarters later, we're 100 million a day higher than that. So it's just the nature of the beast and it's all about timing.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then just a second question on 2016 guidance. I was hoping that you could potentially provide a little bit of clarity around the midstream impact and the curtailments. I think you guys alluded to some of those still impacting Q1
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then just a second question on 2016 guidance. I was hoping that you could potentially provide a little bit of clarity around the midstream impact and the curtailments. I think you guys alluded to some of those still impacting Q1, but I was curious how that's impacted your full year expectations as well. And any color or timing on when those may ultimately reverse here?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Joe. I'll answer that one as well. The gist of it is we're modeling and this is going to transpire here in Q1. We've been able to work some other marketing arrangements in and around the downstream curtailment that we have right now and hope
componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. I'll answer that one as well. The gist of it is we're modeling and this is going to transpire here in Q1. We've been able to work some other marketing arrangements in and around the downstream curtailment that we have right now and hope to have those plus the remedy itself of the facility that was impacted with the fire that you are aware of. Finalized by March, late March, and then of course we have our Hidalgo plant coming on not too far after that, and then there's a number of other processing alternatives that are on the map and pretty close to completion that we feel like mid- to late this year, we're going to be very good shape.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Jason Smith of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Jason Smith of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tom, the Meramec vessels well, I think, was a ways away from your other wells in the Meramec. And I know you have the downspacing pilot this year, but any plans to test the flanks of your acreage position there at all in 2016? And also just curious if
componenttext: So Tom, the Meramec vessels well, I think, was a ways away from your other wells in the Meramec. And I know you have the downspacing pilot this year, but any plans to test the flanks of your acreage position there at all in 2016? And also just curious if you have any near-term HBP requirements, I guess, outside of what you consider your derisked area?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be to essentially hold our acreage. A part of that will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised, not just by our results, b
componenttext: Yes. This is John. Yes, we will be testing quite a bit of extension acreage throughout the Meramec. Part of that will be to essentially hold our acreage. A part of that will also be delineation. We're still constantly surprised, not just by our results, but as Tom alluded to, a lot of competitor results that are kind of changing the landscape of the map in the Meramec. And it's given us some encouragement, especially as we look more to the western side, it's looking much more attractive to us. And fortunately for us, we have a pretty nice position there. In fact, that's where a lot of the new leasing that we have picked up is in more of that area. So yes, throughout the rest of this year we'll be geographically spreading across that map quite a bit with the wells that we'll be drilling and that will just help us further delineate the full potential for this interval.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's Tom. Just really a follow-up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair variability of results with landing zone. Our landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that it h
componenttext: Jason, it's Tom. Just really a follow-up on that. One of the things that we're seeing in the Meramec is a fair variability but also a fair variability of results with landing zone. Our landing zone seems to have a fairly strong impact in the way that it has surprised us compared to the Woodford below it. And so I think as we go forward, you're probably going to hear us talking more and more about the Mississippian as opposed to the Meramec. Yet some of the lower section, you hear the Osage being talked about as a target. And that's looking more and more interesting to us. There are some really good wells out there that are hard to explain if you only have the Meramec to explain it with. And so, as John said, there's a tremendous amount of upside for us not only in our acreage but also operational improvements since we test landing zones and then also completions. We're pretty bullish on that play right now and our position. And although we generally rue competition everywhere, there's some competition out there that's giving us a lot of good information and it's just shining a very good positive light on our position.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up is in a little different direction here. The dividend is now a lot bigger part of your cash flow at current prices. You obviously have the cash on your balance sheet to cover it. But just curious on your thoughts around where it fits and the
componenttext: My follow-up is in a little different direction here. The dividend is now a lot bigger part of your cash flow at current prices. You obviously have the cash on your balance sheet to cover it. But just curious on your thoughts around where it fits and the benefits of maintaining it at current levels.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're committed to a dividend. We've got some very long-term owners that -- for whom it's important. I will say, I was expecting that call because I know so many of our peers in their end of year release had addressed their dividend. We'll have a bo
componenttext: Well, we're committed to a dividend. We've got some very long-term owners that -- for whom it's important. I will say, I was expecting that call because I know so many of our peers in their end of year release had addressed their dividend. We'll have a board meeting next week and that's certainly going to be an active topic with the board, and we'll make decision around what's appropriate.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could maybe just provide a little additional granularity around the planned completions in the 2016 program outside of these kind of key projects that you've highlighted. First in the Permian, outside of the Tim Tam and the Reeves C
componenttext: I was wondering if you could maybe just provide a little additional granularity around the planned completions in the 2016 program outside of these kind of key projects that you've highlighted. First in the Permian, outside of the Tim Tam and the Reeves County infill. I guess you talked about 31 net completions coming out through the course of the year. I'm just curious what the composition of those other wells looks like, be it Bone Spring or Culberson, Upper Wolfcamp, Lower Wolfcamp, et cetera and then the Avalon?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Joe. As far as the net well counts of wells that are being completed during the year, we see about -- the majority of them, 2/3 of them are in the Wolfcamp, Culberson and Reeves, and then the remainder is primarily Bone Spring. And as I've me
componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. As far as the net well counts of wells that are being completed during the year, we see about -- the majority of them, 2/3 of them are in the Wolfcamp, Culberson and Reeves, and then the remainder is primarily Bone Spring. And as I've mentioned in my discussion earlier on, we've got a couple of rigs hitting them right now, right? And we're going to drop them down. So you're going to see our net completions in the area overall, wells waiting on completion increase to about 20-something in the middle of the year. And then it's going to come on down as we pull those rigs back and keep our frac crew running and it tapers itself in with just 6 waiting on completion at the end of the year. So it's really 2/3 Wolfcamp, 1/3 Bone Spring and really just kind of she goes consistent completion pattern during the year.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. He's absolutely right. I'll just point out the Bone Spring component, essentially those wells are drilled and then -- so they'll be completed in the first half. And then all of the rigs for the rest of the year will be dedicated toward Wolfcamp, towar
componenttext: No. He's absolutely right. I'll just point out the Bone Spring component, essentially those wells are drilled and then -- so they'll be completed in the first half. And then all of the rigs for the rest of the year will be dedicated toward Wolfcamp, toward finishing up the pilots. And then the rest of the time, it's all about acreage holding. So yes, there's a component of Bone Spring, but that's early in the year. Then everything else, for the rest of the year, is Wolfcamp.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that Wolfcamp activity outside of the Tim Tam and the Reeves infill, is that predominantly upper or lower? Or just from a leasehold perspectives, are you incentivized to...
componenttext: And that Wolfcamp activity outside of the Tim Tam and the Reeves infill, is that predominantly upper or lower? Or just from a leasehold perspectives, are you incentivized to...

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we've talked about before, it all kind of depends on the lease and what we need to do in order to hold, depending on the lease term. A lot of them may be in lower Wolfcamp's, others could be upper. I don't have that breakdown for you. I do know that as
componenttext: As we've talked about before, it all kind of depends on the lease and what we need to do in order to hold, depending on the lease term. A lot of them may be in lower Wolfcamp's, others could be upper. I don't have that breakdown for you. I do know that as a program, we're about half and half, half net wells in Culberson, half approximately in Reeves for the year.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. The majority of them, about 2/3, will be -- now this is not counting the infill program which we said we've been deferred into the Woodford development program, which we deferred into '17. But of the '16 completions, approximately 2/3 are in the Meramec and just some little singles in and around that. But John, I don't know if you want to look to that?

componenttextpreview: No. Joe is absolutely right. Again, we are pushing back the Eastern core development theoretically into '17. The majority of our completions will be Meramec and then we have the occasional Woodford on a one-off well where we still continue to expand and t
componenttext: No. Joe is absolutely right. Again, we are pushing back the Eastern core development theoretically into '17. The majority of our completions will be Meramec and then we have the occasional Woodford on a one-off well where we still continue to expand and test the boundaries of our Woodford play.

componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I just wanted to understand a little better around the decision to -- or the -- I guess, yes, just the decisions around the timing of that row development and bringing that on production late in the year or early next year. Is that -- it sounde
componenttext: Okay. Then I just wanted to understand a little better around the decision to -- or the -- I guess, yes, just the decisions around the timing of that row development and bringing that on production late in the year or early next year. Is that -- it sounded like it's more a function maybe of holding acreage in the Mid-Continent as opposed to logistical considerations with...

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. And I'll just say as I alluded to in my comments, we have a partner and we develop these rows. We coordinate with our partner from a standpoint of the frac's calendar. We recognized that to achieve the optimal result, we have to work t
componenttext: Well, this is John. And I'll just say as I alluded to in my comments, we have a partner and we develop these rows. We coordinate with our partner from a standpoint of the frac's calendar. We recognized that to achieve the optimal result, we have to work together, we have to time our frac schedule appropriately as we bring these wells on. Our partner has indicated to us that, at this time, they would like to delay that frac schedule. And so we are working with them and coordinating with them to the best of our ability. We have emphasized we'd like to move it up some, if we could. We understand the position they're taking, but we would like to move it up in the year if we could. And we're having those ongoing discussions right now. And we'll see where it ends. I think what we've done is we've presented you, maybe you could call, the worst case scenario, where they get pushed all the way to early '17. But there's a chance perhaps we can push them up earlier into '16. I think that would be our preference.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Cimarex Energy First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the conference over to Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. Acierno, please go ahead.
componenttext:
Welcome to the Cimarex Energy First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the conference over to Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. Acierno, please go ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rocco. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call this morning. So yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. And as a reminder, our d
componenttext:
Thanks, Rocco. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call this morning. So yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. And as a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed today. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business.
So today's prepared remarks, we'll begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden,  followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, VP of Exploration; and then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on operations, including production and well cost. Our CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. And as Rocco said, we will try to keep everybody to 1 question and 1 follow up, so that we can get everybody in the question queue, and you can feel free to jump back in if you have another questions.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's conference call. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will walk us thr
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's conference call. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will walk us through our recent results to describe our progress and some of the projects we have underway. Joe will follow John with an operational overview, including some of the significant steps we have taken to improve sales and efficiencies.
As we described impasse calls, the timing of our delineation projects, many of the significant results from our 2016 delineation program will come and fit some starts this year. Rest assured, our organization is hard at work during this downturn, necessity is the mother of [indiscernible].
I'd like open the call with some brief overview remarks regarding our direction in 2016 and beyond. As always, our focus will be on results. We reported a strong production week this quarter driven by improved well performance. Our total company production came in at 973 million cubic feet equivalent per day for the first quarter, which exceeded the high end of our guidance. Expenses came in within guidance, resulting in a strong quarter overall. Gas production was up, our oil production was down slightly. As we had forecasted, this was due to fewer well completions in the Permian basin due to the timing of our delineation projects. We expect to pick up the pace in our Permian completions during the remainder of the year.
We also reported a modest increase in our 2016 capital budget. This is the result of the completions of our East Cana-Woodford program being pushed forward from 2017 into 2016. The application is bigger, more effective simulations across the board and greater-than-anticipated working interest in both our own walls and in partner operated wells. With the results that we're seeing, we're delighted to have an increased exposure.
Since our last call, we've seen a bit of reading room in commodity prices. As a result, were accelerating some of the Permian completion activity that was delayed due to the planned [indiscernible]. As you'll also hear during the call our focus on science and innovation continues to pace. We continue to experiment with more effective stimulations primarily to the use of more profit, more stages, Hydro cluster spacing and more clusters per space and the use of diverter technology. This down cycle and associated decrease in activity is providing an ideal environment to focus on science and technology. We're also taking advance of decreased service cost to experiment and improve our methodologies.
We've also made great strides in reducing our cost structure. The organizations undergoing a conservative effort to lower G&A through voluntary retirements that lead to headcount reductions, reducing contracting consultants services and optimizing work efficiencies, particularly in the field.
Finally, before I turn the call over to John, I'd like to comment on our thoughts as we look ahead. In 2015, we said that our challenge was to get our program to a point where sustainable our living within cash flow and have a capital program with a cost structure that was appropriate for the new normal. In our  last call, we told you that our challenge in 2016 was to preserve our assets, preserve our balance sheet and preserve organization. I am pleased to tell you that we are on track with those set goals. As we look ahead of the current strip and model of Cimarex and list of cash flow and is able to get back on a growth trajectory in years ahead. We have best-in-class assets, and we will be able to preserve our prime leasehold in our current program. Our organization is effective, focused and hard at work garnering new opportunities. Our balance sheet provides the flexibility and strength that will keep Cimarex at the forefront in a highly competitive landscape.
We don't know where commodity prices are headed but we don't expect to return to the price levels of 2014 anytime soon. Margins will be challenged, cost structures will be paramount and asset quality and organizational effectiveness will be the differentiator. It's always been a tough business and things won't be easier as we move ahead. Our focus is on performance and results. Although further price recovery will be warmly welcomed, we are in great shape and look ahead with conviction that our value creation proposition is alive and well.
With that, I like to turn the call over to John to provide further color on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $158 million on exploration development during the first
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $158 million on exploration development during the first quarter. About 55% was invested in the Permian region with the rest going toward activities in the region. Company-wide, we brought 22 gross 5 net wells on production during the first quarter. Despite the small number of wells completed during the quarter, Cimarex had an average of 10 operated rigs running during the quarter. These rigs were busy finishing the drilling of wells in the Woodford Shale as well as drilling spacing pallets in both the Delaware basin and in the [indiscernible]. That activity is winding down and the majority of our contracting drilling rates will be by July.
By August, we plan to be down to 3 operated rigs. In the Delaware basin, you may recall that we spotted downspacing pilot in the upper Wolfcamp in Culberson County in the fourth quarter 2015. We are finished with the drilling portion of these wells and completions are scheduled to begin in mid-May. First production is now expected by midyear. This 6-well 7,500 foot lateral [indiscernible] will test 2 different spacing designs. One in eight wells per section, while the others will test 6 wells per section, both will be drilled in a staggered pattern.
Cimarex continues to push the envelope on well completions. On Page 12 of our presentation, we've shown you the uplift using a 40% larger completion on these Upper Wolfcamp wells, which equates to 1,640 pounds of sand prefer. We are about to take that a step further on using even larger designed complete this 6-well pilot. Incorporating 2,500 pounds of sand per lateral foot, these wells will have 44% more sand pump than the largest completed wells we've had to date as shown on Page 12.
We are currently drilling also our lower Wolfcamp project, which we call [indiscernible]. This 10,000-foot spacing pilot is comprised of 5 wells which will be drilled in a stack staggered pattern testing 6 wells per section. We believe the success [indiscernible] larger completions in the Upper Wolfcamp should easily translate to that lower Wolfcamp.
By lay of example, Page 13 in our presentation illustrates the we've seen with a larger completion on a 10,000-foot Upper Wolfcamp. We have also just finished operations on our largest lower Wolfcamp completion today, a well we call the flying Ebony where we pumped 5,400 pounds of sand per foot. The production data from on this well along with the larger completions we are doing with the Upper Wolfcamp will provide us with equal data and design in future completions including the 10-pound wells, which are scheduled to be completed in the second half of 2016.
For the remainder of 2016, the vast majority of the capital that we will spend in the primarily will be earmarked for acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. The total capital ascribed to acreage holding in the Delaware basin is just over $200 million in 2016. Part of this obligation drilling will include 6 2 mile-long infill wells in Reeves County, which recently commenced drilling. Similar to our Anaconda pilot, these wells will be drilled using a stack staggered pattern resulting in equivalent of 12 wells per section. Once drilling is completed on this section, we will be down to 2 upper rigs in the Permian for the remainder of the year.
Now on to the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling the latest Woodford development project on the East side of the Cana core in the first quarter of 2015. This development covers 6 sections of which Cimarex operates 2 sections. Due to some last-minute changes in working interest, this in-field project now consist of 47 [indiscernible] 22 net wells. Drilling is nearly finished and completion of these wells have been moved up as now scheduled for early October versus the first quarter 2017. This change in scheduling was a contributing factor in our $15 million increase in capital expenditures for 2016.
In our emerging Meramec play, we now have production data on 18 operated 5,000-foot products. Also our third 2,000-foot wells in Meramec has been in production since early January. Located in Blaine County, this well called the [indiscernible] 1H-2722X had a 30-day peak IP rate of 10.8 [indiscernible] cubic feet [indiscernible] per day including 951 barrels of oil per day. That results in a [indiscernible] deal of around 270 barrels per [indiscernible] 
Page 21one of the presentation illustrates the average uplift we've seen from the 3 long laterals in the Meramec versus the 5,000-foot laterals drilled to date. They have outperformed the shorter laterals by 62%, more than up by 120 days. While we are very encouraged by the initial uplift in IP that we are seeing in these 10,000-foot laterals, we continue to carefully monitor the decline profile in order to determine the open EURs for these long laterals.
To better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have designed a downspacing pilot, which commenced drilling in the fourth quarter of 2015, and has just finished the drilling phase. See Slide 22 for an illustration of the design. The 8 new wells will be stacked and staggered in both the Meramec at Woodford formations. The spacing in the Meramec would be the equivalent on a 10 wells per section made up of 5 upper and 5 lower staggered Meramec wells. The Woodford will be drilled with our standard 9-well per section development plan. Another Meramec spacing pilot operated by our partner, Devon, was recently completed in the early stages of flowback. The results from this 5 wells per section pilot will strongly influence our completion plans for the stacked and staggered pilot. Once drilling is finished on [indiscernible] sections, we will be focused on holding our Meramec acreage.
As you know, in late 2014, we added 12,250 net acres in the Meramec at an average cost of $1,650 per acre. About $70 million of our capital is being invested in the Meramec acreage in 2016. We currently have 4 rigs operating in that region with plans to be down to 1 operated rig by July of this year.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll head on the usual items. Our first quarter production, our Q2 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll follow-up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. As Tom
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll head on the usual items. Our first quarter production, our Q2 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll follow-up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. As Tom mentioned, with the help of stronger-than-expected days property and new well performance, our first quarter volumes came in slightly better than anticipated. Our reported total company net equivalent production of $973 million a day beat our guidance projection at $925 million to $955 million a day, and was up 3% from the $947 million a day that we posted in Q1 '15. As expected, the facility and disruptions and processing constraints in the Permian did negatively impact our Q1 production to the tune of approximately $30 million a day.
Our first quarter equivalent Permian production came in at $477 million a day, down $43 million a day from Q4 '15. The decrease was expected and came as another result of the facility downtime I just mentioned, as well as completing 3 net Permian wells in Q1 as compared to 8 wells in the fourth quarter of '15.
With our Cana-Woodford wells coming online in late Q4. We did anticipate a nice lift [indiscernible] during Q1, and we saw just of that. With the wells exceeding our plan expectations, our mid-content volumes came in 493 million a day, that's up 7% from the $461 million a day we reported in the fourth quarter and 11% from the $444 million a day that we posted a year ago in Q1 '15.
As we look forward into the remainder of this year, we've made a few changes to our completion schedule, including the addition of the flag crew in the Permian to help catch up on deferred completions from the downstream disruptions in Q1. And by advancing, as John mentioned, the timing of our Cana to October this year.
With our stronger-than-expected Q1 results and these completion timing adjustments, we've increased our full year total company equivalent production guidance to 940 million to 970 million a day, up about in a midpoint basis of 45 million a day from our beginning-year guidance of 890 million to 930 million. As compared to the original guidance, the acceleration of our Cana-Woodford project resulted in significant decrease in the number of drilled and uncompleted wells on at the end of the year. Our current model now projects 32 wells and 9 net wells leading on completion at year-end, that compares to the 57 drills and 24 net wells that we anticipated with we have waiting completion early this year when we issued the beginning of the guidance. The total ratio not only burst our 2016 total company guidance. But it increases our projected 2016 exit rate as well with our new modeling, we now project our total company of fourth quarter exit rate this year to be right in line with that of the 986 million a day that we posted back in the fourth quarter of '15.
In the Permian, the Q1 facility downtime and processing constraints resulted in us differing absolutely 3 net completions in the latter part of this year with the processing constraints anticipated to now being behind us, our plans are at the second completion group to help catch up and that will be here in May and early June. And with the projected 2 rigs working, the latter part of the year as John mentioned, we're still forecasting approximately 50 drills and 30 Permian wells to come online in 2016, that's slightly the previous estimates that we just released. [indiscernible] pace clear into Q2 and Q3. So as a result, our protected number of Permian drilled and uncompleted wells were in essence, dropped really quickly here from 34 drills to -- and 21 net wells here in May to 10 drills and 9 net on books by year-end.
For Q2 '16, our projected guidance of 935 million to 965 million a day reflects a drop in production from Q1 '16 levels, primarily as we await the scheduled Permian and Cana completion activity which was planned for Q3 and Q4. And to help you -- provide you some clarity on our projected completion timing through the year, we completed 5 net wells in Q1 with forecasting approximately 13 net wells to be completed in Q2 with approximately 44 net wells projected to come online in Q3 and Q4. So you can see that this is in the latter quarters as far as our completion activity is concerned.
Shifting gears to OpEx. Our production group continued to make great strides during Q1 to further reduce our operating cost. Through their efforts, we realize additional and sizable cost reduction an items such a saltwater disposal, compression, rentals and contract labor. As a result, our Q1 '16 lifting cost came in at $0.80 per Mcfe, that's was at the low-end of our guidance which was $0.80 to $0.90 per Mcfe, down 6.3% for [indiscernible] of fourth quarter average of $0.85 and down 17% from the $0.96 we posted through the average in the first quarter of '15.
With our cost control efforts, we're projecting our 2016 lifting cost to continue to fall in the range of $0.80 to $0.90. I'd say, we're most likely to be on the lower end of that range as we finish off the year. We're extremely proud of the efforts that our [indiscernible] has put forward to reduce our cost structure, all the while, maintaining safe and efficient operations. Tom touched on this not only critical for us to be able to compete in this low product price environment. But our reduced OpEx is also freeing up capital for our drilling and making us more efficient operator. Since prices began falling back in 2014, on an absolute basis, we've seen our total company month rate net operating expense dropped about $5 million per month, which annualized equates to an additional $60 million that we can direct to our drilling program.
And finally, a few comments on drilling and completion cost. Although most drilling cost has remained somewhat in check during Q1, we were able to realize some modest reductions in service cost on the completion side, primarily in the Permian. On the drilling side, we're keeping our focus on efficiencies as seen with our Q1 average Wolfcamp spread to rig release drill time down to 28 days as compared to 25 days in 2014.
On the completion side, in addition to the modest service cost reductions I mentioned, mostly in the Permian, we placed a strong emphasis on reducing a lot of sourcing cost by challenging our team in the planning, engineering and operating efficiencies in every barn. The results of our efforts are just now beginning to make way into our total well cost.
As we continue to [indiscernible] on our frac design and size, our completion cost will continue to dominate our total well cost, while the experiment with larger frac designs beginning with our generic well AFE still have stayed to someone in check. An exception is the Wolfcamp where both our drilling and completion efficiencies have reduced our generic 2-mile lateral Culberson and lower Wolfcamp AFE to a range of $10.2 million to $11.2 million, that's down 5% from the $10.8 million to $11.6 million range that we quoted last fall, and down 22% from where we were in late 2014. With last quarter's frac designs, our Cana core 1-mile lateral wells continue to be in the range of $6.6 million to $7 million, unchanged from the last call and down 16% to 17% from 2014. But with a larger frac designs that we're contemplating to be utilized here in Q3 '16, this range is likely to increase in the range of $500,000 to $600,000 per well. And in the Meramec, our current 1-mile lateral AFEs [indiscernible] the range of $7 million to $7.4 million. Again, that is unchanged from last call and down 13% from late '14 and also here, if we employ larger fracs moving forward, we could see an additional $500,000 to $600,000 in [indiscernible] as well.
So in closing, we had another great quarter. We beat guidance despite a sizable downstream and weather disruptions. We've made significant strides, further reducing our LOE. Our drilling and completion group remains focused on cost efficiencies with these reductions and efficiencies and optimizing the results of our fracs. Our teams are tightly focused on maximizing the productivity and profitability of our wells, all the while, we're optimizing our investment program results.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Q&A.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: My first question is on Slide 11, on the Colbert County Wolfcamp 10,000-foot laterals, the before tax IRR change moved higher by significantly since your last update on this particular slide. Now just curious, what was driving that significant change?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. There are several factors in there, but the biggest driver is an improvement in our tight curve or expectation going forward, and that's really related to the continually to increase our frac design on these wells. We have 3 wells now w
componenttext: Yes, this is John. There are several factors in there, but the biggest driver is an improvement in our tight curve or expectation going forward, and that's really related to the continually to increase our frac design on these wells. We have 3 wells now with this current design, which I talked about earlier at the 1,640 pounds per foot, and those wells have been long enough now that what's really impressing us is the quite frankly, lack of decline. These wells come on and they tend to have a very long frac period to them, and we have enough time with those now that we gain confidence in that tight curve, and that's led to a major change in our expectation for these wells going forward. I should also point out that mentioned, we actually have also in addition to that seeing some cost reduction in these wells. So with all that factor together, that's led to the improvement you're seeing there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then follow-up, in this growth out of Slide #20 in your presentation on the Meramec, that looks like you have some new well results there on the 5,000-foot lateral and then also the 10,000-foot laterals. It looked like there were slightly w
componenttext: Excellent. And then follow-up, in this growth out of Slide #20 in your presentation on the Meramec, that looks like you have some new well results there on the 5,000-foot lateral and then also the 10,000-foot laterals. It looked like there were slightly weaker than supplier once now they may have a bit of a higher oil pad. Just want to get some color on those recent well results in the Meramec.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John, again. Well, first thing I would say is, this is still an emerging play and for us, we're still out there and doing both the combination of holding acreage, delineating acreage and testing frac design. And so it's fair to say that some of th
componenttext: This is John, again. Well, first thing I would say is, this is still an emerging play and for us, we're still out there and doing both the combination of holding acreage, delineating acreage and testing frac design. And so it's fair to say that some of the wells come in much better than expected and some came in less. We're still learning a lot in regards to these wells and there's still a lot that we think we can change or improve upon to make these wells even better. So yes, there's some variability there, especially, I would point out, yes, with our 10,000-foot lateral we just announced. It's also well, I want to point out that we anticipated having a much higher yield than our previous 2 10,000-foot laterals. And so in that case, we do not go back as aggressively from a choke management standpoint. We were interested and with this 1 particular [indiscernible] with choke management, how we can manage that yield. So for that well particular, I don't know that the 30-day rate well, -- 30-day rate is as important to us as say, the 90- or 180-day rate in terms of the way we're flowing that well back.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping you could speak to whether you can apply the same techniques you've used in the Wolfcamp A recently. You said you're testing with at least 1 well already, but does it have broader applications?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. We are very encouraged by what we're seeing coming out of the Upper Wolfcamp A wells. With this continuation of improving the frac design and that's why indeed, went to our most current 10,000-foot lateral in the lower Wolfcamp to find ebony
componenttext: This is John. We are very encouraged by what we're seeing coming out of the Upper Wolfcamp A wells. With this continuation of improving the frac design and that's why indeed, went to our most current 10,000-foot lateral in the lower Wolfcamp to find ebony to apply that design to it. It's just now an early flowback, we all have a very high expectations for that well but also recognize that not any 1 well makes a trend to share. But yes, going forward, we're very encouraged. And let me be also clear, we're not sure that we've really even reached even close to the end number in terms of these frac up lifts. So that's why for the Upper Wolfcamp spacing pilot, even though we don't have a well under our belt, we're very comfortable stepping up in the total amount of sand that we're going to pump in those wells. Because the way we model it with a modest increase in IPVUR, it's a very economic thing to do. So we're very pleased with the progress we're seeing here, in fact, that we still think there's a lot more to gain.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Tom. I want to follow-up on that. We're very excited with the Wolfcamp A, and certainly the results and the uplift we reported is real and it's grounded in actual results. We probably see the Wolfcamp A as being a better target overall than t
componenttext: Joe, this is Tom. I want to follow-up on that. We're very excited with the Wolfcamp A, and certainly the results and the uplift we reported is real and it's grounded in actual results. We probably see the Wolfcamp A as being a better target overall than the Wolfcamp B, but the Wolfcamp B is also outstanding. I mean, it's just a question of great and outstanding. But one of the things I want to follow-up on is -- one of the things that makes Cimarex strong is our presence in multiple plays and in particular, with our footprint in the Delaware Basin and our footprint in stack. We're doing a lot of innovation as are our competitors and every time we see something that works, we look for opportunities to apply it elsewhere in our portfolio. So having that footprint multiple play allows us to really bring innovations, and that's more quickly than we could if we were single basin player. So they are, as John said, we have a lot of running room in completion optimization in both the Wolfcamp A, Wolfcamp B and I would add, in stack, both in the Meramec and Woodford. All of those plays are trying some things in that laboratory, ideas to apply across the board. I don't know that -- we haven't even scratch the surface yet in a lot of areas and we're very excited about the advancements we're reporting, but we have tremendous uplift yet to happen. And so it's pretty exciting right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just to follow-up on that, the results, obviously, the Wolfcamp A, I know it's been less tested in Culberson because the returns, I think for, Wolfcamp B, it looks so good and you can hold the acreage by drilling down to the B. But can you give us a se
componenttext: So just to follow-up on that, the results, obviously, the Wolfcamp A, I know it's been less tested in Culberson because the returns, I think for, Wolfcamp B, it looks so good and you can hold the acreage by drilling down to the B. But can you give us a sense, a better sense of how delineated the Wolfcamp A is across your acreage position?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. It's not near as well delineated as it is for to B, that's a fair statement. The majority of our A drilling to date has mainly putting Culberson down in the southeast part, that's where we really recognize it and from the way we map it. But
componenttext: This is John. It's not near as well delineated as it is for to B, that's a fair statement. The majority of our A drilling to date has mainly putting Culberson down in the southeast part, that's where we really recognize it and from the way we map it. But I will also tell you that we are now stepping out into other areas of Culberson and then I'm hoping in our future earnings release to talk more about those efforts. But so far, it's been relegated more to a much more smaller area in the southeast in the D. But that's just as you mentioned early on, we are were drilling Ds in the way to hold our acreage and hold all our rights with the As, we think a little bit more selective but now, with these encouraging results we're seeing, we are quickly stepping down the other areas of our acreage to get a sense of just how good this could be across the whole position.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, there's tremendous future opportunity to test new zones and same zone elsewhere in our acreage. Not only within Culberson and Reeves County. So we have a lot of work ahead of us and it's definitely pointing us to get more and more excited about that
componenttext: Drew, there's tremendous future opportunity to test new zones and same zone elsewhere in our acreage. Not only within Culberson and Reeves County. So we have a lot of work ahead of us and it's definitely pointing us to get more and more excited about that asset.

componenttextpreview: Yes, sir. Yes.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On our previous row, row 4, we did quite a bit of experimentation with the frac design there. And then in fact, in 1 case, 1 section in particular, we pumped upwards of 32,000 pounds per foot, that section in those wells are outstanding. I mean, we a
componenttext: Yes. On our previous row, row 4, we did quite a bit of experimentation with the frac design there. And then in fact, in 1 case, 1 section in particular, we pumped upwards of 32,000 pounds per foot, that section in those wells are outstanding. I mean, we are just really impressed with the results coming off of that section. And so going forward into this newer development, our base case and I think Joe alluded to that, why we're anticipating the additional cost is to go up to that size of a frac job in the Woodford shale at 3,200 pounds per foot. Whereas before, standard was more around 1,800 pounds per foot. Again, there is cost there associated with it but based on the performance we're seeing on those wells, it's well worth the additional cost to do that. So that's our goal forward plan there for that next well development.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I was wondering if you could perhaps give us some more details on the stack -- staggered pilot that you're doing in the Meramec? In particular, I just wanted to see if you could comment maybe on where your completions have been lending today? And jus
componenttext: Tom, I was wondering if you could perhaps give us some more details on the stack -- staggered pilot that you're doing in the Meramec? In particular, I just wanted to see if you could comment maybe on where your completions have been lending today? And just your general thoughts around this pilot coming up.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before I answer your question, Arun, I'll turn it over to John. He'll have some additions. Landing zone is a real point of experimentation in the Meramec. In the early wells for Cimarex and for many of our competitors, it was quite frankly, a monkey see,
componenttext: Before I answer your question, Arun, I'll turn it over to John. He'll have some additions. Landing zone is a real point of experimentation in the Meramec. In the early wells for Cimarex and for many of our competitors, it was quite frankly, a monkey see, monkey do approach. The Meramec wasn't the most obvious reservoir. And so early wells were kind of targeted based on mimicking what offset wells have done. And as we've continued to delineate the play, Cimarex and the industry has tested different landing zones. We're testing 2 different landing zones and that Meramec stack staggered pilot, and we continue to experiment with landing zones throughout the play. We're seeing landing zones to be a overprint on production, that's greater than we initially anticipated. There are scenarios at play that have underperformed that we're going back in now and testing new landing zones, the new completion techniques and we're quite encouraged by the potential there. But it's a real open part of experimentation as to where the landings laterals. John, you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is for that particular spacing pilot, we went the extra step where we went ahead and drilled what we recall, pilot hole to get additional log information to really refine where to put those laterals in the Meramec. And I must te
componenttext: The only thing I would add is for that particular spacing pilot, we went the extra step where we went ahead and drilled what we recall, pilot hole to get additional log information to really refine where to put those laterals in the Meramec. And I must tell you, I feel pretty good about how we've done this for this particular stack staggered pilot in regards to the data we received from the pilot would really helped us pinpoint exactly where we want to put these letters whereas before, Tom's absolutely right, we would have looked just say, 2 sections over and see what the company X, Y, Z do as far as what he landed it. I think we're recognizing that for the Meramec. I mean, every section might have just a slight different tweak to where you want to put that lateral to achieve maximum performance. And that some of the lessons we're learning as we go forward. So I'm very excited about the stack staggered pilot, I'm looking forward to when we finally get around and completing it. But as I mentioned, we do have our strong interest in the other operated pilot that is just flowing back now and there was a lot of signs associated with that pilot, and we're very anxious to kind of see the flowback, review the signs data. And that's why we're not in any rush to go out and frac our occurrence stack staggered til we see some of those results and see how we might then tater our fracture design for our pilot.

componenttext: Great. Just my follow-up, you drilled and completed some wells at that portion of your acreage on the [indiscernible]. Any takeaway or conclusions around well performance on the [indiscernible] pretty similar?
