headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess I needed just to [indiscernible] the stack vernacular, I guess. Yes, we have. Again, delineation wells, sometimes the results were not as we were hoping. Other times, they're outstanding. It's quite of what you expect early on in a play like
componenttext: Yes. I guess I needed just to [indiscernible] the stack vernacular, I guess. Yes, we have. Again, delineation wells, sometimes the results were not as we were hoping. Other times, they're outstanding. It's quite of what you expect early on in a play like this where every now and then, you hit a homerun and then now and then, you hit one that's not so good. It didn't really -- it's the ones that don't quite meet our expectation that we really, really spend a lot of time on saying, "okay, what could be done differently? Where could we landed differently? How do we make it better?" So yes, I still think there's a lot of improvement still to come in this play based on what I'm seeing so far.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're similar, I think, speaks a little differently than some other companies about the Meramec. I would say, first and foremost, we are very excited about the Meramec. We have a program that is in our estimation, top tier. We study our wells, we study ou
componenttext: We're similar, I think, speaks a little differently than some other companies about the Meramec. I would say, first and foremost, we are very excited about the Meramec. We have a program that is in our estimation, top tier. We study our wells, we study our competitors wells and we think our results are in the upper class and we have a lot of data to back that segment up. That said, we do see a fair amount of reservoir variability through the play. We don't view the Meramec as a blanket play. We see a fair amount of variability and that's why John talked about the importance of having pilot holes when we target our laterals. The landing zones can change in short order, the yield can change a short order and the oil performance can change. Now, we're fairly confident based on the work we're doing that all of if not most of those are solvable, solvable with completion techniques, solvable with large application of your landing zones and it's an evolving story. And as we always have done, we're going to talk about results and our results stay on their own, they're quite good.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Folks on Reeves County, can you update us with the cumulative production days online with the big timber? And then whether or not you think those strong results are repeatable? And I guess a few comments on how the upper Wolfcamp in this area stacks up to
componenttext: Folks on Reeves County, can you update us with the cumulative production days online with the big timber? And then whether or not you think those strong results are repeatable? And I guess a few comments on how the upper Wolfcamp in this area stacks up to other Delaware application assets that are in your portfolio?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. I don't have the big timber production in front of me right now. We can probably get that information back to you. What I do know is based on that well result as well as other competitor wells in the area, we feel really, really good ab
componenttext: Yes, this is John. I don't have the big timber production in front of me right now. We can probably get that information back to you. What I do know is based on that well result as well as other competitor wells in the area, we feel really, really good about that acreage over there from a 10,000-foot lateral standpoint. So good as I mentioned, in my comments that we are moving forward with the development plans that we're doing in Reeves County with the 10,000-foot stack staggered development and we'll initiate started drilling on right now. It's a very good area for the Upper Wolfcamp. And I think, our Anadarko pilots really illustrated to us that it's not just a good area. It's quick enough to support multiple levels of wells in that shale. So going forward, we're very, very excited about that area and the results we'll get, especially from this development that we're currently drilling right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, as it competes for capital and others and your Delaware Basin program, I guess, assuming commodity price, assuming the strip currently isn't competitive with other assets in your portfolio. Do you have any constraints such as infrastructure that
componenttext: I guess, as it competes for capital and others and your Delaware Basin program, I guess, assuming commodity price, assuming the strip currently isn't competitive with other assets in your portfolio. Do you have any constraints such as infrastructure that may limit future development as you head into 2017?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take a stab at that. It competes very well with the other things that we have in our portfolio. The thing that's driving a lot of our capital this year as we've mention is acreage holding. And in particular, in Reeves, we have a lot of acreage
componenttext: Sure. I'll take a stab at that. It competes very well with the other things that we have in our portfolio. The thing that's driving a lot of our capital this year as we've mention is acreage holding. And in particular, in Reeves, we have a lot of acreage there that's still on a primarily term, that we definitely want to hold. So there is quite a bit of capital going that way. It is fair to say that once we get to a point where we have excess capital beyond on holding acreage then we'd have look. And in how we make those decisions, then it factors such as yes, always rate of return and take away issues and water sourcing as Joe mentioned, other factors that lead to really, to deploy that capital. But in terms of optional capital spending, Reeves holds it's own pretty well compared to Culberson right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, one of the things that drives that isn't just the rocks but it's also our diligent drilling at longer lateral. And so one of the things that makes Culberson such a beautiful asset for us, not only is a multiple zone, some of which we haven't eve
componenttext: Yes, Dan, one of the things that drives that isn't just the rocks but it's also our diligent drilling at longer lateral. And so one of the things that makes Culberson such a beautiful asset for us, not only is a multiple zone, some of which we haven't even tested yet, but we can drill long laterals at will, there's no constraint there over that entire acreage block. That's generally true with Reeves, but there are areas where it's not true and what Cimarex is doing and a lot of operators are focused on. I think, there widespread recognition of the [indiscernible] with longer wells. And so there were some trades going on to let us block up that area and be a better place to drill long laterals. But as far as the rock goes, it's highly competitive with other things we've got.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question is from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to take that net prior question on capital allocation, maybe a step further and just thinking about the portfolio as a whole, now that you've drilled more wells in Meramec and are getting more confident in your Upper Wolfcamp wells, I'm not going to as
componenttext: So to take that net prior question on capital allocation, maybe a step further and just thinking about the portfolio as a whole, now that you've drilled more wells in Meramec and are getting more confident in your Upper Wolfcamp wells, I'm not going to ask you Tom, when you're got to go back to work. But just a question around where that first incremental dollar goes when you do go back to work?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm back to work, Jason.
componenttext: I'm back to work, Jason.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm seeing that is a little better.
componenttext: I'm seeing that is a little better.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the challenge is, it's really evolving story. And if we have a snapshot of today, then we said, you know what? Based on what we know today, we have to make long-term capital allocation decisions, there would probably be a bias to a lot of our Delawa
componenttext: Well, the challenge is, it's really evolving story. And if we have a snapshot of today, then we said, you know what? Based on what we know today, we have to make long-term capital allocation decisions, there would probably be a bias to a lot of our Delaware program, I'm not only the Bone Spring but the Avalon looks quite good and these long wells in the Wolfcamp, those are all cream of the crop. But we are still seeing not only in Meramec, but I would still put Woodford in the mix, that with our experiments we're doing with our completion innovations, we're seeing a really improving story there. And so in the near term, we're going to continue to experiment. And we want to have an active program on both basins because what we learn is setting the stage for long-term capital allocation. I mean, you've heard us talk about in the Woodford, we have some projects that would be stacked Meramec and Woodford that once we kick them off, they are hundreds of 10,000-foot long wells. I mean, it's a real opportunity for Cimarex. So we're not just going to snapshot today, it's evolving story.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. I'll just follow-up, specially in today's market to what Tom said, completion costs are really surprisingly enough to me, that gotten a little softer on the service, kind of, side. But as an example to just take our total company frac stats,
componenttext: This is Joe. I'll just follow-up, specially in today's market to what Tom said, completion costs are really surprisingly enough to me, that gotten a little softer on the service, kind of, side. But as an example to just take our total company frac stats, now is the time to have the extra mentation. Our early 2016 average frac as statistics compared to our 2015 average are such that we're drilling, we're completing 11% longer laterals, pumping 23% more fluid, 30% more sand and when you look at an all in cost reduction per well including water sourcing, we're seeing a reduction of 5% in our completion cost with all those increases. So now is the time to try those experiments.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And Just 1 quick one on the Avalon. A few of your peers have talked about it this quarter, I think that it's held by production for you guys, are there any changing thoughts around allocating some capital there? Doing further tests in that
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And Just 1 quick one on the Avalon. A few of your peers have talked about it this quarter, I think that it's held by production for you guys, are there any changing thoughts around allocating some capital there? Doing further tests in that zone?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Actually, I think about 2 days ago, I was in Midland, and reviewed our latest Avalon well with our latest generation of frac design and it's fantastic. It's a great well. And the challenge, again, as you mentioned is all helped our productio
componenttext: This is John. Actually, I think about 2 days ago, I was in Midland, and reviewed our latest Avalon well with our latest generation of frac design and it's fantastic. It's a great well. And the challenge, again, as you mentioned is all helped our production. And so right now, we'd much rather spend that capital to hold the rest of our acreage position throughout the Wolfcamp. But I can tell you, I've got a team down there that's itching to go on a 2-mile lateral in the Avalon, and the numbers look great. The statistic -- a matter of capital allocation are now where we think, obviously, our best interest is to go out there and deploy that capital, hold our acreage for this year. But they're [indiscernible] to go and then at some point, especially since we've already got a number of the spacing products done where we're already at 8 wells per section on each interval within the Avalon, there are several benches. So it looks really good. It's just a question of when we get the point where I guess, as someone said, we can get back and we start drilling some more wells out there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Janine from Citigroup.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the fourth quarter call, you all provided us with your estimated year-end "16 cash balance, I think it was $400 million. And with the $50 million CapEx increase that you announced last night, what's your new estimated cash balance at year-end '16 an
componenttext: So on the fourth quarter call, you all provided us with your estimated year-end "16 cash balance, I think it was $400 million. And with the $50 million CapEx increase that you announced last night, what's your new estimated cash balance at year-end '16 and realizing that the strip is moved up in the meantime?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc Huron. Early May, May 2nd strip price with that incremental capital and volume forecast, we're still expecting actually gone up a bit from $484 million [ph] and $450 million, as the way it looks right now. So it's something we're closely watc
componenttext: This is Marc Huron. Early May, May 2nd strip price with that incremental capital and volume forecast, we're still expecting actually gone up a bit from $484 million [ph] and $450 million, as the way it looks right now. So it's something we're closely watching and seeing how that reach of the year but a -- even with the increased capital, expect that cash balance to be even a bit higher than we have previously forecasted.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Janine, I want to give just a little bit of detail on that CapEx increase. On our fourth quarter call, we were in the range of $600 million to $650 million, and we said the upper end of that $650 million will be a close to completion drilled into 2016
componenttext: And Janine, I want to give just a little bit of detail on that CapEx increase. On our fourth quarter call, we were in the range of $600 million to $650 million, and we said the upper end of that $650 million will be a close to completion drilled into 2016. So those completions have rolled into 2016, so if we wanted to benchmark us against the next fourth quarter, we'll be at that $650 million number we talked about. Now we give a range of guidance of $650 million to $700 million, so really, we can deal with midpoint, midpoint is $675 million. So really, it's a $25 million increase that we're really wanted our fourth quarter call given that those completions accelerated. So although it looks like $50 million, I think that's probably just an absolute upper end of that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great, it's actually helpful. My follow-up, so it sounds like you have more cash, slightly more cash than you previously thought and you're finding more ways to spend your cash flow. So what are the next opportunities you have to spend more CapEx on
componenttext: Okay. Great, it's actually helpful. My follow-up, so it sounds like you have more cash, slightly more cash than you previously thought and you're finding more ways to spend your cash flow. So what are the next opportunities you have to spend more CapEx on if you spend anymore at all?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take that this Tom. We've got lots to do and certainly, we have a lot of projects that are begging for capital in the Delaware basin and these are as John said, the list is long and long and long. And then this Meramec delineation probably is o
componenttext: Well, I'll take that this Tom. We've got lots to do and certainly, we have a lot of projects that are begging for capital in the Delaware basin and these are as John said, the list is long and long and long. And then this Meramec delineation probably is one that we easily be able to throw a little capital at. And then we're also -- we talked in the past about we're doing some exploration. I mean, this is the time when we're kind of keying on what our organization does best and our value proposition has always been centered around doing good geoscience, finding ideas to give us a competitive advantage and getting acreage positions ahead of the crowd. And so we're putting a lot of emphasis on that as well and there will be some opportunities come out of that. So depending on what the landscape looks like over the next 6 months, I think there's a reasonable chance that we may do a little more. We're going to need to see the fundamentals [indiscernible] we're going to need to have confidence that this price files is supportable, that we are ready to roll with cash in balance sheet to do it.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Michael Hall of Hiking and Energy.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Michael Hall of Hiking and Energy.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me follow-up a little on that while we're on the topic. Just bigger picture, as I think about capital allocation as a cycle, what's your perspective on spending cash? You mentioned earlier in your remarks that you think within cash flow on the strip,
componenttext: Let me follow-up a little on that while we're on the topic. Just bigger picture, as I think about capital allocation as a cycle, what's your perspective on spending cash? You mentioned earlier in your remarks that you think within cash flow on the strip, you can get back to growth in the years ahead. Appreciate that certainly, but we'll end the year with a substantial amount of cash on hand already very differentiated balance sheet. And just thinking through this where we are in the cycle, you've got productivity trending up into the right cost or at cyclical lows. How do you think about outspending cash flow and as we move further forward in 2017, given the current environment, is that something you'd be more likely to do than in other points in the cycle?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'll take that. This is Tom. We are very willing to outspend cash flow. And the way I think about it is very simple, it's about creating value. If we can borrow money at low interest rate, invest it in a high interest rate, I think as long as we'
componenttext: Michael, I'll take that. This is Tom. We are very willing to outspend cash flow. And the way I think about it is very simple, it's about creating value. If we can borrow money at low interest rate, invest it in a high interest rate, I think as long as we're confident in those returns, that's a value creating proposition for our shareholders. And with our top tier assets, I think our bias as a management team is to bring that value forward for our shareholders. Now that said, when you drill a well, those returns are predicated on a discounted cash flow that's made some significant assumptions on future commodity pricing. And the quality of that assumption is key. If we get to a point where we gain confidence about that future commodity pricing, if we think that the markets have kind of worked themselves out and they're in balance and we get asked about at what price file? It's not about the price file. We have the opportunities today at this price file to accelerate in that value. It's about our confidence in the price file and that the markets are in balance and that we think that it's a fairly low volatile proposition. So I think our bias is going to be to invest, use our balance sheet and yes, we'd be willing to modestly outspend cash flow. Mark, you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I completely agree, Tom. It's a gain in confidence in that future curve because that would be saying, kind of, saying thinking about increasing activity, the current curves suggest that we have [indiscernible] economic well drill, but we've seen a co
componenttext: Yes. I completely agree, Tom. It's a gain in confidence in that future curve because that would be saying, kind of, saying thinking about increasing activity, the current curves suggest that we have [indiscernible] economic well drill, but we've seen a couple of [indiscernible] exceeding commodity price [indiscernible] to these probably working on expectations of oil productions and inventories improving. We're just starting to see the -- we want to see more continuation in that and making sure that strip really is grounded and based on core fundamentals.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just say 1 last thing on that. We do an annual look back and many of you heard of us talk about that in the past. And John and I spent 2 hours yesterday reviewing our annual look back, going back on our history of economic performance and there are s
componenttext: I'll just say 1 last thing on that. We do an annual look back and many of you heard of us talk about that in the past. And John and I spent 2 hours yesterday reviewing our annual look back, going back on our history of economic performance and there are some real lessons there. And one lessons is you really have that confidence in that commodity price file. I mean, there's a lot of lessons in that. It's about being good at the business, making sure you have high-quality assets and being very prudent in your investments. And I think, Cimarex has a long history of success on that front, and we're in a continued to stay disciplined. We have a luxury of top tier assets and outstanding returns in this current price environment. So we're going to be ready to roll and I think you -- I think it's reasonable for you to expect with a little stability and commodity pricing, you'll see Cimarex pick up the pace.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. It's very helpful. I guess my follow-up, step in kind of way back again high-level, just look at the Meramec today, this might be a little tricky to answer, but just given every, all the moving pieces in the world. But if you look a
componenttext: Appreciate that color. It's very helpful. I guess my follow-up, step in kind of way back again high-level, just look at the Meramec today, this might be a little tricky to answer, but just given every, all the moving pieces in the world. But if you look at the Meramec today and you try to kind of compare that to the year of learning curve for the Wolfcamp and the Dell basin. And so looking back in time in the Delaware Basin and on the Wolfcamp, what year would you do the [indiscernible] if you were to try and characterize the Meramec today, if that make sense?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- this is John, and I guess I'll take a stab at that. It's interesting you asked that, I've been actually, I'm going down memory lane and just recently talked with our lead generator for Culberson. I've forgotten it Culberson started 2006 for us.
componenttext: Well, I -- this is John, and I guess I'll take a stab at that. It's interesting you asked that, I've been actually, I'm going down memory lane and just recently talked with our lead generator for Culberson. I've forgotten it Culberson started 2006 for us. So we're at year 10 in Culberson. And I'm going to tell you right now, we still don't know everything about Wolfcamp and Culberson, and obvious by our low results and what we continue to do. Whereas we're in year 2 at Meramec, and I just think we scratched the surface, there's just so much that we are learning with each well both us and our competitors. And in some way, yes, it is happening at a far more accelerated pace than Culberson ever did because we're the only game in town when we're doing Culberson. Here, as you well are all aware, we have at least 5 other operators drilling all around us and we're all looking to achieve trying to figure out what works best, where should I go, where do I land. And so clearly, it's at a much more accelerated pace. But sometimes I wonder, maybe too fast, honestly. You never really get a chance to really catch a breath and look at the data and look at the results, not just that 30-day rate, as I mentioned, but with this [indiscernible] doing 180 days later, and it is surprising. And so I -- there -- sometimes I wish we went a little bit slower, to be honest, in Meramec, but in some ways, we're being forced to with the competition. So I don't know if that answers your question but that's just my perspective on what's going on in Meramec right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw the same -- this is Joe. We saw the same thing and Cana when we kicked off that program in 2007 and its 2014 where our frac design revolutionizes the play. So that's a tough question. Where is the endgame on how well these wells can produce, is the
componenttext: We saw the same -- this is Joe. We saw the same thing and Cana when we kicked off that program in 2007 and its 2014 where our frac design revolutionizes the play. So that's a tough question. Where is the endgame on how well these wells can produce, is the real question here.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A good segue into the question I had here focusing in on the Meramec. Going back to the commentary on the landing zone and some of the variability. How do you address those challenges in the variability as you apply the down spacing test going forward, bo
componenttext: A good segue into the question I had here focusing in on the Meramec. Going back to the commentary on the landing zone and some of the variability. How do you address those challenges in the variability as you apply the down spacing test going forward, both the results from yours and Evans across the broader acreage position?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. That's a great question, it's something that we talk about all the time. Part of it is sometimes in some of the sections, we're blessed to have, quite frankly, quite a bit of vertical control within the section to give us an idea what variab
componenttext: This is John. That's a great question, it's something that we talk about all the time. Part of it is sometimes in some of the sections, we're blessed to have, quite frankly, quite a bit of vertical control within the section to give us an idea what variability we should expect. In other cases, quite frankly, we've reached the point, we said we're just go ahead and drill and create that information by drilling a pilot hole. I would also tell you in some ways, we're putting even more renewed emphasis on our 3D seismic coverage, because at least with 3D seismic, you're sampling the geology, so to speak, in a much finer scale. So we're really trying to incorporate that as a tool to help us along with the subsurface control and the horizontal wells that's been drilled to date to build a more comprehensive model what's going on and what we should expect going forward. I would just tell you that again, right now, we have expectations for every Meramec well we drill on each one, in some ways, typically surprises us. And fortunately, to the positive but also sometimes, in the negative. So as we go forward, we'll continue to look for ways to get more comfortable with that variability and be able to adjust to it appropriately.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we see opportunities and we're always in the hunt. As we talked in the past calls, there's no point in time that where we're not evaluating something. Our challenge is we want to create value. And I think if you look at the history of M&A, in EMP an
componenttext: Well, we see opportunities and we're always in the hunt. As we talked in the past calls, there's no point in time that where we're not evaluating something. Our challenge is we want to create value. And I think if you look at the history of M&A, in EMP and in other industries, it's a fairly challenging landscape for acquirers to make the argument that over the long run, that's been a real good value creating strategy. Now, hey, maybe we count our money differently than others do. But we are who we are and we want to be forthright in our approach in the business. We're look at full cycle value creation, we look at time to capital, we looking at what the pace of development will be and will that generate a rate of return for our shareholders. Some of these splashy acquisition deals are good for everybody who participates except for the shareholder. In our focus first and foremost, is on shareholder value. So now, as I've said in the past, there are assets we covent, and w nourished some really outstanding assets on the market and some really outstanding assets that transact it, and we been in that game. And we often are at a valuation point where we are just flat out unwilling to get the number that's the winning bid. We ask ourselves at every turn, what's our competitive advantage. If we don't have a competitive advantage and that's generally either information, science or ability to execute well above and beyond our competitors then we're just bidding discount rate and commodity price forecast with a group of very well-funded competitors. And that's just not a winning proposition for the Cimarex shareholder. So we look, I'm very hopeful that there'll be opportunities for us and when we find the right one, we'll strike. But it will be right because we had a competitive advantage.

We've always kept our debt low and our conclusion from what we've seen over the last 24 months is that was a prudent course of action because we have a lot of flexibility today into the arena where many of our competitors do not. So we're going to be careful but nobody's unhappier with us going down 3 rigs than we are, but what we have to do it and we're going to stay disciplined.

componenttext:
Welcome to the Cimarex Energy First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the conference over to Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. Acierno, please go ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rocco. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call this morning. So yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. And as a reminder, our d
componenttext:
Thanks, Rocco. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call this morning. So yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. And as a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed today. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business.
So today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, VP of Exploration. And then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on operations, including production and well cost. Our CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. [Operator Instructions]
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference call. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will walk us th
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference call. We sincerely appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. 
On the call today, John will walk us through our recent results and describe our progress on some of the delineation projects we have underway. Joe will follow John with an operational overview, including some of the significant steps we have taken to improve field efficiencies.
As we've described in past calls, owing to timing of our delineation projects, many of the significant results from our 2016 delineation program will come in fits and starts this year. Rest assured, our organization is hard at work during this downturn. Necessity is the mother of invention.
I'd like open the call with some brief overview remarks regarding our direction in 2016 and beyond. As always, our focus will be on results. We reported a strong production beat this quarter, driven by improved well performance. Our total company production came in at 973 million cubic feet equivalent per day for the first quarter, which exceeded the high end of our guidance. Expenses came in within guidance, resulting in a strong quarter overall. 
Gas production was up, while oil production was down slightly. As we had forecasted, this was due to fewer well completions in the Permian basin due to the timing of our delineation projects. We expect to pick up the pace in our Permian completions during the remainder of the year.
We also reported a modest increase in our 2016 capital budget. This is the result of the completions of our East Cana-Woodford infill program being pushed forward from 2017 into 2016; the application is bigger, more effective stimulations across the board; and greater-than-anticipated working interest in both our own wells and in partner-operated wells. With the results that we're seeing, we're delighted to have the increased exposure.
Since our last call, we've seen a bit of breathing room in commodity prices. As a result, were accelerating some of the Permian completion activity that was delayed due to the planned outages this winter. 
As you'll also hear during the call, our focus on science and innovation continues apace. We continue to experiment with more effective stimulations, primarily to the use of more proppant, more stages, tighter cluster spacing and more clusters per stage and the use of diverter technology. This down cycle and associated decrease in activity is providing an ideal environment to focus on science and technology. We're also taking advance of decreased service cost to experiment and improve our methodologies.
We've also made great strides in reducing our cost structure. The organization's undergoing a concerted effort to lower G&A through voluntary retirements that lead to headcount reductions, reducing contracted consultant services and optimizing work efficiencies, particularly in the field.
Finally, before I turn the call over to John, I'd like to comment on our thoughts as we look ahead. In 2015, we said that our challenge was to get our program to a point where it was sustainable, where we were living within cash flow and had a capital program and a cost structure that was appropriate for the new normal. In our last call, we told you that our challenge in 2016 was to preserve our assets, preserve our balance sheet and preserve organization. I am pleased to tell you that we are on track with both sets of goals. 
As we look ahead at the current strip, we model a Cimarex that lives within cash flow and is able to get back on a growth trajectory in the years ahead. We have best-in-class assets, and we will be able to preserve our prime leasehold in our current program. Our organization is effective, focused and hard at work generating new opportunities. Our balance sheet provides the flexibility and strength that will keep Cimarex at the forefront in a highly competitive landscape.
We don't know where commodity prices are headed, but we don't expect to return to the price levels of 2014 any time soon. Margins will be challenged, cost structures will be paramount and asset quality and organizational effectiveness will be the differentiator. It's always been a tough business, and things won't be any easier as we move ahead. Our focus is on performance and results. Although further price recovery would be warmly welcomed, we are in great shape and look ahead with conviction that our value creation proposition is alive and well.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to John to provide further color on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $158 million on exploration and development during the
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our 2016 plans. 
Cimarex invested $158 million on exploration and development during the first quarter. About 55% was invested in the Permian region, with the rest going toward activities in Mid-Continent region. Company-wide, we brought 22 gross, 5 net, wells on production during the first quarter. 
Despite the small number of wells completed during the quarter, Cimarex had an average of 10 operated rigs running during the quarter. These rigs were busy finishing the drilling of infill wells in the Woodford Shale, as well as drilling spacing pilots in both the Delaware basin and the Mid-Continent. That activity is winding down and majority of our contracted drilling rates will be rolling off by July. By August, we plan to be down to 3 operated rigs. 
In the Delaware basin, you may recall that we spudded downspacing pilot in the upper Wolfcamp in Culberson County in the fourth quarter 2015. We are finished with the drilling portion of these wells and completions are scheduled to begin in mid-May. First production is now expected by midyear. This 6-well, 7,500 foot lateral pilot will test 2 different spacing designs, one at 8 wells per section, while the other will test 6 wells per section, both will be drilled in a staggered pattern.
Cimarex continues to push the envelope on well completions. On Page 12 of our presentation, we've shown you the uplift using a 40% larger completion on these upper Wolfcamp wells, which equates to 1,640 pounds of sand per foot. We're about to take that a step further on using even larger design to complete this 6-well pilot. Incorporating 2,500 pounds of sand per lateral foot, these pilot wells will have 44% more sand pumped than the largest completed wells we've had to date, as shown on Page 12.
We are currently drilling also our lower Wolfcamp infill project, which we call Tim Tam. This 10,000-foot spacing pilot is comprised of 5 wells, which will be drilled in a stacked/staggered pattern, testing 6 wells per section. We believe the success we've had with larger completions in the upper Wolfcamp should easily translate to that lower Wolfcamp. By way of example, Page 13 in our presentation illustrates the uplift we've seen with a larger completion on a 10,000-foot upper Wolfcamp well. 
We have also just finished operations on our largest lower Wolfcamp completion to date, a well we call the Flying Ebony, where we pumped 2,400 pounds of sand per foot. The production data from this well, along with the larger completions we are doing with the upper Wolfcamp, will provide us critical data for design of future completions, including the Tim Tam wells, which are scheduled to be completed in the second half of 2016.
For the remainder of 2016, the vast majority of the capital that we will spend in the Permian will be earmarked for acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. The total capital ascribed to acreage holding in the Delaware basin is just over $200 million in 2016. Part of this obligation drilling will include 6 2 mile-long infill wells in Reeves County, which recently commenced drilling. Similar to our Anaconda pilot, these wells will be drilled using a stacked/staggered pattern, resulting in equivalent of 12 wells per section. Once drilling is completed on this section, we will be down to 2 operating rigs in the Permian for the remainder of the year.
Now on to the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling the latest Woodford development project on the east side of the Cana core in the fourth quarter of 2015. This development covers 6 sections, of which Cimarex operates 2 sections. Due to some last-minute changes in working interest, this infill project now consists of 47 gross, 22 net, wells. Drilling is nearly finished, and completion of these wells have been moved up, and is now scheduled for early October versus the first quarter 2017. This change in scheduling was a contributing factor in our $50 million increase in capital expenditures for 2016.
In our emerging Meramec play, we now have production data on 18 operated 5,000-foot laterals. Also, our third 10,000-foot wells in the Meramec has been in production since early January. Located in Blaine County, this well called the Dakota Carol 1H-2722X, had a 30-day peak IP rate of 10.8 million cubic feet equivalent per day, including 951 barrels of oil per day. That results in a condensate yield of around 278 barrels per million. 
Page 21 of the presentation illustrates the average uplift we've seen from the 3 long laterals in the Meramec versus the 5,000-foot laterals drilled to date. They have outperformed the shorter laterals by 62%, with an up by 120 days. While we are very encouraged by the initial uplift in IP that we are seeing in these 10,000-foot laterals, we continue to carefully monitor the decline profile in order to determine the ultimate EURs for these long laterals.
To better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have designed a downspacing pilot, which commenced drilling in the fourth quarter 2015, and has just finished the drilling phase. See Slide 22 for an illustration of the design. The 8 new wells will be stacked and staggered in both the Meramec at Woodford formations. The spacing in the Meramec would be the equivalent on a 10 wells per section, made up of 5 upper and 5 lower staggered Meramec wells. The Woodford will be drilled with our standard 9 wells per section development plan. 
Another Meramec spacing pilot operated by our partner, Devon, was recently completed and is in the early stages of flowback. The results from this 5 wells per section pilot will strongly influence our completion plans for the stacked/staggered pilot. 
Once drilling is finished on infill sections, we'll be focused on holding our Meramec acreage. As you know, in late 2014, we added 12,250 net acres in the Meramec at an average cost of $1,650 per acre. About $70 million of our capital is being invested in holding Meramec acreage in 2016. We currently have 4 rigs operating in the Cana [ph] region, with plans to be down to 1 operated rig by July of this year.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll hit on the usual items: Our first quarter production, our Q2 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll follow-up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. As To
componenttext:
Well, thank you, John, and thank you all for joining us on our call today. I'll hit on the usual items: Our first quarter production, our Q2 and full year 2016 production outlook and then I'll follow-up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. 
As Tom mentioned, with the help of stronger-than-expected base property and new well performance, our first quarter volumes came in slightly better than anticipated. Our reported total company net equivalent production of 973 million a day beat our guidance projection at 925 million to 955 million a day, and was up 3% from the 947 million a day that we posted in Q1 '15. As expected, facility disruptions and processing constraints in the Permian did negatively impact our Q1 production to the tune of approximately 30 million a day.
Our first quarter equivalent Permian production came in at 477 million a day, down 43 million a day from Q4 '15. The decrease was expected and came as primarily a result of the facility downtime I just mentioned, as well as us completing 3 net Permian wells in Q1 as compared to 8 wells in the fourth quarter of '15.
With our Cana-Woodford wells coming online in late Q4, we did anticipate a nice Mid-Continent post gain during Q1, and we saw just that. With the wells exceeding our plan expectations, our Mid-Content volumes came in 493 million a day, that's up 7% from the 461 million a day we reported in the fourth quarter and 11% from the 444 million a day that we posted a year ago in Q1 '15.
As we look forward into the remainder of this year, we've made a few changes to our completion schedule, including the addition of a frac crew in the Permian to help catch up on deferred completions from the downstream disruptions in Q1, and by advancing, as John mentioned, the timing of our Cana to drilled completions to October this year.
With our stronger-than-expected Q1 results and these completion timing adjustments, we've increased our full year total company equivalent production guidance to 940 million to 970 million a day, up about, in midpoint basis, 45 million a day, from our beginning-year guidance of 890 million to 930 million. 
As compared to the original guidance, the acceleration of our Cana infill project resulted in a significant decrease in the number of drilled but uncompleted wells on our books at the end of the year. Our current model now projects 32 gross and 9 net Mid-Continent wells waiting on completion at year end. That compares to the 57 gross and 24 net wells that we anticipated we'd have awaiting completion earlier this year, when we issued our beginning-year guidance. 
The acceleration not only boosts our 2016 total company guidance, but it increases our projected 2016 exit rate as well. With our new modeling, we now project our total company fourth quarter exit rate this year to be right in line with that of the 986 million a day that we posted back in the fourth quarter of '15.
In the Permian, the Q1 facility downtime and processing constraints resulted in us deferring absolutely 3 net completions into the latter part of this year. With the processing constraints anticipated to now be behind us, our plans are to add a second completion crew to help catch up and. That will be here in May and end early June. And with the projected 2 rigs working the latter part of the year as John mentioned, we're still forecasting approximately 50 gross and 30 net Permian wells to come online in 2016. That's flat with our previous estimates, but we just really accelerated the pace here into Q2 and Q3. So as a result, our protected number of Permian drilled and uncompleted wells will, in essence, drop fairly quickly here: From 34 gross to -- and 21 net wells here in May to 10 gross and 9 net on the books by year-end.
For Q2 '16, our projected guidance of 935 million to 965 million a day reflects a drop in production from Q1 '16 levels, primarily as we await the scheduled Permian and Cana completion activity, which is planned for Q3 and Q4. And to help you -- provide you with some clarity on projected completion timing through the year, we completed 5 net wells in Q1. We're forecasting approximately 13 net wells to be completed in Q2, with approximately 44 net wells projected to come online in Q3 and Q4. So you can see that this is in the latter quarters as far as our completion activity is concerned.
Shifting gears to OpEx. Our production group continued to make great strides during Q1 to further reduce our operating cost. Through their efforts, we realized additional and sizable cost reductions in items, such as saltwater disposal, compression, rentals and contract labor. As a result, our Q1 '16 lifting cost came in at $0.80 per Mcfe, that was at the low end of our guidance, which was $0.80 to $0.90 per Mcfe, down 6.3% from our fourth quarter average of $0.85 and down 17% from the $0.96 we posted for the average in the first quarter of '15.
With our cost control efforts, we're projecting our 2016 lifting cost to continue to fall in the range of $0.80 to $0.90. I'd say we'll most likely be in the lower end of that range as we finish up the year. We're extremely proud of the efforts that our ops team has put forth to reduce our cost structure, all the while maintaining safe and efficient operations. 
Tom touched on this, not only is doing so, so critical for us to be able to compete in this low product price environment, but our reduced OpEx is also freeing up capital for our drilling program, making us a more efficient operator. 
Since prices began falling back in 2014, on an absolute basis, we've seen our total company monthly net operating expense drop about $5 million per month, which annualized, equates to an additional $60 million that we can direct to our drilling program.
And finally, a few comments on drilling and completion cost. Although most drilling cost components remained somewhat in check during Q1, we were able to realize some modest reductions in service cost on the completion side primarily in the Permian. On the drilling side, we're keeping our focus on efficiencies, as seen with our Q1 average Wolfcamp spread to rig release drill time now down to 28 days as compared to 35 days in 2014.
On the completion side, in addition to the modest service cost reductions I mentioned, mostly in the Permian, we placed a strong emphasis on reducing a lot of sourcing cost by challenging our team in their planning, engineering and operating efficiencies in that regard. The results of our efforts are just now beginning to make their way into our total well cost.
As we continue to push the limit on our frac design and size, our completion cost will continue to dominate our total well cost, while we experiment with larger frac designs many of our generic well AFEs still have stayed somewhat in check. An exception is the Wolfcamp, where both our drilling and completion efficiencies have reduced our generic 2-mile lateral Culberson and lower Wolfcamp AFE to a range of $10.2 million to $11.2 million, that's down 5% from the $10.8 million to $11.6 million range that we quoted last fall, and down 22% from where we were in late 2014. 
With last quarter's frac design, our Cana core 1-mile lateral wells continue to run in the range of $6.6 million to $7 million, unchanged from the last call and down 16% to 17% from 2014. But with the larger frac designs that we're contemplating to be utilized here in Q3 '16, this range is likely to increase anywhere in the range of $500,000 to $600,000 per well. 
And in the Meramec, our current 1-mile lateral AFE is still in the range of $7 million to $7.4 million. Again, that is unchanged from last call and down 13% from late '14. And also here, if we employ larger fracs moving forward, we could see an additional $500,000 to $600,000 in these AFEs as well.
So in closing, we had another great quarter. We beat guidance despite a sizable downstream and weather disruptions. We've made significant strides further reducing our LOE. Our drilling and completion group remains focused on cost efficiencies -- reductions and efficiencies and optimizing the results of our fracs. Our teams are tightly focused on maximizing the productivity and profitability of our wells. All the while, we're optimizing our investment program results.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Q&A.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: My first question is on Slide 11, on the Culberson County Wolfcamp 10,000-foot laterals, the before-tax IRR changed -- moved higher significantly since your last update on this particular slide. Now just curious, what was driving that significant change?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. There are several factors in there, but the biggest driver is just an improvement in our type curve or expectation going forward, and that's really related to the -- continually to increase our frac design on these wells. We have 3 well
componenttext: Yes, this is John. There are several factors in there, but the biggest driver is just an improvement in our type curve or expectation going forward, and that's really related to the -- continually to increase our frac design on these wells. We have 3 wells now with this current design, which I talked about earlier, at the 1,640 pounds per foot. And those wells have been on long enough now that what's really impressing us is the, quite frankly, lack of decline. These wells come on and they tend to have a very long, flat period to them. And we have enough time with those now that we gain confidence in that type curve, and that's led to a major change in our expectation for these wells going forward. I should also point out that as Joe mentioned, we actually have, also in addition to that, seen some cost reduction in those wells. So with all that factored together, that's led to the improvement you're seeing there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then my follow-up, in this growth out of Slide #20 in your presentation on the Meramec, that looks like you had some new well results there on the 5,000-foot lateral and then also the 10,000-foot lateral. It looked like they were slightly w
componenttext: Excellent. And then my follow-up, in this growth out of Slide #20 in your presentation on the Meramec, that looks like you had some new well results there on the 5,000-foot lateral and then also the 10,000-foot lateral. It looked like they were slightly weaker than some prior ones now that may have a had a bit of a higher oil cut. Just want to get some color on those recent well results in the Meramec.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John again. Well, first thing I would say is this is still an emerging play, and for us, we're still out there and doing both a combination of holding acreage, delineating acreage and testing frac design. And so it's fair to say that some of
componenttext: Yes, this is John again. Well, first thing I would say is this is still an emerging play, and for us, we're still out there and doing both a combination of holding acreage, delineating acreage and testing frac design. And so it's fair to say that some of the wells come in much better than expected and some come in less. We're still learning a lot in regards to these wells and there's still a lot that we think we can change or improve upon to make these wells even better. So yes, there's some variability there, especially, I would point out, yes, with our 10,000-foot lateral we just announced. It's also -- well, I want to point out that we anticipated having a much higher yield than our previous 2 10,000-foot laterals. And so in that case, we did not flow it back as aggressively from a choke management standpoint. We were interested -- and with this one particular, in seeing with choke management, how we can manage that yield. So for that well in particular, I don't know that the 30-day rate well -- 30-day rate is as important to us as, say, the 90- or 180-day rate in terms of the way we're flowing that well back.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could speak to whether you can apply the same techniques you've used in the Wolfcamp A recently to the Wolfcamp D. And I know you said you're testing that with at least 1 well already, but does it have broader applications?
componenttext: I was hoping you could speak to whether you can apply the same techniques you've used in the Wolfcamp A recently to the Wolfcamp D. And I know you said you're testing that with at least 1 well already, but does it have broader applications?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. We are very encouraged by what we're seeing coming out of the upper Wolfcamp, the A wells, with this continuation of improving the frac design. And that's why we, indeed, went into our most current 10,000-foot lateral in the lower Wolfc
componenttext: Yes. This is John. We are very encouraged by what we're seeing coming out of the upper Wolfcamp, the A wells, with this continuation of improving the frac design. And that's why we, indeed, went into our most current 10,000-foot lateral in the lower Wolfcamp, Flying Ebony, to apply that design to it. It's just now an early flowback. We all have very high expectations for that well, but we also recognize that not any one well makes a trend just yet. But yes, going forward, we're very encouraged. And let me be also clear, we're not sure that we've really even reached even close to the end number in terms of these frac uplifts. So that's why, for the Upper Wolfcamp spacing pilot, even though we don't have a well under our belt, we're very comfortable stepping up in the total amount of sand that we're going to pump in those wells. Because the way we model it, with a modest increase in IP and EUR, it's a very economic thing to do. So we're very pleased with the progress we're seeing here. And -- but we still think there's a lot more to gain.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes Drew, this is Tom. I want to follow up on that. We're very excited by the Wolfcamp A, and certainly, the results and the uplift we reported is real and it's grounded in actual results. We'd probably see the Wolfcamp A as being a better target overall
componenttext: Yes Drew, this is Tom. I want to follow up on that. We're very excited by the Wolfcamp A, and certainly, the results and the uplift we reported is real and it's grounded in actual results. We'd probably see the Wolfcamp A as being a better target overall than the Wolfcamp D, but the Wolfcamp D is also outstanding. I mean, so it's a question of great and outstanding. But one of the things I want to follow up on is -- one of the things that makes Cimarex strong is our presence in multiple plays, and in particular, with our footprint in the Delaware Basin and our footprint in STACK, we're doing a lot of innovation, as are our competitors. And every time we see something that works, we look for opportunities to apply it elsewhere in our portfolio. So having that footprint in multiple plays allows us to really bring innovations in much more quickly than we could if we were a single-basin player. So there are -- as John said, we have a lot of running room in completion optimization in both the Wolfcamp A, the Wolfcamp D and I would add, in STACK, both in the Meramec and Woodford. All of those plays are trying some things in that laboratory, gives us ideas to apply across the board. I don't know that we're even scratching the surface yet in a lot of areas. And we're very, very excited about the advancements we're reporting, but we have tremendous uplift yet to happen. And so it's pretty exciting right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so just a follow-up on that, the results, obviously, look great in the Wolfcamp A. I know it's been less tested in Culberson because the returns, I think, for Wolfcamp D had looked so good and you can hold the acreage by drilling down to the D. But ca
componenttext: And so just a follow-up on that, the results, obviously, look great in the Wolfcamp A. I know it's been less tested in Culberson because the returns, I think, for Wolfcamp D had looked so good and you can hold the acreage by drilling down to the D. But can you give us a sense, a better sense of how delineated the Wolfcamp A is across your acreage position?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. It's not near as well delineated as it is for the D, that's a fair -- a very fair statement. The majority of our A drilling to date has been -- has mainly putting Culberson down in the southeast part, that's where we really recognize it
componenttext: Yes. This is John. It's not near as well delineated as it is for the D, that's a fair -- a very fair statement. The majority of our A drilling to date has been -- has mainly putting Culberson down in the southeast part, that's where we really recognize it, and from the way we map it. But I will also tell you that we are now stepping out into other areas of Culberson. And I am hoping, in a future earning release, to talk more about those efforts. But so far, it's been relegated more to a much more smaller area in the southeast in the D. But that's just, as you mentioned early on, we were drilling Ds in a way to hold our acreage and hold all our rights. With the As, we've been a little bit more selective. But now, with these encouraging results we're seeing, we are quickly stepping out into other areas of our acreage to get a sense of just how good this could be across the whole position.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, there's tremendous future opportunity to test new zones and same zone elsewhere in our acreage, not only within Culberson and Eddy County. So we have a lot of work ahead of us, and it's definitely pointing us to get more and more excited about that
componenttext: Drew, there's tremendous future opportunity to test new zones and same zone elsewhere in our acreage, not only within Culberson and Eddy County. So we have a lot of work ahead of us, and it's definitely pointing us to get more and more excited about that asset.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Will Derrick of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess first question, looking over in the Meramec and the Cana-Woodford, on the completion time and moving it up to October, what's your expectation on when those wells are all going to come online?
componenttext: I guess first question, looking over in the Meramec and the Cana-Woodford, on the completion time and moving it up to October, what's your expectation on when those wells are all going to come online?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. We're going to start to see the beginnings of that production late Q4 and into early Q1. We filled the wells back to clean up, and just the timing of the complete row of activity is such that it'll end up pretty close to what happened this ye
componenttext: This is Joe. We're going to start to see the beginnings of that production late Q4 and into early Q1. We filled the wells back to clean up, and just the timing of the complete row of activity is such that it'll end up pretty close to what happened this year, with row 4 carrying into not only Q4 but into Q1 of this year. I think we'll see the same thing next.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also up there, in terms of the completion designs that you all are looking at. How does that differ from what you've seen in the past? Are using the higher-intensity completions you've seen -- you've done recently? What are your thoughts th
componenttext: Okay. And then also up there, in terms of the completion designs that you all are looking at. How does that differ from what you've seen in the past? Are using the higher-intensity completions you've seen -- you've done recently? What are your thoughts there?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. I think you're referring to our Woodford development wells, correct?
componenttext: Yes. This is John. I think you're referring to our Woodford development wells, correct?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sir. Yes.
componenttext: Yes, sir. Yes.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- on our previous row, row 4, we did quite a bit of experimentation with the frac design there. And then in fact in one case, one section in particular, we pumped upwards of 3,200 pounds per foot. That section and those wells are outstanding. I m
componenttext: Yes. We -- on our previous row, row 4, we did quite a bit of experimentation with the frac design there. And then in fact in one case, one section in particular, we pumped upwards of 3,200 pounds per foot. That section and those wells are outstanding. I mean, we are just really impressed with the results coming off of that section. And so going forward into this new row development, our base case, and I think Joe alluded to that, why we're anticipating the additional cost, is to go up to that size of a frac job in the Woodford shale at 3,200 pounds per foot. Whereas before, standard was more around 1,800 pounds per foot. Again, there is cost there associated with it, but based on the performance we're seeing on those wells, it's well worth the additional cost to do that. So that's our go-forward plan there for that next row development.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I was wondering if you could perhaps give us some more details on the stack/staggered pilot that you're doing in the Meramec, in particular, I just wanted to see if you could comment maybe on where your completions have been lending today. And just y
componenttext: Tom, I was wondering if you could perhaps give us some more details on the stack/staggered pilot that you're doing in the Meramec, in particular, I just wanted to see if you could comment maybe on where your completions have been lending today. And just your general thoughts around this pilot coming up.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll answer your question, and then I'll turn it over to John, he'll have some additions. Landing zone is a real point of experimentation in the Meramec. In the early wells for Cimarex and for many of our competitors, it was quite frankly, a monkey
componenttext: Well, I'll answer your question, and then I'll turn it over to John, he'll have some additions. Landing zone is a real point of experimentation in the Meramec. In the early wells for Cimarex and for many of our competitors, it was quite frankly, a monkey see, monkey do approach. The Meramec wasn't the most obvious reservoir. And so early wells were kind of targeted based on mimicking what offset wells had done. And as we've continued to delineate the play, Cimarex and the industry has tested different landing zones. We're testing 2 different landing zones in that Meramec stacked/staggered pilot, and we continue to experiment with landing zones throughout the play. We're seeing landing zone to be a overprint on production that's greater than we initially anticipated. There are some areas of the play that have underperformed that we're going back in now and you're testing new landing zones, new completion techniques, and we're quite encouraged by the potential there. But it's a real open part of experimentation as to where to land these laterals. John, you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is that for that particular spacing pilot, we went the extra step, where we went ahead and drilled what we would call pilot hole to get additional log information to really refine where to put those laterals in the Meramec. And
componenttext: The only thing I would add is that for that particular spacing pilot, we went the extra step, where we went ahead and drilled what we would call pilot hole to get additional log information to really refine where to put those laterals in the Meramec. And I must tell you, I feel pretty good about how we've done this for this particular stacked/staggered pilot in regards to the data we received from that pilot what really helped us pinpoint exactly where we want to put these letters. Whereas before, Tom's absolutely right, we would have looked just say, 2 sections over, and see what did company X, Y, Z do as far as where they landed it. I think we're recognizing that for the Meramec, I mean, every section might have just a slight different tweak to where you want to put that lateral to achieve maximum performance. And that's some of the lessons we're learning as we go forward. So I'm very excited about the stacked/staggered pilot, and I'm looking forward to when we finally get around to completing it. But as I mentioned, we do have a strong interest in the other operated pilot that is just flowing back now. And there was a lot of science associated with that pilot, and we're very anxious to kind of see the flowback, review the science data. And that's why we're not in any rush to go out and frac our current stacked/staggered till we see some of those results and see how we might then tailor our fracture design for the -- for our pilot.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just my follow-up, you drilled and completed some wells on the up-dip portion of your acreage, on the down-dip. Any takeaways or conclusions around well performance on the up-dip or down-dip? Pretty similar?
componenttext: Great. And just my follow-up, you drilled and completed some wells on the up-dip portion of your acreage, on the down-dip. Any takeaways or conclusions around well performance on the up-dip or down-dip? Pretty similar?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: This is John. I think you're referring to Meramec wells or Mississippi [ph] wells?
