componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess I need to just adopt the STACK vernacular, I guess. Yes, we have. Again, delineation wells, sometimes, the results were not as we were hoping. Other times, they're outstanding. So it's kind of what you expect early on in a play like this, where every now and then, you hit a home run; and then now and then, you hit one that's not so good. It didn't really -- it's the ones that don't quite meet our expectation that we really, really spend a lot of time on saying, "Okay, what could be have done differently? Where could we have landed differently? How do we make it better?" And so yes, I'd still think there's a lot of improvement still to come in this play based on what I've seen so far.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. Cimarex, I think, speaks a little differently than some other companies about the Meramec. I would say, first and foremost, we're very excited about the Meramec. We have a program that is, in our estimation, top tier. We study our wells, we stu
componenttext: Yes, Arun. Cimarex, I think, speaks a little differently than some other companies about the Meramec. I would say, first and foremost, we're very excited about the Meramec. We have a program that is, in our estimation, top tier. We study our wells, we study our competitors' wells, and we think our results are in the upper class. And we have a lot of data to back that statement up. That said, we do see a fair amount of reservoir variability through the play. We don't view the Meramec as a blanket play. We see a fair amount of variability, and that's why John talked about the importance of having pilot holes when we target our laterals. The landing zones can change in short order, the yield can change in short order, and the well performance can change. Now we're fairly confident, based on the work we're doing, that all of, if not most of, those are solvable, solvable with completion techniques, solvable with smart application of your landing zone, but it's an evolving story. And as we always have done, we're going to talk about results, and our results stand on their own. They're quite good.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey of Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Focusing on Reeves County, can you update us of the cumulative production and days online for the Big Timber? And then whether or not you think the strong result's repeatable? And I guess a few comments on how the upper Wolfcamp in this area stacks up to
componenttext: Focusing on Reeves County, can you update us of the cumulative production and days online for the Big Timber? And then whether or not you think the strong result's repeatable? And I guess a few comments on how the upper Wolfcamp in this area stacks up to other Delaware Basin assets that are in your portfolio.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is John. I don't have the Big Timber production in front of me right now. We can probably get that information back to you. What I do know is, based on that well result, as well as some other competitor wells in the area, we feel really, really
componenttext: Yes, this is John. I don't have the Big Timber production in front of me right now. We can probably get that information back to you. What I do know is, based on that well result, as well as some other competitor wells in the area, we feel really, really good about that acreage over there from a 10,000-foot lateral standpoint. So good, as I mentioned in my comments, that we are moving forward with the development plans that we're doing in Reeves County with the 10,000-foot stacked/staggered development that will initiate -- in fact, have started drilling on right now. It's a very good area for the Upper Wolfcamp. And I think our Anaconda pilots really demonstrated to us that it's not just a good area, it's thick enough to support multiple levels of wells in that shale. So going forward, we're very, very excited about that area and the results we'll get, especially from this development that we're currently drilling right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, as it competes for capital in other areas in your Delaware Basin program, I guess, assuming commodity price, assuming the strip currently isn't competitive with other assets in your portfolio, do you have any constraints, such as infrastructure,
componenttext: I guess, as it competes for capital in other areas in your Delaware Basin program, I guess, assuming commodity price, assuming the strip currently isn't competitive with other assets in your portfolio, do you have any constraints, such as infrastructure, that may limit future development as you head into 2017?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take a stab at that. It competes very well with the other things that we have in our portfolio. The thing that's driving a lot of our capital this year, as we've mentioned, is acreage holding. And in particular, in Reeves, we have a lot of acre
componenttext: Sure. I'll take a stab at that. It competes very well with the other things that we have in our portfolio. The thing that's driving a lot of our capital this year, as we've mentioned, is acreage holding. And in particular, in Reeves, we have a lot of acreage there that's still on a primary term that we definitely want to hold, so there is quite a bit of capital going that way. It is fair to say that once we get to a point where we have excess capital beyond holding acreage, then we'd have look. And any time we make those decisions, then it's factors such as, yes, always rate of return and takeaway issues and water sourcing, as Joe mentioned, and other factors that lead to where we deploy that capital. But in terms of optional capital spending, Reeves holds its own pretty well compared to Culberson right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, one of the things that drives that isn't just the rocks, but it's also our ability to drill that longer lateral. And so one of the things that makes Culberson such a beautiful asset for us, not only is it multiple zone, some of which we haven't
componenttext: Yes, Dan, one of the things that drives that isn't just the rocks, but it's also our ability to drill that longer lateral. And so one of the things that makes Culberson such a beautiful asset for us, not only is it multiple zone, some of which we haven't even tested yet, but we can drill long laterals at will, there's no constraint there over that entire acreage block. That's generally true in Reeves, but there are areas where that's not true. And what Cimarex is doing and a lot of operators are focused on, I think, theres widespread recognition of the economic uplift to these longer wells. And so there's some trades going on to let us block up that area and be in a better place to drill long laterals. But as far as the rock goes, it's highly competitive with other things we've got.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Smith of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Smith of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to take that net prior question on capital allocation maybe a step further and just thinking about the portfolio as a whole, now that you've drilled more wells in the Meramec and are getting more confident in your upper Wolfcamp wells, I'm not going to
componenttext: So to take that net prior question on capital allocation maybe a step further and just thinking about the portfolio as a whole, now that you've drilled more wells in the Meramec and are getting more confident in your upper Wolfcamp wells, I'm not going to ask you Tom, when you're got to go back to work, but just getting -- just a question around where that first incremental dollar goes when you do go back to work.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm back to work, Jason.
componenttext: I'm back to work, Jason.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible]
componenttext: [indiscernible]

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I should have worded that one a little better.
componenttext: I should have worded that one a little better.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the challenge is, it's a really evolving story. And if we had a snapshot of today, and we said, you know what, based on what we know today, we have to make long-term capital-allocation decisions, there would probably be a bias to a lot of our D
componenttext: Yes. Well, the challenge is, it's a really evolving story. And if we had a snapshot of today, and we said, you know what, based on what we know today, we have to make long-term capital-allocation decisions, there would probably be a bias to a lot of our Delaware program. Not only the Bone Spring, but the Avalon looks quite good. And these long wells in the Wolfcamp, those are all cream of the crop. But we are still seeing, not only the Meramec, but I would still throw Woodford in the mix, that with our experiments we're doing with our completion innovations, we're seeing a really improving story there. And so we're going to -- in the near term, we're going to continue to experiment. And we want to have an active program in both basins because what we learn is setting the stage for long-term capital allocation. I mean, you've heard us talk about in the Woodford, we have some projects that would be STACK, Meramec and Woodford, that once we kick them off, they are hundreds of 10,000-foot long wells. I mean, it's a real opportunity for Cimarex. So we're not just going to snapshot today, it's evolving story.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Joe. I will just follow up, especially in today's market, to what Tom said. Completion costs are really, surprisingly enough to me, theyve gotten a little softer on the service cost side. But as an example, to just take our total company f
componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. I will just follow up, especially in today's market, to what Tom said. Completion costs are really, surprisingly enough to me, theyve gotten a little softer on the service cost side. But as an example, to just take our total company frac stats, now is the time to try this experimentation. Our early 2016 average frac statistics compared to our 2015 average are such that we're drilling, we're completing 11% longer laterals, pumping 23% more fluid, 30% more sand. And when you look at an all-in cost reduction per well, including water sourcing, we're seeing a reduction of 5% in our completion cost, even with those increases. So now is the time to try those experiments.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. And just one quick one on the Avalon. A few of your peers have talked about it this quarter. I think that it's held by production for you guys. I mean, any change in your thoughts around allocating some capital there? Doing any further tes
componenttext: Got it. Got it. And just one quick one on the Avalon. A few of your peers have talked about it this quarter. I think that it's held by production for you guys. I mean, any change in your thoughts around allocating some capital there? Doing any further tests in that zone?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Actually, I think about 2 days ago, I was in Midland and reviewed our latest Avalon well with our latest generation of frac design, and it's fantastic. It's a great well. And the challenge, again, as you mentioned is it's all held by product
componenttext: This is John. Actually, I think about 2 days ago, I was in Midland and reviewed our latest Avalon well with our latest generation of frac design, and it's fantastic. It's a great well. And the challenge, again, as you mentioned is it's all held by production. And so right now, we'd much rather spend that capital to hold the rest of our acreage position throughout the Wolfcamp. But I got to tell you, I've got a team down there that's just itching to go on a 2-mile lateral in Avalon, and the numbers look great. But it's just a matter of capital allocation right now, where we think, obviously, our best interest is to go out there and deploy that capital, hold our acreage for this year. But they're raring to go. And at some point, especially since we've already got a number of the spacing pilots done, where we're already at 8 wells per section on each interval within the Avalon, there are several benches, so it looks really good. It's just a question of when we get to a point where, I guess, as someone said, we get back to work and we start drilling some more wells up there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeanine Wai of Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeanine Wai of Citigroup.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the fourth quarter call, you all provided us with your estimated year-end '16 cash balance of, I think it was $400 million. And with a $50 million CapEx increase that you announced last night, what's your new estimated cash balance at year-end '16?
componenttext: So on the fourth quarter call, you all provided us with your estimated year-end '16 cash balance of, I think it was $400 million. And with a $50 million CapEx increase that you announced last night, what's your new estimated cash balance at year-end '16? And realizing that the strip has moved up in the meantime?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark here. And yes, using a early May, May 2, strip price with that incremental capital and our new volume forecast, we're still -- we're expecting -- actually, it's gone up a bit from $400 million to maybe $450 million, is the way it looks right
componenttext: This is Mark here. And yes, using a early May, May 2, strip price with that incremental capital and our new volume forecast, we're still -- we're expecting -- actually, it's gone up a bit from $400 million to maybe $450 million, is the way it looks right now, Jeanine. So it's something we're closely watching and seeing how that moves through the year, but even with the increased capital, we expect that cash balance to be even a bit higher than we had previously forecasted.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jeanine, I want to give just a little bit of detail on that CapEx increase. On our fourth quarter call, we were in the range of $600 million to $650 million, and we said the upper end of that, $650 million, would be if those completions rolled into 20
componenttext: And Jeanine, I want to give just a little bit of detail on that CapEx increase. On our fourth quarter call, we were in the range of $600 million to $650 million, and we said the upper end of that, $650 million, would be if those completions rolled into 2016. So those completions have rolled into 2016, so if we wanted to benchmark us against the fourth quarter, we'd be at that $650 million number we talked about. Now we gave a range of guidance of $650 million to $700 million, so really, we kind of feel with the midpoint, midpoint is $675 million. So really, it's a $25 million increase over where we were in our fourth quarter call, given that those completions are accelerated. So although it looks like $50 million, I think that's probably just an absolute upper end of that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great, and that's really helpful. My follow-up, so it sounds like you have more cash, slightly more cash than you've previously thought and you're finding more ways to spend your cash flow. So what are the next opportunities you have to spend more C
componenttext: Okay. Great, and that's really helpful. My follow-up, so it sounds like you have more cash, slightly more cash than you've previously thought and you're finding more ways to spend your cash flow. So what are the next opportunities you have to spend more CapEx on if you spend any more at all?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take that. This is Tom. We've got lots to do. And certainly, we have a lot of projects that are begging for capital in the Delaware Basin, and these are -- as John said, the list is long and long and long. And then this Meramec delineation prob
componenttext: Well, I'll take that. This is Tom. We've got lots to do. And certainly, we have a lot of projects that are begging for capital in the Delaware Basin, and these are -- as John said, the list is long and long and long. And then this Meramec delineation probably is one that wed easily be able to throw a little capital at. And then we're also -- we talked in the past about we're doing some exploration. I mean, this is the time when we're kind of keying on what our organization does best, and our value proposition has always been centered around doing good geoscience, finding ideas to give us a competitive advantage and getting acreage positions ahead of the crowd. And so we're putting a lot of emphasis on that as well, and there will be some opportunities that come out of that. So depending on what the landscape looks like over the next 6 months, I think there's a reasonable chance that we may do a little more. We're going to need to see the fundamentals shore up, we're going to need to have confidence that this price file is supportable, but we are ready to roll with cash in the balance sheet to do it.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me follow up a little on that while we're on the topic. Just bigger picture, as I think about capital allocation as a cycle, what's your perspective on outspending cash flow? You mentioned earlier in the remarks that you think within cash flow on the
componenttext: Let me follow up a little on that while we're on the topic. Just bigger picture, as I think about capital allocation as a cycle, what's your perspective on outspending cash flow? You mentioned earlier in the remarks that you think within cash flow on the strip, you can get back to growth in the years ahead. Appreciate that, certainly, but we'll end the year with a substantial amount of cash on hand, already, a very differentiated balance sheet. And just thinking, through this -- where we are in the cycle, you've got productivity trending up and to the right, costs are at cyclical lows. How do you think about outspending cash flow? And as we move further forward in 2017, given the current environment, is that something you'd be more likely to do than at other points in the cycle?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'll take that one. This is Tom. We are very willing to outspend cash flow. And the way I think about it is it's very simple, it's about creating value. If we can borrow money at a low interest rate, invest it in a high interest rate, I think as
componenttext: Michael, I'll take that one. This is Tom. We are very willing to outspend cash flow. And the way I think about it is it's very simple, it's about creating value. If we can borrow money at a low interest rate, invest it in a high interest rate, I think as long as we're confident in those returns, that's a value-creating proposition for our shareholder. And with our top tier assets, I think our bias as a management team is to bring that value forward for our shareholders. Now that said, when you drill a well, those returns are predicated on a discounted cash flow that's -- makes some significant assumptions about future commodity pricing. And the quality of that assumption is key. If we get to a point to where we gain confidence about that future commodity pricing, if we think that the markets have kind of worked themselves out and they're in balance -- and we get asked about at what price file? It's not about the price file. We have the opportunities today at this price file to accelerate and add value. It's about our confidence in that price file and that the markets are in balance and that we think that it's a fairly low-volatile proposition. So I think our bias is going to be to invest, use our balance sheet. And yes, we'd be willing to modestly outspend cash flow. Mark, you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I completely concur, Tom. It's gaining confidence in that future curve because that we'd seen -- kind of seeing, and thinking about increasing our activity, the current curve suggests that we have lots of economic wells to drill, but we've seen a
componenttext: Yes. No, I completely concur, Tom. It's gaining confidence in that future curve because that we'd seen -- kind of seeing, and thinking about increasing our activity, the current curve suggests that we have lots of economic wells to drill, but we've seen a couple of head fakes, seen a commodity price reverse. A lot of movement raises to date is probably been more driven on expectations of continued oil production and inventories improving, which we're starting to see, but we want to see more continuation of that and making sure that oil strip is really grounded in fact and based on clear fundamentals.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just say one last thing on that. We do an annual look-back, and many of you have heard of us talk about that in the past. And John and I spent 2 hours yesterday reviewing our annual look-back, going back on our history of economic performance. And th
componenttext: I'll just say one last thing on that. We do an annual look-back, and many of you have heard of us talk about that in the past. And John and I spent 2 hours yesterday reviewing our annual look-back, going back on our history of economic performance. And there are some real lessons there. And one of the lessons is, you really have to have confidence in that commodity price file. I mean, there's a lot of lessons in that, and it's about being good at the business, making sure you have high-quality assets and being very prudent in your investments. And I think Cimarex has a long history of success on that front, and we're going to continue to stay disciplined. We have a luxury of top-tier assets and outstanding returns in this current price environment, so we're going to be ready to roll. And I think you -- I think it's reasonable for you to expect, with a little stability in commodity pricing, you'll see Cimarex pick up the pace.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. It's very helpful. I guess my follow-up, stepping kind of way back again, high level. Just look at the Meramec today, and this might be a little tricky to answer, but just given every -- all the moving pieces in the world. But if yo
componenttext: Appreciate that color. It's very helpful. I guess my follow-up, stepping kind of way back again, high level. Just look at the Meramec today, and this might be a little tricky to answer, but just given every -- all the moving pieces in the world. But if you look at the Meramec today and you try to kind of compare that to the year of learning curve for the Wolfcamp and the Del Basin. And so looking back in time in the Delaware Basin and on the Wolfcamp, what year would you [indiscernible] in if we were to try and characterize the Meramec today? If that makes sense.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll -- this is John, and I guess I'll take a stab at that. It's interesting you asked that, I've been actually kind of going down memory lane and just recently talked with our lead generator for Culberson. I'd forgotten it, Culberson started 2006 f
componenttext: Well, I'll -- this is John, and I guess I'll take a stab at that. It's interesting you asked that, I've been actually kind of going down memory lane and just recently talked with our lead generator for Culberson. I'd forgotten it, Culberson started 2006 for us. So we're at year 10 in Culberson. And I'm going to tell you right now, we still don't know everything about Wolfcamp and Culberson, they're obvious by our well results and what we continue to do. Whereas we're in year 2 of Meramec, and I just think weve scratched the surface. There's just so much that we are learning with each well, both us and our competitors. And in some way, yes, it is happening at a far more accelerated pace than Culberson ever did because we were the only game in town when we were doing Culberson. Here, as you well are aware, we have at least 5 other operators drilling all around us, and we're all looking at each other trying to figure out what works best, where should I go? Where do I land? And so clearly, it's at a much more accelerated pace. But sometimes I wonder, maybe too fast, honestly, that you never really get a chance to really catch your breath and look at the data and look at the results. Not just that 30-day rate, as I mentioned, but what is the well doing 180 days later? And is it surprising you? And so I -- there -- sometimes I wish we went a little bit slower, to be honest, in Meramec. But in some ways, we're being forced to, just with the competition. So I don't know if that answers your question, but that's just my perspective on what's going on in the Meramec right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We saw the same -- this is Joe. We saw the same thing in Cana. We kicked off that program in 2007, and it's 2014 where our frac design revolutionizes the play. So that's a tough question. Where is the endgame on how well these wells can produce, is the re
componenttext: We saw the same -- this is Joe. We saw the same thing in Cana. We kicked off that program in 2007, and it's 2014 where our frac design revolutionizes the play. So that's a tough question. Where is the endgame on how well these wells can produce, is the real question here.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say a good segue into the question I had here, focusing in on the Meramec. Going back to the commentary on the landing zone and some of the variability, how do you address those challenges in the variability as you apply the downspacing test going for
componenttext: I'd say a good segue into the question I had here, focusing in on the Meramec. Going back to the commentary on the landing zone and some of the variability, how do you address those challenges in the variability as you apply the downspacing test going forward? Both the results from yours and Devon's across the broader acreage position.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. That's a great question, it's something that we talk about all the time. Part of it is sometimes, in some of the sections, we're blessed to have, quite frankly, quite a bit of vertical control within the section to give us an idea of what va
componenttext: This is John. That's a great question, it's something that we talk about all the time. Part of it is sometimes, in some of the sections, we're blessed to have, quite frankly, quite a bit of vertical control within the section to give us an idea of what variability we should expect. In other cases, quite frankly, we've reached the point we said we've just got to go ahead and drill and create that information by drilling a pilot hole. I would also tell you, in some ways, we're putting even more renewed emphasis on our 3D seismic coverage. Because at least with 3D seismic, you are sampling the geology, so to speak, in a much finer scale. So we're really, really trying to incorporate that as a tool to help us, along with the subsurface control and the horizontal wells that have been drilled to date, to build a more comprehensive model of what's going on and what we should expect going forward. I would just tell you that again, right now, we have expectations for every Meramec well we drill. And each one, in some ways, typically surprises us, fortunately to the positive, but also sometimes, in the negative. So as we go forward, we'll continue to look for ways to get more comfortable with that variability and be able to adjust to it appropriately.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe a follow-up here for Tom. Can you just talk about the current M&A outlook? And what you're seeing in both the Permian as well as in the Mid-Con?
componenttext: And then maybe a follow-up here for Tom. Can you just talk about the current M&A outlook? And what you're seeing in both the Permian as well as in the Mid-Con?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we see opportunities and we're always in the hunt. As we've talked in the past calls, there's not a point in time that where we're not evaluating something. Our challenge is we want to create value. And I think if you look at the history of M&A in E
componenttext: Well, we see opportunities and we're always in the hunt. As we've talked in the past calls, there's not a point in time that where we're not evaluating something. Our challenge is we want to create value. And I think if you look at the history of M&A in E&P and in other industries, it's a fairly challenging landscape for acquirers to make the argument that, over the long run, that's been a real good value-creating strategy. Now hey, maybe we count our money differently than others do, but we are who we are, and we want to be forthright in our approach to business. We look at full-cycle value creation. We look at time to capital. We look at what the pace of development will be and will that generate a rate of return for our shareholders. Some of these splashy acquisition deals are good for everybody that participates except for the shareholder. And our focus, first and foremost, is on shareholder value. So as I've said in the past, there are assets we covet. I mean there are some really outstanding assets on the market and some really outstanding assets that are transacted. And we've been in that game. And we often are at a valuation point where we are just flat out unwilling to get the number that's the winning bid. We ask ourselves at every turn, "What's our competitive advantage?" If we don't have a competitive advantage, and that's generally either information, science or ability to execute well above and beyond our competitors, then we're just bidding discount rate and commodity price forecast with a group of very well-funded competitors. And that's just not a winning proposition for the Cimarex shareholder. So we look. I'm very hopeful that there's going to be opportunities for us, and when we find the right one, we'll strike. But it'll be right because we had a competitive advantage.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Nelson of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Nelson of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've already belabored the reacceleration point, but if I could just ask, would it be reasonable to assume, the planned drop of rigs around midyear is probably a good catalyst for you to reevaluate if that commodity outlook has stabilized, rather than ri
componenttext: We've already belabored the reacceleration point, but if I could just ask, would it be reasonable to assume, the planned drop of rigs around midyear is probably a good catalyst for you to reevaluate if that commodity outlook has stabilized, rather than risk losing efficiencies gains -- efficiencies kind of with those rigs?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's reasonable. I mean, we're -- hey, we're not happy about going down to 4 then 3 rigs, but we're going to do what we need to do to preserve that balance sheet and make sure that we're well positioned for the future. We may be getting the wrong f
componenttext: Yes. That's reasonable. I mean, we're -- hey, we're not happy about going down to 4 then 3 rigs, but we're going to do what we need to do to preserve that balance sheet and make sure that we're well positioned for the future. We may be getting the wrong feedback. We've always kept our debt low. And our conclusion from what we've seen over the last 24 months is that was a prudent course of action because we have a lot of flexibility today in an arena where many of our competitors do not. So we're going to be careful. But nobody's unhappier with us going down to 3 rigs than we are, but it's what we have to do, and we're going to stay disciplined.
