headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded.At this time, I like to turn the conference over to Ms. Karen Acierno, Direc
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded.
At this time, I like to turn the conference over to Ms. Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, please go ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. Yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-lookin
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. Yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed.
You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. We know it's a busy week so we're going to try to keep her prepared remarks short today so that we have plenty of time for Q&A. We'll begin with overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, EVP of Exploration; and then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on operations, including production and well cost. Our CFO, Mark Burford, is also present to help answer any questions. [Operator Instructions]
And so with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look for to questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call.On the call today, John will walk us through our recent re
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look for to questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call.
On the call today, John will walk us through our recent results and describe our progress on some of the delineation projects that we have under way. This will include results from delineation in the Merrimac, the completion modifications that have further improve our results in the lower Wolfcamp.
In the Meramec, John will discuss results from 2 recent 10,000-foot horizontal wells that are significant in our performance, that they're also encouraging in the manner in which there delineating our acreage. In the Wolfcamp, John will discuss some recent results from completion optimization, including an outstanding recent 10,000-foot well in lower Wolfcamp in Culberson County. We're making great strides to improving our well results across our portfolio.
Additionally, we are confirming our optimism regarding the uplift we see from 10,000-foot horizontal wells. Not only are these wells delivering outstanding 30-day and 180-day rates, they are exhibiting surprisingly low decline.
Joe will follow John with an operational overview, including some of the steps we have taken to improve field efficiencies. As Joe will describe, he and his team had made great progress in getting our lease operating expenses down. There many components in the progress Joe will report, including smart well-engineered water management, personnel and equipment deficiencies, liftoff to optimization, compressor optimization and others. The result in savings and current and future of these operating expenses are significant to Cimarex.
We report another production beat this quarter driven by continued improvement in well performance. Our total company production was 974 million cubic feet equivalent per day for the second quarter, which exceeded the high end of our guidance. Gas production was up while oil production was down slightly. As we had forecasted, this was due to fewer well completions in the Permian Basin due to the timing of our infill and filing completions. As we pick up the pace in our Permian completions during the second half of the year, we expect oil production to trend upwards. Combined with all production expected from the Woodford completions in East Cana, we expect all production to be up approximately 15% in the fourth quarter versus second quarter levels.
Operating expenses with the exception of G&A came in within guidance resulting in a strong quarter overall. G&A were slightly above guidance as we recorded the cost of an early retirement package offered to employees in the first quarter that was finalized in June. We also announced an increase in our 2016 capital budget. We have raised our guidance from a range of a $650 million to $700 million of exploration development capital to $750 million for 2016. This includes $600 million earmarked for drilling and completions, up $100 million from the high end of our previous guidance. The increased capital will be used to further delineate the Meramec formation in the Anadarko Basin, push the completion of Woodford infill wells forward and add a handful of new wells to our Delaware Basin program.
Our bigger, more effective stimulations are also adding to our capital. This is money well spent as shown by our well results. We now see our operating rig count holding at 5 for the remainder of 2016.
With that, I'll turn the call over to John to provide further color in our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $156 million on exploration and development dur
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $156 million on exploration and development during the second quarter. About 65% was invested in the Permian region with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region.
Company-wide, we brought 34 gross, 14 net wells on production during the quarter. We had an average of 9 operating rigs during the quarter. These rigs were busy working the whole day [indiscernible] Wolfcamp and Meramec place as well as drilling base and pilots in the Delaware Basin and Mid-Continent. That activity is winding down and we are currently running 5 rigs, 3 in the Permian and 2 in Anadarko, an activity level with sentiment in through the rest of 2016.
While a lot of focus in put on the number of rigs and wells running, completion of the wells the biggest impact on both well cost and well performance. We are continuing to push the envelope on well completions.
On Page 30 of our presentation, we illustrate the evolution of completion size as measured in pound per sand per lateral foot drilled.
As you can see, completions are evolving across the company. We have several other slides in our presentation that illustrates the uplift we've seen in several of these plays, including the upper Wolfcamp in Culberson County and now the lower Wolfcamp as shown on Slide 12. Our most recent lower Wolfcamp well, the [indiscernible] 19 state A #5 H was completed with 2,400 pounds of sand per lateral foot and had an average 30-day IP of 3,127 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 23% was oil, 46% gas and 29% was NGL. All on average, that IP is 36% higher than previous completions.
The success of the frac design used on the [indiscernible] is more than just a pound a sand per foot increase. It is a direct consequence Cimarex developing a strong understanding of the geology and rock mechanics of this interval, which in turn, leads to design changes, not just in the amount of sand pump but also in the type of sand, cluster design, cluster count, stage spacing along with that type of fluid. This type of detailed frac design is taking place internally for each of our perspective zones in both basins, which is leading to the strong well performances that we have been achieving across the board.
Regarding our New Mexico Avalon Shale program, Cimarex drilled and completed the 500,000-foot [indiscernible] 25 fed #7 H late last youth amending an upside stimulation design in order to determine that we could achieve improved performance for this interval as seen in other Permian Shale intervals.
As shown on Slide 17 on our presentation, the results for this well has been outstanding. The well achieved a 30-day peak IP rate of 1,811 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 59% was oil, 20% gas and 22% NGL. With a very impressive 180-day rate of 1,317 barrels of oil equivalent per day and 180-day cube of 230,000 oil equivalent. This kind of results racist the program to top tier for us going forward.
Capital to be invested in the Permian for the second half 2016 will be focused on completion activity in acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position above Culberson and Reeves County. The total capital ascribed to acreage holding and Delaware Basin is just over $230 million in 2016. We currently have 3 rigs running in Delaware Basin and expect to keep them active through the remainder of 2016.
Now onto the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling the latest Woodford development project on the east side of the Cana core in the fourth quarter 2015. This development covers 6 sections of which Cimarex operates 2 sections. This infill project consists of 47 groves, 22 net wells. Drilling is finished and completion of the wells has again been moved up and is now scheduled for early September versus October that was discussed in our last fall. This change in scheduling was a contributing factor to our increasing capital expenditures for 2016.
As for the Meramec, we continue to drill wells to both hold our acreage and delineate our acreage position. Of note, our 2 of our most recent Meramec results, the Peterson and Sims long laterals, whose location can be seen on Slide 19 of the presentation.
The Peterson 1H-28 21X located in the Northwest part of our Meramec position achieved a 30-day peak average rate of 19 million cubic equivalent per day of which 54% was oil, 30% gas, 16% NGL. While the Sims 1H-20 17 X located in the southeastern part of our Meramec acreage, achieved a 30-day average rate of 12.8 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 29% oil, 46% gas, 25% NGL. These 2 books in wells in our acreage a good confirmation of our ability to adjust both the landing zone and frac designe to achieve very good rate of return that results across a breath of our Meramec acreage, and it's why we chose to keep to rigs running remainder of the year holding Meramec acreage.
Finally, to better understand the multizone potential for this area, we have recently finished drilling an 8-well stack [indiscernible] spectrum spacing pilot in the Meramec and Woodford formations. See Slide 21 for an illustration of this design. These wells are scheduled to begin completion operations later this month with first production anticipated in the fourth quarter. Results from another Meramec spacing pilot were recently announced by our partner, name. The pilot wells had an average IP of 1,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day of which 60% was oil. The completion of these wells was influential in the stimulation design for the Meramec in our stack stagger pilot to the final Meramec design using 2,600 pounds of sand per lateral foot. Cimarex hold a 46% working interest in this product.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albee

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining our call today. I'll touch on the usual items. Our second quarter production, our Q3 and full year '16 production outlook and then finish up with a few comments on LOE and the service cost. As Tom mentioned
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining our call today. I'll touch on the usual items. Our second quarter production, our Q3 and full year '16 production outlook and then finish up with a few comments on LOE and the service cost. As Tom mentioned, we have yet another great quarter for production with stronger-than-expected base property in new well performance. Really driving the quarter, our second quarter volumes came in better than anticipated. Our reported Q2 total company net equivalent production of $974 million a day, either guidance projection of $935 million to $965 million, and was up slightly lowered Q1 reported volume of $973 million a day rather than down as we anticipated in the last call.
As expected, with accelerated completion activity and increased processing capacity during the second quarter, we saw a nice boost in our Permian production with the addition of a second frac crew in May. We completed 9 Permian wells during the quarter as compared to just 3 in the first quarter. As a result, our second quarter Permian equivalent volume came in at $509 million a day, that's a $32 million a day or 7% from the first quarter.
In the Mid-Continent, continued well strong performance from our Cana-Woodford project, which came online in late fourth quarter last year, supported both our Q1 and our Q2 Mid-Continent volumes. And with that support, our second quarter Mid-Continent equivalent volume averaged $463 million a day, that's up $44 million a day or 11% from Q2 '15. But as expected, with only 5 new wells in the Mid-Continent coming online during the quarter, our second quarter Mid-Continent volumes decreased $30 million a day as compared to Q1.
So as we look forward into the last half of '16, we're projecting further acceleration of completion activity in both our Mid-Continent and Permian programs. And as a result, we're projecting a total of 72 net wells to come online during the year as compared to the 60 net wells we projected last call with 7 of those additional wells being located in the Permian and 5 in the Mid-Continent.
In the Mid-Continent, we moved up with the start date for Cana infill development project to September, as been previously stated. And that's again, versus our previous estimate of October. And in the Permian, with planed addition of third rig in August, we've also accelerated our completion activity for the most part in first quarter, for both of our Bone Spring and Reeves County programs. As a result, we now anticipate having 22 net wells waiting on completion at year-end with 11 in both the Mid-Continent and the Permian, and that's down from the 46 total wells that we have waiting on completion here at the end of Q2.
With our strong first half performance and our planted and completion activity, we've increased our total company full year production guidance to 0.98 to 1 Bcfe per day, that's up from our previous guidance of $940 million to $970 million a day. And would put us in essence, flat to 2% higher than our 2015 average of 985 -- $984.5 million a day. More importantly, our plan acceleration -- accelerated completion activity gives us very strong momentum going into 2017 with our forecasted Q4 exit rate in the range of 1.02 to 1.07 Bcfe per day, that's 3% to 9% higher than the $986 million a day we posted in Q4 '15. Our all production plays a big role in our projected Q4 exit rate. With our Q4 Permian and Mid-Continent net oil volumes forecasted to be up 12% to 17% from the volumes that we reported in Q2.
From Q3 '16, with 10 net Permian wells and 3 net Mid-Continent wells expected to come online during the quarter, we're guiding our total company net equivalent volumes to be in the range of $950 million to $980 million at it. That's in essence, flat with the second quarter. And as we move into Q4, completion activity really picks up steam with 15 net Permian wells and 26 net Mid-Continent wells, planned to come online in the fourth quarter.
Shifting gears to OpEx. We had a nice guidance feet for the second quarter LOE, and we owe it all to the production groups continue and dedicated efforts to optimally reduce our overall operating cost structure with their focus, we once again saw a sizable cost reductions during the quarter and similar components in quarters past. [indiscernible] disposal, compression, rentals, contract labor. And as such, our Q2 lifting cost came in at $0.65 per Mcfe, well below the low end of our guidance, which was $0.80 to $0.90, down 19% from our first quarter average of $0.80 per Mcfe and down 22% from the $0.83 we averaged in 2015.
So after incorporating our continued cost control efforts and also taking into account, the fluctuating nature of work over expenses, we projected our remaining year lifting cost to be in the range of $0.60 to $0.75 per Mcfe.
I want to take a moment to serial extremely proud of our entire production ops team for the success and safety and effectively reducing our LOE. The progress is sizable. Since prices began falling back in 2014, we've seen our absolute roughly that LOE approximately $9 million a month, which on annualized basis, it has in essence, freed up over $100 million a year that we can direct our drilling program.
And finally, on service cost. Some very similar comments to our last call with regard to drilling and completion cost, most all of our drilling cost components have remained relatively in check while we have seen some modest reductions in per-unit completion cost, primarily in the Permian. On the drilling side, we have kept our focus on efficiencies as illustrated with our average 2016 Bone Spring spread to rig release real time of 10 days, that's down from 12 days in '15 and 14 days in 2014. On the completion side, we've seen continued cost reductions in the Permian, both from a frac cost standpoint as well as in the cost of source our water, which has really helped to mitigate additional cost pumping larger jobs. As we continue to increase our frac size, completion dollars continue to dominate our total well cost, representing up to 2/3 of the individual total well cost reached well. As in quarters past, we've been able to offset the costs of the facts with lower per unit pumping costs. And as such, most of our generic AFEs have remained somewhat in check as compared to last quarter. An exception, however, is our Permian Bone Spring program where both our drilling and completion efficiencies have reduced our current 1 mile lateral AFE's to $4.7 million to $5.1 million, that's down 6% from the $5 million to $5.4 million that we quoted last quarter.
In the Wolfcamp, with larger completions, our generic 2-mile lateral Culberson AFEs continue to run in the 10.2 to 11.2 to range. That's flat the last call, but down 5% from where we were in Q4 and down 23% from that program's AFE back in late 2014.
With our larger frac design, our Cana core 1-mile lateral Woodford AFE is running in the range of $7.1 million to $7.5 million, up from the $6.6 million to $7 million range we previously quoted with the smaller frac, but right in line with the $500,000 to $600,000 anticipated increase that we quoted last call, should we adopt and implement the larger fracs, which we are. But even with a larger frac, our current Cana 1-mile Woodford well is down 10% on a total well cost as compared to late 2014.
As we drill more 2-mile lateral Meramec wells, our current AFEs are run in the range of $10.7 mi to $11.4 million, all the while, we continue to experiment with various frac design and land index and so on.
In closing, we had another great quarter. We gained tremendous strides reducing operating cost structure. We stayed -- we're staying focused on efficiencies to reduce and optimize our joint and completion cost and we continue to make good progress, maximizing the productivity and profitability of our wells.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Q&A.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The results are great. I think they keep surprising the upside, I guess kind of basic question of how the progress through this completion design evolution? You have, obviously, in front of name that you want to execute on, and it seems the more and more
componenttext: The results are great. I think they keep surprising the upside, I guess kind of basic question of how the progress through this completion design evolution? You have, obviously, in front of name that you want to execute on, and it seems the more and more you test bigger, the more complex completions, you keep getting much, much more return than the capital you put in. So how is the -- what's your strategy for reaching that optimal well-design the quickest?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One is pick up the pace in capital and significant reason and justification why we decided to keep 5 rigs going, it accelerates our completion, just gives us more Laboratories. And I'm very proud of our organization and the degree of innovation that they'
componenttext: One is pick up the pace in capital and significant reason and justification why we decided to keep 5 rigs going, it accelerates our completion, just gives us more Laboratories. And I'm very proud of our organization and the degree of innovation that they're the undertaking. We studied our competitors hard. I think you all know us well enough, not be surprised by that statement. But it's also strength at Cimarex to be in 2 of the most active basins in the country. To be in the Delaware Basin and the STACK play means that we have 2 independent laboratories and we can draw and bring best practices from one play to another. And that it's also been a really big part of our success and we're just getting warmed up there. We have lots of things that are on our list to try, and many of them are things that have been tried in 1 basin but haven't been tried in the another.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. I think the only comment I'd make is we put a lot of debate internally on these frac design changes. I mean, we involve all disciplines when it comes to that. And then we measure ourselves quickly and like you pointed out, this incremental c
componenttext: This is John. I think the only comment I'd make is we put a lot of debate internally on these frac design changes. I mean, we involve all disciplines when it comes to that. And then we measure ourselves quickly and like you pointed out, this incremental capital involved, that drive up our overall total costs and so we're asking ourselves, what type of improvement justifies this. What should we be looking for early in the life of these wells that say, this is a good investment decision, keep moving forward with it. And quite frankly, once we achieve that, I mean, we're asking ourselves, okay, can we go even further, what's next? And now that's what I'm proud of, we are not resting on our laurels here. And as much as I really love the landscape right now of what we've achieved and what it looks like from a rate of return perspective, we are not going to sit and say okay, this is it, we are going to keep pushing. There's so much were learning about these rocks and these frac designs and I still think there's a lot of potential there.

componenttext: This is John. I guess you're referencing a particular Canadian County where we have built a number of Meramec wells, including the latest one we just talked about, which is the -- our Sims well. That area, I would just say, is a little bit of has challenged than Meramec than necessarily say more that you [indiscernible] but that's why we're proud of that Sims result down there in that part of the play. I think that's also why we decided to add a little bit more capital because now we feel a little bit better about that area. But it's also one that's going to take a little bit more drilling as we get more comfortable with the landing zone and frac design. And again, I want to stress that there is no one recipe here in the Meramec, seeing 1 area that works best across the whole play, We're definitely changing things up and adapting to results. And again, I'll just have to emphasize, that's why we like that sims result, that one really -- has given us a little bit more definitely more encouragement through that part of the Meramec play.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's an [indiscernible] story and you hear us, you talk about the variability of the Meramec, we've been around that Sims well, we had some results from [indiscernible] and competitors that led us to think oh, should we drill this well or not. And we trie
componenttext: It's an [indiscernible] story and you hear us, you talk about the variability of the Meramec, we've been around that Sims well, we had some results from [indiscernible] and competitors that led us to think oh, should we drill this well or not. And we tried some different things and it's a stunning and surprisingly positive results. And that tells us, it's not over until it's over. This Meramec really is a function of landing zone and completion design, in that section, has lots of surprises left and thus far it surprising the upside.

componenttext: This is John, and I'm going to broad brush strokes maybe. The differences clearly, there's always amount of sand we pump. There are going to be differences in the cluster design, cluster spacing. And quite frankly, there's differences on whether or not we use diverters. And all of those are kind of in our bag of tricks to look at. I would just say right now, state that again, the Peterson design was way different than the Sims design. And what we're trying to do now is check on that, do a couple of wells and see does 1 work better in one area and then in the other and then we'll continue to progress from there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I just wanted to ask on capital allocation. It looks like you guys have a -- looks like you have a pretty good problem given all your impressive results across multiple geographic areas. How are you thinking about prioritization of capital by both in
componenttext: Tom, I just wanted to ask on capital allocation. It looks like you guys have a -- looks like you have a pretty good problem given all your impressive results across multiple geographic areas. How are you thinking about prioritization of capital by both in geographic area and zone? I guess, what I'm getting at is First Call heavy rank your place right now.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's a great question, Jason. And it is a challenge, that's a pretty high-class problem we have. We have 2 outstanding plays and we have an outstanding acreage business in both plays and acreage positions that offer 10,000 [indiscernible] on horizonta
componenttext: No, it's a great question, Jason. And it is a challenge, that's a pretty high-class problem we have. We have 2 outstanding plays and we have an outstanding acreage business in both plays and acreage positions that offer 10,000 [indiscernible] on horizontal wells. You some all that together and it's your dilemma on how we allocate capital. Now I will say as I said in the past that some of our best well level returns are in the Bone Spring, in the Delaware Basin. Certainly, the 10,000-foot long Wolfcamp wells are fantastic and getting better. And as John said, the Avalon is really roaring to the compete heads up with everything I just mentioned. I would say the Delaware at the well level rate of return is at the top of the pack. But that Anadarko story is evolving and not very far behind. If some of these new landing zones in new stimulations, if the Sims, Peterson and some of the wells are now competitors, if these results are repeatable across large portions of our 115,000 Meramec acres, then it's going to give a j[indiscernible] on how we allocate capital because there's also science in delineation we want to view. So we're always balancing with that absolute high rate of return, our next investment, with looking 5, 10 years ahead, what information do we want and when do we want it? So in terms of capital allocation, we're going ahead with 3 rigs in the Delaware and 2 rigs in the STACK play, and we think both those rigs or both those programs are designed to give us a lot of information, both landing zone, completion optimization and geological delineation. And so we're fairly comfortable with that 3-rig Delaware to 2-rig Anadarko right now. If prices were to improve materially, I think it's a function of oil or gas improves. But right now, the Delaware is probably the strongest voice for incremental capital if we were to increase the on that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. Yes, shame on me. The Cabinet state is an outstanding well, and we're very, very pleased to that result. And the reality is, I wish I could've made it to 10,000  but that particular case, we were landlocked to hold that acreage as a 5,
componenttext: Well, this is John. Yes, shame on me. The Cabinet state is an outstanding well, and we're very, very pleased to that result. And the reality is, I wish I could've made it to 10,000  but that particular case, we were landlocked to hold that acreage as a 5,000-foot lateral. And in that particular play, we clearly, in our own mind, have demonstrated uplift going to 10 so just imagine Cabinet state taking to attend it would be that much better. I think what you're seeing Cabinet state is again, Tom, does a nice job of talking about this just as leveraging frac design changes in the upper Wolfcamp in Culberson, over to Reeves and back and forth, and that's a good example. Along with -- we have our major development there and next to Big Timber where we're about to start fracking with the wood wells, we're clearly taking that frac design that we implemented overall in the upper Wolfcamp product there over the dose wells. So we're seeing really good results there, throughout that part of Reeves County, and we're very excited about it and we've got a lot of drilling to do there, the main on year and in next year. And finally, when I think about it, the thing also that's changing there and we talk a lot about is landing zone. We are definitely getting much more comfortable in Reeves as to where we want to land those wells, and I think it's leading to the kind of results you're seeing as well. So it's a combination is kind of sound like a broken record but both frac, uplift and landing zone.

componenttextpreview: Regarding the Avalon, can it attract a rig to itself in 2017 or does it need to be part of more regional strategy?
componenttext: Regarding the Avalon, can it attract a rig to itself in 2017 or does it need to be part of more regional strategy?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. I've got a lot of people live and [indiscernible] on the Avalon, and again, we have certain priorities that we need to meet no matter. We still have acreage we need to hold in the Wolfcamp, and that will clearly be something we will fu
componenttext: Well, this is John. I've got a lot of people live and [indiscernible] on the Avalon, and again, we have certain priorities that we need to meet no matter. We still have acreage we need to hold in the Wolfcamp, and that will clearly be something we will fund. But I will tell you, this well result has definitely caused us to ask what's next. And I won't be surprised if we go back up on that acreage and push the envelope again in terms of our stimulation design and with a long lateral, that's the one thing I think next up we'd like to take in the Avalon, let's get along lateral under our belt with this type of stimulation and it really see what kind of rate of returns we can achieve. And then probably the next step for us is then spacing. We've already announced before that we did spacing pilots in the past in the Avalon. We feel very good at 8 wells per section and again multiple intervals and in our the Avalon, we probably won't need to go out there and tests tighter spacing, but we're also blessed that we have a lot of competitors in and around our HBP acreage who doing just that. So we're not in the vacuum there. So we'll learn a lot from looking across the fence. But yes, I think it's safe to say, we'll at least get a look of little more capital, at least, I'm [indiscernible] for that. For some wells, next year to test further within that plan next year.

componenttext: This is John. As far as -- let me just address first, updip, downdip, that's a nice little display be put out there. And in no way does that influence where we go with the rig. Right now, honestly, that rig is going to HBP acreage the 2 rigs that are remaining the rest this year as well as going into next year is earmarked to holding acreage, and some of that acreage is both up dip and some of it is downdip. Again, what's nice is we're achieving very good returns in both areas that we want to justify that capital, which is why we're keeping the 2 rigs. So I don't know that we make a you should distinction just yet, in terms of that, in terms of where we would send the rig, because again, we're trying to hold acreage. And then I'm sorry, what was the second part of that. I'm sorry, was that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, really, what I was sort of thinking is sort of thinking simplistically and trying to look at a greater number of wells over the play as a whole. It seems like the up dip tends to be well, but you're on the downdip, but the Alamo pilot stren
componenttext: Well, I guess, really, what I was sort of thinking is sort of thinking simplistically and trying to look at a greater number of wells over the play as a whole. It seems like the up dip tends to be well, but you're on the downdip, but the Alamo pilot strength for has got a pretty impressive oil cut there, and I'm wondering if there's any influence from having 2 zones producing there as opposed to the Meramec kind of theoretical oilier area.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All I'll say there is, there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us and our competitors. I think it Last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite frankly, we have an interest in most of them. So we'll be an avid watcher of those
componenttext: All I'll say there is, there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us and our competitors. I think it Last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite frankly, we have an interest in most of them. So we'll be an avid watcher of those results as well as our own pilot that we'll be starting completions on here soon. I don't know that we so fully understand the full stack potential of this play, I guess, to use that acronym. We just don't know yet. We feel pretty good where we put our Leon Gundy that there's enough thickness there to justify the 2 layers within the Meramec, with the 1 layer in the Woodford. And we're very -- we have high expectations for that pilot. Beyond that, I don't a how much we can go beyond that, and time will tell. And then you can also argue, how will it vary based on maybe that's what you're driving at versus the hydrocarbon component that is as I get into more oilier window, can I stack more or not or vice a versa? Those are the things we just don't know yet for this play.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's a lot of variables here, up dip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure pre-study, we will study every well in the train, and I tell you fairly evergreen list where we look at every well and rank them by the rate of return, and we focus
componenttext: Yes, there's a lot of variables here, up dip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure pre-study, we will study every well in the train, and I tell you fairly evergreen list where we look at every well and rank them by the rate of return, and we focus on rate of return. And that's what we're going for. And so we talked in the past, we have bias pressure, we have a bias stores pressure, we have a bias towards [indiscernible] but our real bias is toward rate of return. And if we really look at rate of return, this map will be contoured differently. And we're pretty excited about potential for us .

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons, Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Tom, with these very strong well results, do you see this lowering your threshold oil and gas price, necessary to move beyond 5 rigs if you wanted to add some? So essentially, if the old numbers say it was $50, does it move down to $45? Or likewise, on gas, does it move to below $3. Just want to get your thoughts around that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well that's a great question, and I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story. And you can go back what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance improvements,
componenttext: Well that's a great question, and I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story. And you can go back what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance improvements, our cost reductions and certainly, that LOE reduction is really important part of the story. Our breakeven cost will come way down and that's true, both in the Anadarko and in Delaware Basin. So I will say that Cimarex looks pretty, pretty good in the mid-40s to $53 gas environment. We have tremendous returns through our portfolio and we are achieving fully burden results that are historically high within our program. So it's not so much in answering your question. It's not so much about price as it is stability. We want to manage our balance sheet. We watch our cash flow and we're absolutely omitted to being disciplined and keep the health of this company second to none. And so what we're looking for isn't necessary an absolute price signal as it is price stability. And ramping up our capital as we did is probably to us, a strong vote of confidence on our assets. And we think that if prices were stable at $45 and the $2.50 to $3 gas range, we've you've got a great landscape ahead of us. And I've said in the past, we're not waiting for the rescue boat to save us. I challenged was our make a living in this environment. And I would say that our organization respond to that call in every way, both in increased well performance and decrease costs and lease operating. So we're into good shape if we see stability.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between this short and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's fairly early on, but I was wondering if you think there are any material differences in overall returns between the
componenttext: I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between this short and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's fairly early on, but I was wondering if you think there are any material differences in overall returns between the longer laterals. And the deeper overpressure window versus the more shallow regular pressure window, and if you thank the longer laterals seem to make sense in both areas?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. I guess I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of return we achieved, and we demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But again, it'
componenttext: This is John. I guess I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of return we achieved, and we demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But again, it's fair to say, the majority of our portfolio is in pressure drop, and that's where most of our experience. We don't have a lot of experience in drilling long laterals and lower pressured -- close to normal pressure type rocks. And something else also happens. We talked about this. Once you move in that normal pressure part of the play, more earlier play, you are talking about a part of the plays were it's shallower. So your cost to get there, the vertical part of it is very inexpensive. You don't need that extra string of pipe. You drill bit very quickly and a lot of times, when you think of long laterals, we love them because it's pretty expensive for us to get there to, to get to the target, so once we're there, we want to stay there as long as we can. In fat, [indiscernible] the drilling department must know why we stopped at 10,000 feet. And in some ways, internally, we talk about that. But the big difference is when you go up dip, it's pretty cheap to get down there to get to the zone. So then you want to ask yourself, operationally, does that extra 5,000 really gain you a lot or not. And we just don't have a lot of experience with that. I'll be honest with you. All are experience has been in the pressure but we're watching it very, very carefully, ourselves. As Tom says, we're looking across the fence and asking ourself, maybe, maybe in that shallow or lower normal pressure. Maybe 5,000 is a better way to go than 10,000. I don't know that answer right now, we'll see over time.

componenttextpreview: This is Joe. What I might allow there is our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty high level company wise and going into '17. So there's a couple of ways looking at it. Now, on a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking about is doable. But
componenttext: This is Joe. What I might allow there is our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty high level company wise and going into '17. So there's a couple of ways looking at it. Now, on a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking about is doable. But we're going to get these oscillated production profiles with a lot of these intel projects. So for us, always, we talked about in I think our first quarter call. A lot of these perceptions or exit rate has a lot to do with what your next year's average is going to be. I think we all need to take a little bit of caution in that because we're going to see highs and lows and highs in lows in some of these projects come online.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the challenges we face is we're in our constant inflection point with the quality of our assets and as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is, we're just not that good forecasting on things that are difficult to forecast, an improved well perform
componenttext: One of the challenges we face is we're in our constant inflection point with the quality of our assets and as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is, we're just not that good forecasting on things that are difficult to forecast, an improved well performance is the biggest of them all. But with our asset quality, we have the wind in our backs on that. So we're pretty optimistic as we look ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Helpful color, appreciate it. I guess, my kind of bigger picture. You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think it was Slide 30 or so where you outlined the progression of profit loading over time. I'm just curious, as we think about a re-accel
componenttext: Great. Helpful color, appreciate it. I guess, my kind of bigger picture. You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think it was Slide 30 or so where you outlined the progression of profit loading over time. I'm just curious, as we think about a re-acceleration of activity from the industry over the coming years, I guess, in theory, anyway, if oil prices go up, how would you think about profit loading as cost inflation comes back into the picture? Meaning, is it harder to carry such high profit loads without the big benefit of cost deflation that was seen from the cyclical pressures, that makes sense?

componenttext: Would you not have increased loading to the extent that you have or not for the cyclical benefits you've gotten from improved pricing, from service vendors. Such that if things move the opposite way theoretically, we expect some sensation down the road, would profit loading be an area where you would reduce well costs going at some point in the future [indiscernible]

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been such we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total overall cost had come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus Q1. In Q2, w
componenttext: I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been such we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total overall cost had come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus Q1. In Q2, we pumped about as a company, 21% more fluid and 12% more sand, yet, our crude well frac cost was maybe down 10%. It all comes down to what John just said earlier. It's going to be a matter of economics. So with these prices do creep up, the cost do creep up, we're always going to be looking at for that job, what will it cost? What are the results we expect to achieve pumping that job? And does the merit good to job or should we deviate summer plus or minus from there in design? So it's kind of a tough question to answer other than to tell you that we're constantly looking at current costs. We're constantly working hard to keep them low and we're constantly focused on rate of return.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last couple of
componenttext: Yes. That's the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last couple of years. But we've got the right wins, and I'm confident we have the right wins, and its after-tax rate of return. So yes, answer your question, some of the aggressiveness that we've had in adding to our profit certainly has been facilitated by how low our cost structure has been. And if we had a pressure either through commodity pricing or service cost, we're going to look at that on a regular underweight ever term basis and trying to find optimal solution. We don't look at production rates and say, the highest production rate is our best solution. We always, always at Cimarex, look at rate of return on the investment required. So I have a lot of confidence in free markets. If a market forces cause us to find a different path forward. I think our focus on rate of return is exactly the way to navigate that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry about that. For Tom and John, I guess I'm curious. You guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil window in Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down on the gas window in the southwest portion of the play. And then, obviously, in between the
componenttext: Sorry about that. For Tom and John, I guess I'm curious. You guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil window in Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down on the gas window in the southwest portion of the play. And then, obviously, in between the 2 extremes. I guess, Tom, based on the running list of operated, nonoperating results and then the associated rate of return for all of those wells, what portion of the play do you feel consistently is at the top of the list based on rate of return?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide 21, certainly, there's an little area where those -- less stars cluster. It's right that where our pilot project has the arrow going through the pileup, certainly on
componenttext: Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide 21, certainly, there's an little area where those -- less stars cluster. It's right that where our pilot project has the arrow going through the pileup, certainly on Gumby pilot. That is a tremendous south area within the play. Cimarex has an outstanding well in there. Other operators do as well and that's certainly a really, really attractive part of the play, comparing the play overall. Now I will say, if you go up to where we've got our got our well, that is emerging as really, really nice part of the play. Cimarex, you've seen the peers in the results, I would say, we're very pleased with our acreage position, our team has done a nice job of building a position up there. So we have really, really nice exposure there. But John, do you want to comment about the play in general?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties there, Kingfisher, Blank Canadian. We had a number as well as our competitors, had a number of good wells. That area still holds up as a very good area. But without a d
componenttext: Just follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties there, Kingfisher, Blank Canadian. We had a number as well as our competitors, had a number of good wells. That area still holds up as a very good area. But without a doubt, this most western blain area where our Peterson well is and some of our competitor wells had recently come on, it's starting to rise right up to the top there. It's an interesting area and I'm really, really proud of our team because that's an area where early on in this play, we got out there and grabbed some really good acreage at a really good price. That's really given us that nice yellow position, we have where Peterson well is located. So that's kind of in a Broadway where most of the best returns that we see so far, but I don't think this story is done. I think there's still -- im fascinated everyday, another well comes on and we are surprised just the other day, another well came on and any we didn't think would be perspective and we are quickly looking at it asking ourselves, okay, what's going on there. So there's a lot of chapters in this story left to play out here in the Meramec for sure.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up that you mentioned it. Can you walk through the geologic differences between where that good Peterson well in the pilot and what you know today, I understand it's evolving but kind of where you're at today.
componenttext: As a follow-up that you mentioned it. Can you walk through the geologic differences between where that good Peterson well in the pilot and what you know today, I understand it's evolving but kind of where you're at today.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different to geologic setting for the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on what
componenttext: It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different to geologic setting for the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on what we call an up tip position. And yet, we are seeing some really good frothy development in and around that Peterson area, which is leading to these really high IP rates we're seeing and leaning to the kind of results. So you may be sacrificing a little bit. I don't see that as is STACK, meaning multilayer area in Peterson versus say, our Leon Gundy or even [indiscernible] area. But because you're not as thick, but boy, the rock looks pretty good there, though.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past and on this call as well, talked about Merrimack wearability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how is your thoughts evolve on variab
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past and on this call as well, talked about Merrimack wearability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how is your thoughts evolve on variability across the play? And I guess, obviously, have increased confidence with that second rig in there. But expectations in terms of variability as you move to different areas of the play. How have those changed and evolved, I guess, since last quarter and then really, since last year?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we still we see the Merrimack as highly variable. Perhaps, one of the evolution is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with landing zone and proper simulation. One of the things that I think we've learned in
componenttext: Well, I think we still we see the Merrimack as highly variable. Perhaps, one of the evolution is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with landing zone and proper simulation. One of the things that I think we've learned in the last year is that you cannot settle on the landing zone and carry that 6 or 8 miles and ran the well and that same [indiscernible] And expect comparable results. That said, what we're finding is the Merrimack, because it is, if you put yourself in a different wedge and find the right landing zone, you find you can overcome that variability. So yes, we still see this as a highly variable play. I think there are some announcements out of our competitors that's adjusted to that. But we're soldiering on and we really like it. John, you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the viability, and how we adapt to it. And then change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think what really, in our vernacular what it means is, we will tear it differently. We'll ha
componenttext: Yes. I think what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the viability, and how we adapt to it. And then change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think what really, in our vernacular what it means is, we will tear it differently. We'll have some areas that will be a certain part that we'll look at it from the way we want to drill it and frac it and other areas would be different. It's not like our -- I would argue, our Woodford shale, it's a consistent frac design, we wanted to pull across all of that shale. It's a very homogeneous interval. That's not true in the Meramec. In the Merrimack, you had to adjust. And I think over time, we're understanding of what's required to get the kind of returns that we like across the breadth of our acreage. And again, the story will continue to evolve. And I am sure, based on what I've seen, I think our results will continue to get better as we get better understanding of this rock and what's going on here.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think it's important. Were -- for Cimarex here, and some of our own style's overprinted on this. I think some of our competitors have spoken about it being a more uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they maybe talking about
componenttext: And I think it's important. Were -- for Cimarex here, and some of our own style's overprinted on this. I think some of our competitors have spoken about it being a more uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they maybe talking about different issues than we are. If you are saying it's a play broad areas top tier economic returns over broad areas, you can drill and get really good results on average. Yes, it's a fairly uniform play. But I'll contrast Cimarex with the Woodford shale. The Woodford shale, we fairly early on and particularly, with our own stimulations, got a point where we think we understand the regional consistency. We can drill anywhere in our asset and fairly acrylate predict the yield and we're fairly console at a fairly high-level making decisions. When we go to the Meramec, I will tell you that John and I get the into the weeds on looking at that geography, looking at landing zones, talking about completion styles because it is very variable. And as foreign to it as we are, it is still in our opinion, a fascinating and challenging scientific project.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree. We have very stimulating things with every Meramec well we drill. And there is every Meramec well in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Everyone, it's different in how we landed. It's different how we frac it. And I think that's going to co
componenttext: I agree. We have very stimulating things with every Meramec well we drill. And there is every Meramec well in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Everyone, it's different in how we landed. It's different how we frac it. And I think that's going to continue for quite a while until we settle in, in different areas aren't years as the what's a best practice. And we're getting there and I think that's what you're hearing from us is that we're getting more confident in how to plan those wells now going forward.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Applebaum from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Applebaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm Mark. I'm curious, with the rig additions here. In the past, you guys have kind of outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of these things, I guess. One, and it's really kind of a 2-part question. Is the 5 r
componenttext: I'm Mark. I'm curious, with the rig additions here. In the past, you guys have kind of outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of these things, I guess. One, and it's really kind of a 2-part question. Is the 5 rigs -- does the 5 rigs sort of adequately answer what you would like to learn in early 2017? If not, what sort of shortfall is there? And 2, how do you sort of marry that now? I don't see any incremental activity going to the Cana just yet. And you do have a premier guest asset now with in the strip, well above 3 into 2017. How do you marry an asset that's ready for full field development with attractive economics now versus trying to find all this knowledge in your other place?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy, trying to juggle everything you just described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of current returns, especial
componenttext: This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy, trying to juggle everything you just described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of current returns, especially now that we look at it as a long lateral development. And again, keep that in mind, everything up-to-date in Cana has been 5,000 feet, but given the continuity of our acreage that we, along with our partner, Devon have, we, together, are starting to have those discussions over long macro development and a need, I think you will hear from us in the coming quarters start talking more about where that next development will take place for us. This well we're about to bring on is pretty exciting. It's a more liquid, rich part of the Cana Woodford shale. I am also excited because our partner there, Devon, has build 4 2-mile lateral so we'll get a chance to see those in the development phase, how they look. And we had a wonderful position between the two of us, just north of that we call the 13 8 area that we definitely see as long lateral development, it's just a question of two of us coming together at some point and planning that out and then we'll see when that starts. So no, you're absolutely right. Cana looks very good but it's also a matter of how you get that funded versus everything else that were trying to answer in the Meramec and the Wolfcamp and into every other play we have. The other comment I want to make real quick is we'd really did a lot this year with our spacing pilots. And yes, we don't have a lot to talk on just yet but we put a lot of capital earlier in the year in these pilots in the Wolfcamp, and in the Meramec, and that's really going to set us up very well for the coming years when we start moving to full-scale development where we get the kind of confidence to deploy those large amounts of capital in the Wolfcamp or the Meramec likely we are today in the Woodford and that's going to put more pressure on Tom to open up the first ring, let's spend more money to get there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just to add on what John said. We are really high on the Woodford. And you're right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford? It's a good question, but part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodford is we n
componenttext: David, just to add on what John said. We are really high on the Woodford. And you're right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford? It's a good question, but part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodford is we need to understand that Meramec, so that when we develop out there, we really exploit the resource in the most prudent fashion. We have to understand how many landing zones we have. We have to understand the full potential of the Meramec. The thing we absolutely do not want to do is go into Cana Woodford development and then find out that the Meramec is left behind. And then if we come in and get it later, we have every production interference and disruption. So part of our aggressiveness in testing the Meramec is to set ourselves up for codevelopment from Woodford to Meramec, and we still have a lot of things to learn. So we're high on the Woodford, probably higher today than we've ever been.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question for today comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our final question for today comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had just a couple of very quick questions. But can you give us some more details on the eastern core infill development. I know it's now going to come online or start fracking in September. How many wells is that? And you can talk a little bit about com
componenttext: I had just a couple of very quick questions. But can you give us some more details on the eastern core infill development. I know it's now going to come online or start fracking in September. How many wells is that? And you can talk a little bit about completion design around that program?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, it's -- for us, it's 47 gross wells, 22 net wells, and we operate the Westernmost 2 sections. We will be coming into it with 1 frac crew in September. Devon will match it up with 1 frac crew. Very quickly, we'll then have 2 frac c
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, it's -- for us, it's 47 gross wells, 22 net wells, and we operate the Westernmost 2 sections. We will be coming into it with 1 frac crew in September. Devon will match it up with 1 frac crew. Very quickly, we'll then have 2 frac crews to finish up our 2 sections. And then Devon, I think has plans to bring in a second frac crew a little bit later in the year so they can get those done. Although I think there is the extend into next year, I don't recall. Does it, Mark?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: I can also tell you that, that when we look at it, it is definitely liquid rich than say, what we experienced in our previous real development. In fact, I asked the team the other day, when we hit peak production, the net production we expect off that row at peak will be about 49% gas, 34% NGL and 17% oil. So kind of on a gas liquid basis, it's almost a 50-50 split. And so again, that's why we're very encouraged. We think we can get good returns out of this row. And as far as the completion itself, I think Devon himself will speak for their wells. But for our wells, we are moving forward with the design that we deployed on the [indiscernible] section. I think if you refer to Page 30, we talked about where we were up to 3,500 pounds per foot. we really, really like the results from armored cost. In fact, we didn't even talk much about that, but we had a really nice slide showing how [indiscernible] wells [indiscernible] just as well as our other sections. And yet, we put an additional well within that section, new well. So we're able to get an extra well and yet, still get similar results, meaning we're getting more reserves per section, out of that section. So we feel really good about that frac design. And then that's what we intend on using going forward on our 2 operating sections.

componenttext: Sure. I would tell you that certainly, all the acreage that we allude to on Slide 17 as far as the 13,700 net acres of Avalon, have already Bone Spring. In fact, a lot of them already have Bone Spring wells on them that we drilled in the past, some of the do. And certainly, have Wolfcamp potential as well, without a doubt, will have Wolfcamp potential. That area alone in the part of Lee County definitely has all 3. So it's a very, very target rich acreage position we have there. That again, it's HPP, it's not going anywhere and yet, we recognize that there is a lot of potential there on that acreage. And then again, this playlist Avalon will well just shows that.
