headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded.At this time, I'd like to turn the conference call over to Ms. Karen Acierno
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference call over to Ms. Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Ma'am, please go ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. Yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-lookin
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. Yesterday afternoon, an updated presentation was posted to our website. We will be referring to this presentation during our call today. As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed.
You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. We know it's a busy week so we're going to try and keep our prepared remarks short today so that we have plenty of time for Q&A. We'll begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden; followed by an update on drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, EVP of Exploration; and then, Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on operations, including production and well cost; our CFO, Mark Burford, is also here to help answer any questions. [Operator Instructions]
And so with that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call.On the call today, John will walk us through our
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who is participating in today's call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call.
On the call today, John will walk us through our recent results and describe our progress on some of the delineation projects that we have underway. This will include results from delineation in the Meramec, the completion modifications that have further improved our results in the lower Wolfcamp.
In the Meramec, John will discuss results from 2 recent 10,000-foot horizontal wells that are significant in their performance, but they're also encouraging in the manner in which they're delineating our acreage. In the Wolfcamp, John will discuss some recent results from completion optimization, including an outstanding recent 10,000-foot well in lower Wolfcamp in Culberson County. We're making great strides in improving our well results across our portfolio.
Additionally, we are confirming our optimism regarding the uplift we see from 10,000-foot horizontal wells. Not only are these wells delivering outstanding 30-day and 180-day rates, they're exhibiting surprisingly low decline.
Joe will follow John with an operational overview, including some of the steps we have taken to improve field efficiencies. As Joe will describe, he and his team have made great progress in getting our lease operating expenses down. There are many components to the progress that Joe will report, including smart, well-engineered water management, personnel and equipment efficiencies, liftoff optimization, compressor optimization and others. The result in savings incurred and future lease operating expenses are significant to Cimarex.
We reported another production beat this quarter driven by continued improvement in well performance. Our total company production was 974 million cubic feet equivalent per day for the second quarter, which exceeded the high end of our guidance. Gas production was up, while oil production was down slightly. As we had forecasted, this was due to fewer well completions in the Permian Basin due to the timing of our infill and spacing -- pilot completions. As we pick up the pace on our Permian completions during the second half of the year, we expect oil production to trend upwards. Combined with oil production expected from the Woodford completions and East Cana, we expect all production to be up approximately 15% in the fourth quarter versus second quarter levels.
Operating expenses, with the exception of G&A, came in within guidance, resulting in a strong quarter overall. G&A were slightly above guidance as we recorded the cost of an early retirement package offered to employees in the first quarter that was finalized in June. We also announced an increase in our 2016 capital budget. We have raised our guidance from a range of $650 million to $700 million of exploration development capital to $750 million for 2016. This includes $600 million earmarked for drilling and completions, up $100 million from the high end of our previous guidance. The increased capital will be used to further delineate the Meramec formation in the Anadarko Basin, push the completion of Woodford infill wells forward and add a handful of new wells to our Delaware Basin program.
Our bigger, more effective stimulations are also adding to our capital. This is money well spent as shown by our well results. We now see our operated rig count holding at 5 for the remainder of 2016.
With that, I'll turn the call over to John to provide further color in our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $156 million on exploration and development dur
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $156 million on exploration and development during the second quarter. About 65% was invested in the Permian region, with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region.
Company-wide, we brought 34 gross, 14 net wells on production during the quarter. We had an average of 9 operated rigs running during the quarter. These rigs were busy working to hold acreage in both the Wolfcamp and Meramec plays as well as drilling spacing pilots in both the Delaware Basin and the Mid-Continent. That activity is winding down and we are currently running 5 rigs, 3 in the Permian and 2 in Anadarko, an activity level we intend to maintain through the rest of 2016.
While a lot of focus is put on the number of rigs Cimarex is running, completion of the wells has the biggest impact on both well cost and well performance. We are continuing to push the envelope on well completions.
On Page 30 of our presentation, we illustrate the evolution of completion size as measured in pound per sand per lateral foot drilled. As you can see, completions are evolving across the company. We have several other slides in our presentation that illustrate the uplift we've seen in several of these plays, including the upper Wolfcamp in Culberson County and now the lower Wolfcamp, as shown on Slide 12. Our most recent lower Wolfcamp well, the Flying Ebony 19 State A #5 H was completed with 2,400 pounds of sand per lateral foot and had an average 30-day IP of 3,127 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 23% was oil, 46% gas and 29% was NGL. On average, that IP is 36% higher than previous completions.
The success of the frac design used on the Flying Ebony is more than just a pound a sand per foot increase. It is a direct consequence of Cimarex developing a strong understanding of the geology and rock mechanics for this interval, which in turn leads to design changes, not just in the amount of sand pump but also in the type of sand, cluster design, cluster count, stage spacing along with the type of fluid. This type of detailed frac design is taking place internally for each of our perspective zones in both basins, which is leading to the strong well performances that we have been achieving across the board.
Regarding our New Mexico Avalon Shale program, Cimarex drilled and completed the 500,000-foot Triste Draw 25 Fed #7 H late last year, implementing an upsized stimulation design in order to determine if we could achieve improved performance for this interval, as seen in other Permian Shale intervals.
As shown on Slide 17 on our presentation, the results for this well have been outstanding. The well achieved a 30-day peak IP rate of 1,811 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 59% was oil, 20% gas and 22% NGL, with a very impressive 180-day rate of 1,317 barrels of oil equivalent per day and 180-day cume of 230,000 barrels oil equivalent. This kind of result certainly raises the Avalon program to top tier for us going forward.
Capital to be invested in the Permian in the second half 2016 will be focused on completion activity and acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. The total capital ascribed to acreage holding in Delaware Basin is just over $230 million in 2016. We currently have 3 rigs running in Delaware Basin and expect to keep them active through the remainder of 2016.
Now onto the Mid-Continent. You will recall that we began drilling the latest Woodford development project on the east side of the Cana core in the fourth quarter 2015. This development covers 6 sections, of which Cimarex operates 2 sections. This infill project consists of 47 gross, 22 net wells. Drilling is finished and completion of the wells has again been moved up and is now scheduled for early September versus October that was discussed in our last call. This change in scheduling was a contributing factor to our increasing capital expenditures for 2016.
As for the Meramec, we continue to drill wells to both hold our acreage and delineate our acreage position. Of note, our 2 of our most recent Meramec results, the Peterson and Sims long laterals, whose location can be seen on Slide 19 of the presentation. The Peterson 1H-2821X located on the Northwest part of our Meramec acreage position achieved a 30-day peak average rate of 19 million cubic equivalent per day, of which 54% was oil, 30% gas, 16% NGL. While the Sims 1H-2017X located in the southeastern part of our Meramec acreage achieved a 30-day average rate of 12.8 million cubic feet equivalent per day, 29% oil, 46% gas, 25% NGL. These 2 bookend wells on our acreage are good confirmation of our ability to adjust both the landing zone and frac design to achieve very good rate of return -- results across the breadth of our Meramec acreage, and it's why we have chosen to keep 2 rigs running throughout the remainder of the year holding Meramec acreage.
Finally, to better understand the multi-zone potential for this area, we have recently finished drilling an 8-well stacked/staggered spacing pilot in the Meramec and Woodford formations. See Slide 21 for an illustration of this design. These wells are scheduled to begin completion operations later this month with first production anticipated in the fourth quarter. Results from another Meramec spacing pilot were recently announced by our partner, Devon. The Alma pilot wells had an average IP of 1,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 60% was oil. The completion of these wells was influential in the stimulation design for the Meramec wells in our stacked/staggered pilot with the final Meramec design using 2,600 pounds of sand per lateral foot. Cimarex holds a 46% working interest in this pilot.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our second quarter production, our Q3 and full year '16 production outlook and then finish up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. As Tom mentioned,
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining our call today. I'll touch on the usual items, our second quarter production, our Q3 and full year '16 production outlook and then finish up with a few comments on LOE and service cost. 
As Tom mentioned, we had yet another great quarter for production with stronger than expected base property and new well performance really driving the quarter. Our second quarter volumes came in better than anticipated. Our reported Q2 total company net equivalent production of 974 million a day beat our guidance projection of 935 million to 965 million, and was up slightly to our Q1 reported volume of 973 million a day rather than down, as we had anticipated last call.
As expected, with accelerated completion activity and increased processing capacity during the second quarter, we saw a nice boost in our Permian production with the addition of a second frac crew in May. We completed 9 Permian wells during the quarter as compared to just 3 in the first quarter. As a result, our second quarter Permian equivalent volume came in at 509 million a day, that's up 32 million a day or 7% from the first quarter.
In the Mid-Continent, continued strong well performance from our Cana-Woodford project, which came online in late fourth quarter last year, supported both our Q1 and our Q2 Mid-Continent volumes. And with that support, our second quarter Mid-Continent equivalent volume averaged 463 million a day, that's up 44 million a day or 11% from Q2 '15. But as expected, with only 5 new wells in the Mid-Continent coming online during the quarter, our second quarter Mid-Continent volumes decreased 30 million a day as compared to Q1.
So as we look forward into the last half of '16, we're projecting further acceleration of completion activity in both our Mid-Continent and Permian programs. And as a result, we're projecting a total of 72 net wells to come online during the year as compared to the 60 net wells we projected last call, with 7 of those additional wells being located in the Permian and 5 in the Mid-Continent.
In the Mid-Continent, we've moved up the start dates for Cana infill development project to September, as has been previously stated. And that's, again, versus our previous estimate of October. And in the Permian, with planned addition of the third rig in August, we've also accelerated our completion activity for the most part in fourth quarter, for both of our Bone Spring and Reeves County Wolfcamp programs. As a result, we now anticipate having 22 net wells waiting on completion at year-end, with 11 in both the Mid-Continent and the Permian, and that's down from the 46 total wells that we had waiting on completion here at the end of Q2.
With our strong first half performance and our planned acceleration and completion activity, we've increased our total company full year production guidance to 0.98 to 1 Bcfe per day, that's up from our previous guidance of 940 million to 970 million a day, and would put us, in essence, flat to 2% higher than our 2015 average of 985 -- 984.5 million a day. More importantly, our planned acceleration -- accelerated completion activity gives us very strong momentum going into 2017 with our forecasted Q4 exit rate in the range of 1.02 to 1.07 Bcfe per day, that's 3% to 9% higher than the 986 million a day we posted in Q4 '15. Our oil production plays a big role in our projected Q4 exit rate, with our Q4 Permian and Mid-Continent net oil volumes forecasted to be up 12% to 17% from the volumes that we reported in Q2.
For Q3 '16, with 10 net Permian wells and 3 net Mid-Continent wells expected to come online during the quarter, we're guiding our total company net equivalent volumes to be in the range of 950 million to 980 million a day. That's, in essence, flat with the second quarter. And as we move into Q4, our completion activity really picks up steam with 15 net Permian wells and 26 net Mid-Continent wells planned to come online in the fourth quarter.
Shifting gears to OpEx. We had a nice guidance beat for the second quarter LOE, and we owe it all to our production groups' continued and dedicated efforts to optimally reduce our overall operating cost structure. With their focus, we once again saw sizable cost reductions during the quarter and similar components in quarters past, saltwater disposal, compression, rentals, contract labor. And as such, our Q2 lifting cost came in at $0.65 per Mcfe, well below the low end of our guidance, which was $0.80 to $0.90, down 19% from our first quarter average of $0.80 per Mcfe, and down 22% from the $0.83 we averaged in 2015.
So after incorporating our continued cost control efforts and also taking into account the fluctuating nature of workover expenses, we've projected our remaining year lifting cost to be in the range of $0.60 to $0.75 per Mcfe.
I want to take a moment just to say we're extremely proud of our entire production ops team for their success, and safely and effectively reducing our LOE. The progress is sizable. Since prices began falling back in 2014, we've seen our absolute monthly net LOE drop approximately $9 million a month, which on an annualized basis, has, in essence, freed up over $100 million a year that we can direct to our drilling program.
And finally, on service cost. Some very similar comments to our last call with regard to drilling and completion cost, most all of our drilling cost components have remained relatively in check, while we have seen some modest reductions in per-unit completion cost, primarily in the Permian. On the drilling side, we've kept our focus on efficiencies, as illustrated with our average 2016 Bone Spring spud to rig release drill time of 10 days, that's down from 12 days in '15 and 14 days in 2014. 
On the completion side, we've seen continued cost reductions in the Permian, both from a frac cost standpoint as well as in the cost to source our water, which has really helped to negate the additional cost of us pumping larger jobs. 
As we continue to increase our frac size, completion dollars continue to dominate our total well cost, representing up to 2/3 of the individual total well cost for each well. As in quarters past, we've been able to offset the costs of the larger fracs with lower per unit pumping costs. And as such, most of our generic AFEs have remained somewhat in check as compared to last quarter. An exception, however, is our Permian Bone Spring program where both drilling and completion efficiencies have reduced our current 1 mile lateral AFEs to $4.7 million to $5.1 million, that's down 6% from the $5 million to $5.4 million that we quoted last quarter.
In the Wolfcamp, with larger completions, our current generic 2-mile lateral Culberson AFEs continue to run in the $10.2 million to $11.2 million range. That's flat to last call, but down 5% from where we were in Q4, and down 23% from that program's AFE back in late 2014.
With our larger frac design, our Cana core 1-mile lateral Woodford AFE is running in the range of $7.1 million to $7.5 million, up from the $6.6 million to $7 million range we previously quoted with the smaller frac, but right in line with the $500,000 to $600,000 anticipated increase that we quoted last call, should we adopt and implement the larger fracs, which we are. But even with a larger frac, our current Cana 1-mile Woodford well is down 10% on a total well cost as compared to late 2014.
As we drill more 2-mile lateral Meramec wells, our current AFEs are running in the range of $10.7 million to $11.4 million, all the while, we continue to experiment with various frac designs and landing depths and so on.
In closing, we had another great quarter. We made tremendous strides reducing our overall operating cost structure. We stayed -- we're staying focused on efficiencies to reduce and optimize our drilling and completion costs, and we continue to make good progress maximizing the productivity and profitability of our wells.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Q&A.

componenttext: Drew, this is John. And I'll just echo what Tom just said. I mean, it is very early and the flowback of the wells are now just cleaning up. I will just say, operationally, everything went just fine from a frac standpoint, everything looked good. So we'll just -- time will tell as we flow them back. And as we get enough data on hand, and hopefully, in the near future, we'll get to talk about it.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing, if I could just tandem to. We're really fascinated. I mentioned in my opening remarks that it's 2 things we're seeing with a lot of these Wolfcamp wells. One is the enhanced well performance. But the other is the lower decline from our longer l
componenttext: One thing, if I could just tandem to. We're really fascinated. I mentioned in my opening remarks that it's 2 things we're seeing with a lot of these Wolfcamp wells. One is the enhanced well performance. But the other is the lower decline from our longer laterals, and that's -- I don't want that to be lost on observers. It's really a remarkable result and it takes some time to watch that and see it stabilized. In fact, some wells we have there have been on for 6 months are still surprising us. And so it's -- we'll talk about it as soon as we can make conclusions.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'll follow-up with Tom. He's absolutely right in that it's difficult -- it's very difficult to really predict an ultimate EUR for some of these wells until a good 4, 5, 6 months out that we finally start seeing some form of decline, so we can th
componenttext: I guess, I'll follow-up with Tom. He's absolutely right in that it's difficult -- it's very difficult to really predict an ultimate EUR for some of these wells until a good 4, 5, 6 months out that we finally start seeing some form of decline, so we can then model what it's ultimately going to end up at. So that's a good problem to have, quite frankly, but it just means it takes quite a while before we finally reach a point we feel really good about that ultimate EUR will be for the well.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The results are great. I think they keep surprising to the upside, I guess, which kind of begs the question of how do you progress through this completion design evolution? You have obviously a ton of projects that you want to execute on, and it seems lik
componenttext: The results are great. I think they keep surprising to the upside, I guess, which kind of begs the question of how do you progress through this completion design evolution? You have obviously a ton of projects that you want to execute on, and it seems like the more and more you test bigger and more complex completions, you keep getting much, much more return than the capital you put in. So how is the -- what's your strategy for reaching that optimal well design the quickest?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one is pick up the pace in our capital and that's a significant reason and justification why we decided to keep 5 rigs going and accelerate our completions, this gives us more laboratories. And I'm very proud of our organization and the degree of in
componenttext: Well, one is pick up the pace in our capital and that's a significant reason and justification why we decided to keep 5 rigs going and accelerate our completions, this gives us more laboratories. And I'm very proud of our organization and the degree of innovation that they're undertaking. We study our competitors hard. And I think you all know us well enough to not be surprised by that statement. But it's also strength of Cimarex to be in 2 of the most active basins in the country. To be in the Delaware Basin and the STACK play means that we have 2 independent laboratories and we can draw and bring best practices from one play to another. And that has also been a really big part of our success and we're just getting warmed up there. We have lots of things that are on our list to try, and many of them are things that have been tried in 1 basin but haven't been tried in the other.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is John. I think, the only other comment I'd make is we put a lot of debate internally on these frac design changes. And we involve all disciplines when it comes to that. And then, we measure ourself quickly. Like you pointed out, there's increme
componenttext: And this is John. I think, the only other comment I'd make is we put a lot of debate internally on these frac design changes. And we involve all disciplines when it comes to that. And then, we measure ourself quickly. Like you pointed out, there's incremental capital involved that does drive up our overall total costs, and so we're asking ourself, what type of improvement justifies this. What should we be looking for early in the life of these wells that say, this is a good investment decision, keep moving forward with it. And quite frankly, once we achieve that in the middle, we're asking ourself, okay, can we go even further, what's next? And now, that's what I'm kind of proud of is that we are not resting on our laurels here. And as much as I really love the landscape right now of what we've achieved and what it looks like from a rate of return perspective, we are not going to then just sit and kind of say, okay, this is it. We're going to keep pushing because there's still so much that we're learning about these rocks and these frac designs that I still think there's lot of potential there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Will Derrick from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Will Derrick from SunTrust.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first question, looking at the stack and everything you've got going around there. In Canadian County specifically, curious what's your thoughts on those initial wells are and what your plans are for activity going forward there?
componenttext: I guess, first question, looking at the stack and everything you've got going around there. In Canadian County specifically, curious what's your thoughts on those initial wells are and what your plans are for activity going forward there?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, this is John. I guess, you're referencing in particular Canadian County where we have drilled a number of Meramec wells, including the latest one we just talked about, which is the -- our Sims well. That area, I would just say, has been a
componenttext: All right. Well, this is John. I guess, you're referencing in particular Canadian County where we have drilled a number of Meramec wells, including the latest one we just talked about, which is the -- our Sims well. That area, I would just say, has been a little bit of a challenge for the Meramec than necessarily say more of the Blaine, Kingfisher, but that's why we're proud of that Sims result down there in that part of the play. I think that's also why we decided to add a little bit more capital because now, we feel a little bit better about that area. But it's also one that's going to take a little bit more drilling as we get more comfortable with landing zone and frac design. And again, I want to stress that, there is no one recipe here in the Meramec saying 1 area that works best across the whole play, we're definitely changing things up and adapting to results. And again, I'll just emphasize, that's why we really like that Sims result, that one really has given us a little bit more -- definite more encouragement toward that part of the Meramec play.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really a dream story. And you hear us talking about the variability in the Meramec, we've been around that Sims well, we had some results from ourselves and competitors that led us to think, oh, should we drill this well or not. And we tried some dif
componenttext: It's really a dream story. And you hear us talking about the variability in the Meramec, we've been around that Sims well, we had some results from ourselves and competitors that led us to think, oh, should we drill this well or not. And we tried some different things and it's a stunning and surprisingly positive result. And that tells us, you know what, it's not over until it's over. This Meramec really is a function of landing zone and completion design, and that section has lots of surprises left, and thus far, it's surprising to the upside.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you quantify the differences in completion that you've had in Blaine County versus on the Sims well?
componenttext: Could you quantify the differences in completion that you've had in Blaine County versus on the Sims well?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John, and I'm going to broad brush strokes maybe. The differences, clearly, there's always the amount of sand we pump. There are going to be differences in the cluster design, cluster spacing. And quite frankly, there's differences on whethe
componenttext: Well, this is John, and I'm going to broad brush strokes maybe. The differences, clearly, there's always the amount of sand we pump. There are going to be differences in the cluster design, cluster spacing. And quite frankly, there's differences on whether or not we use diverters. And all of those are kind of in our bag of tricks to look at. I will just say, right now, state that again, the Peterson design was way different than the Sims design. And what we're trying to do now is go out there and check on that, do a couple more wells and see, does one work better in one area than one in the other? And then, we'll continue to progress from there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, I just wanted to ask on capital allocation. It looks like you guys have a -- it looks like a pretty good problem given all your impressive results across multiple geographic areas. So just how are you thinking about prioritization of capital by both
componenttext: Tom, I just wanted to ask on capital allocation. It looks like you guys have a -- it looks like a pretty good problem given all your impressive results across multiple geographic areas. So just how are you thinking about prioritization of capital by both geographic area and zone? And I guess, what I'm getting at is what gets the first call and how do you rank your plays right now?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Jason. And it is a challenge and it's a pretty high-class problem to have. We have 2 outstanding plays and we have an outstanding acreage positions in both plays, and acreage positions that allows for 10,000-foot long horizontal wel
componenttext: It's a great question, Jason. And it is a challenge and it's a pretty high-class problem to have. We have 2 outstanding plays and we have an outstanding acreage positions in both plays, and acreage positions that allows for 10,000-foot long horizontal wells. You sum all that together and it's real dilemma on how we allocate capital. Now I will say, as I said in the past, that some of our best well level returns are in the Bone Spring, in the Delaware Basin. Certainly, the 10,000-foot long Wolfcamp wells are fantastic and getting better. And as John said, the Avalon is really roaring to compete heads-up with everything I just mentioned. I would say the Delaware at the well level rate of return is at the top of the pack. But that Anadarko story is evolving and not very far behind. If some of these new landing zones and new stimulations, if the Sims, Peterson and some of the wells announced by our competitors, if these results are repeatable across large portion of our 115,000 Meramec acres, then it's going to really give a [indiscernible] on how we allocate capital because there's also science in delineation we want to do. So we're always balancing with the absolute high rate of return on our next investment, with looking 5, 10 years ahead, what information do we want and when do we want it? So in terms of capital allocation, we're going ahead with 3 rigs in the Delaware and 2 rigs in the STACK play, and we think both those rigs or both those programs are designed to give us a lot of information, both landing zone, completion optimization and geological delineation. And so we're fairly comfortable with that 3-rig Delaware, 2-rig Anadarko right now. If prices were to improve materially, I think, it's a function of if oil or gas improves. But right now, the Delaware is probably the strongest voice for incremental capital if we were to increase above and beyond that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, my follow-up is one thing you guys didn't really discuss in the prepared was Reeves County where a Cabinet State well also looks really, really strong and on a shorter laterals. So can you maybe just talk about that well? What you guys did? A
componenttext: And I guess, my follow-up is one thing you guys didn't really discuss in the prepared was Reeves County where a Cabinet State well also looks really, really strong and on a shorter laterals. So can you maybe just talk about that well? What you guys did? And does that maybe drive you guys to flock more towards shorter laterals in that play?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. Yes, shame on me. The Cabinet State is an outstanding well, and we're very, very pleased with that result. And the reality is, I wish I could've made it a 10,000-foot lateral, but that particular case, we were landlocked to hold that a
componenttext: Well, this is John. Yes, shame on me. The Cabinet State is an outstanding well, and we're very, very pleased with that result. And the reality is, I wish I could've made it a 10,000-foot lateral, but that particular case, we were landlocked to hold that acreage as a 5,000-foot lateral. And in that particular play, we clearly, in our own minds, have demonstrated the uplift of going to 10,000. So just imagine taking the Cabinet State, taking to 10,000, it would be even that much better. I think, what you're also seeing at Cabinet State is, again, and Tom does a nice job of talking about this, just as leveraging frac design changes, say, in the upper Wolfcamp and Culberson over to Reeves and back and forth, and that's a good example, along with we have our major development there next to the Big Timber where we're about to start fracking with the Wood wells. We're clearly taking that frac design that we implemented overall in the upper Wolfcamp pilot there over to those wells. So we're seeing really good results there throughout that part of Reeves County, and we're very excited about it and we've got a lot of drilling to do there, remainder of this year and the next year. And then, finally, when I think about it, the thing also that's changing there, and we talked a lot about, is landing zone. We are definitely getting much more comfortable in Reeves as to where we want to land those wells, and I think it's leading to the kind of result you're seeing as well. So it's kind of a combination of those -- kind of sounds like a broken record, but both frac, uplift and landing zone.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jason, the true to answer to that is this has been a real active week for earnings release amongst our competitors and we're sensitive that you all are living on 1 hour sleep and Red Bull, so we decide to keep our prepared remarks short.
componenttext: And Jason, the true to answer to that is this has been a real active week for earnings release amongst our competitors and we're sensitive that you all are living on 1 hour sleep and Red Bull, so we decide to keep our prepared remarks short.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell from Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the Avalon, can it attract a rig to itself in 2017, or does it need to be part of a more regional strategy?
componenttext: Regarding the Avalon, can it attract a rig to itself in 2017, or does it need to be part of a more regional strategy?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is John. I've got a lot of people in Midland who love to have a rig on the Avalon. And again, we have certain priorities that we need to meet no matter what. We still have acreage we need to hold in the Wolfcamp, and that will clearly be someth
componenttext: Well, this is John. I've got a lot of people in Midland who love to have a rig on the Avalon. And again, we have certain priorities that we need to meet no matter what. We still have acreage we need to hold in the Wolfcamp, and that will clearly be something we will fund. But I will tell you, this well result has definitely caused us to ask what's next. And I would not be surprised if we go back up on that acreage and push the envelope again in terms of our stimulation design and with a long lateral, that's the one thing, I think, next step we'd like to take in the Avalon is get a long lateral under our belt with this type of stimulation and then really see what kind of rate of returns we can achieve. And then, probably, the next step for us is then spacing. We've already announced before that we did spacing pilots in the past in the Avalon. We feel very good at 8 wells per section for individual interval. And again, there are multiple intervals in the Avalon. We probably will need to go out there and test tighter spacing, but we're also blessed that we have a lot of competitors in and around our HBP acreage who are doing just that. So we're not in a vacuum there. So we'll learn a lot from looking across the fence. But yes, I think it's safe to say, we'll at least get a little bit more capital, at least I'm going to argue for that, for some wells next year to test further within that play next year.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was good color. I'd like to ask a little bit broader question for my follow-up. I was wondering what the Meramec updip versus downdip drilling strategy might be over, say, 2017 and 2018? And to what extent, if any, this might be influenced by the mul
componenttext: That was good color. I'd like to ask a little bit broader question for my follow-up. I was wondering what the Meramec updip versus downdip drilling strategy might be over, say, 2017 and 2018? And to what extent, if any, this might be influenced by the multi-zone potential that you showed on Slide 21?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. As far as -- let me just address first updip, downdip. I mean, that's a nice little display we put out there, but in no way does that influence where we go with the rig. Right now, honestly, that rig is going to HBP acreage. The 2 rigs that
componenttext: This is John. As far as -- let me just address first updip, downdip. I mean, that's a nice little display we put out there, but in no way does that influence where we go with the rig. Right now, honestly, that rig is going to HBP acreage. The 2 rigs that are remaining the rest of this year as well as going into next year is earmarked to holding acreage, and some of that acreage is both updip and some of it is downdip. Again, what's nice is we're achieving very good returns in both areas that we want to justify that capital, which is why we're keeping the 2 rigs. So I don't know that we'd make huge distinction just yet in terms of that, in terms of where we would send the rig, because again, we're trying to hold acreage. And then, I'm sorry, what -- your second part of that, I'm sorry, was what?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, really, what I was really thinking is, I mean, sort of thinking simplistically and trying to look at what -- greater number of wells over the play as a whole. It seems like the updip tends to be oilier than the downdip, but the Alma pilot,
componenttext: Well, I guess, really, what I was really thinking is, I mean, sort of thinking simplistically and trying to look at what -- greater number of wells over the play as a whole. It seems like the updip tends to be oilier than the downdip, but the Alma pilot, it was pretty impressive, got a pretty impressive oil cut there, and I'm wondering if there's any influence from having 2 zones producing there as opposed to, say, targeting the Meramec kind of theoretically oilier area?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, all I'll say there is there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us and our competitors. I think, at last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite frankly, we have an interest in most of them, so we'll be an avid watcher of
componenttext: Well, all I'll say there is there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us and our competitors. I think, at last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite frankly, we have an interest in most of them, so we'll be an avid watcher of those results as well as our own pilot that we'll be starting completions on here soon. I don't know that we ourself fully understand the full STACK potential of this play, I guess, to use that acronym. We just don't know yet. We feel pretty good where we put our Leon Gundy that there's enough thickness there to justify the 2 layers within the Meramec with the 1 layer in the Woodford. And we're very -- we have high expectations for that pilot. Beyond that, I don't know how much more you can go beyond that, and time will tell. And then, you can also argue, how will it vary based on maybe that's what you're driving at versus the hydrocarbon component that is as I get into more oilier window, can I stack more or not, or vice versa? Those are the things we just don't know yet for this play.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of variables here, updip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure. We will study every well on the trend, and I will tell you that we keep a fairly evergreen list where we look at every well and rank them by their rate of return. And we
componenttext: There's a lot of variables here, updip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure. We will study every well on the trend, and I will tell you that we keep a fairly evergreen list where we look at every well and rank them by their rate of return. And we focus on rate of return. And that's what we're going for. And so we've talked in the past, we have a bias towards pressure, we have a bias towards deliverability, but our real bias is towards rate of return. And if we were to look at rate of return, this map would be contoured a little differently. And we're pretty excited about the potential for us.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons, Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons, Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, with these very strong well results, do you see this lowering your threshold oil and gas price necessary to move beyond 5 rigs if you wanted to add some? So essentially, if the oil number say was $50, does it move down to $45? Or likewise, on gas, do
componenttext: Tom, with these very strong well results, do you see this lowering your threshold oil and gas price necessary to move beyond 5 rigs if you wanted to add some? So essentially, if the oil number say was $50, does it move down to $45? Or likewise, on gas, does it move, say, to below $3. Just want to get your thoughts around that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question. And I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story. And you can go back to what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance improvemen
componenttext: Well, that's a great question. And I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story. And you can go back to what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance improvements, our cost reductions and certainly, that LOE reduction is really an important part of the story. Our breakeven cost have come way down, and that's true both in the Anadarko and in Delaware Basin. So I will say that Cimarex looks pretty, pretty good in the mid-40s, $2.50 to $3 gas environment. We have tremendous returns throughout our portfolio and we are achieving fully burdened results that are historically high within our program. So it's not so much -- in answering your question, it's not so much about price as it is stability. We're one who manage our balance sheet. We watch our cash flow and we're absolutely committed to be disciplined and keep the health of this company second to none. And so what we're looking for isn't necessarily an absolute price signal as it is price stability. And ramping up our capital as we did is probably, to us, a strong vote of confidence on our assets. And we think that if prices were stable at $45 and the $2.50 to $3 gas range, we've got a great landscape ahead of us. And I've said in the past, we're not waiting for the rescue boat to save us. Our challenge to the organization was to figure out how to make a living in this environment. And I will say that our organizations respond to that call in every way, both in increased well performance and decreased costs and lease operating. So we're in pretty good shape if we see stability.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. That's excellent color. My follow-up is just to make sure I heard this correctly in the prepared remarks. So you're targeting 15% growth in oil production from Q2 to Q4, and that's based on your acceleration?
componenttext: Excellent. That's excellent color. My follow-up is just to make sure I heard this correctly in the prepared remarks. So you're targeting 15% growth in oil production from Q2 to Q4, and that's based on your acceleration?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that was my foot in my mouth. Joe said 12% to 17%.
componenttext: Well, that was my foot in my mouth. Joe said 12% to 17%.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're in the middle.
componenttext: You're in the middle.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the midpoint of our range. But Joe, why don't you handle that.
componenttext: Yes, that's the midpoint of our range. But Joe, why don't you handle that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That is quite simply a byproduct of our CNR oriental [ph] project in the Permian come on here in Q3 and in Q4, as well as the oil that's associated with our Anadarko Basin completions. Now the real wild card there is timing because in late Q3, early
componenttext: Yes. That is quite simply a byproduct of our CNR oriental [ph] project in the Permian come on here in Q3 and in Q4, as well as the oil that's associated with our Anadarko Basin completions. Now the real wild card there is timing because in late Q3, early Q4, we've got a fair number of wells scheduled to come on, and a week or 2 slip here can really impact those numbers. But the way we forecasted it, we could be anywhere from 12% to 17% higher combined in our total company oil production.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Magee from GMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Magee from GMP Securities.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between the short and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's fairly early on, but I was wondering if you think there will be any material differences in overall returns between
componenttext: I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between the short and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's fairly early on, but I was wondering if you think there will be any material differences in overall returns between the longer laterals and the deeper overpressure window versus the more shallow regular pressure window, and if you think the longer lateral seem to make sense in both areas?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. I guess, I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of return we achieve, and we've demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But again,
componenttext: This is John. I guess, I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of return we achieve, and we've demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But again, it's fair to say, the majority of our portfolio is in pressured rock, and that's where most of our experience. We do not have a lot of experience in drilling long laterals and lower pressured -- close to normal pressure type rocks. And something else also happens. We've talked a lot about this. Once you move up in that normal pressured part of the play, more oilier play, you're talking about a part of a play were it's shallower, so your cost to get there, the vertical part of it, is very inexpensive. You don't need that extra string of pipe, you drill it very quickly. And a lot of times, when we think about long laterals, we love them because it's pretty expensive for us to get there to, to get to the target, so once we're there, we want to stay there as long as we can. In fact, I would argue, our drilling department wants to know why we stopped at 10,000 feet. And in some ways, internally, we talk about that. But the big difference is when you go updip, it's pretty cheap to get down there to get to the zone. So then, you got to ask yourself, operationally, does that extra 5,000 really gain you a lot or not. And we just don't have a lot of experience with that. I'll be honest with you. All our experience have been in the pressure but we're watching it very, very carefully ourselves. As Tom said, we're always looking across the fence and asking ourself, maybe, maybe in that shallower or normal pressure, maybe 5,000 is a better way to go than 10,000. I don't know that answer right now. We'll see over time.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just curious. Looking at the 4Q, implied 4Q rate. Just thinking about that level as well as the commentary around the oil growth to the fourth quarter. What sort of activity levels would you say or require to keep those levels at least flat as we
componenttext: I guess, just curious. Looking at the 4Q, implied 4Q rate. Just thinking about that level as well as the commentary around the oil growth to the fourth quarter. What sort of activity levels would you say or require to keep those levels at least flat as we look towards 2017? And is your anticipation at this point, given the current strip, that you would actually still be pressing to grow those levels?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, why don't you handle that?
componenttext: Mark, why don't you handle that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Mark. For early '17, too much guidance around '17, but as we've now changed our plans to be going from 3 to 5 rigs, staying in 5 rigs permitted in  second half of '16. As you go into '17, 5 to 7 rigs, I would call, is a pretty good place,
componenttext: Michael, this is Mark. For early '17, too much guidance around '17, but as we've now changed our plans to be going from 3 to 5 rigs, staying in 5 rigs permitted in  second half of '16. As you go into '17, 5 to 7 rigs, I would call, is a pretty good place, we could be flat to growing slightly into '17. Again, lots of work that still needs to be done. We still need to get comfortable with where the commodity is at and all those kinds of caveats, Michael. But 5 -- we're exiting in a very good pace into '17. And I think a 5 to 7-rig program would keep us flat or grow slightly.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. What I might add on there is our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty high level, company-wise, and it's going into '17. So there's a couple of ways looking at it. Now on a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking about is doab
componenttext: This is Joe. What I might add on there is our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty high level, company-wise, and it's going into '17. So there's a couple of ways looking at it. Now on a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking about is doable. But we're going to get these oscillated production profiles with a lot of these infill projects. So for us to always -- and we've talked about this in, I think, our first quarter call. A lot of these perceptions that your exit rate has a lot to do with what's your next year's average is going to be at. I think, we all need to take a little bit of caution in that because we're going to see highs and lows and highs and lows as some of these big projects come online.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the challenges we face is we're in a constant inflection point with the quality of our assets. And also, as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is we're just not that good at forecasting on things that are difficult to forecast, and improved well
componenttext: One of the challenges we face is we're in a constant inflection point with the quality of our assets. And also, as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is we're just not that good at forecasting on things that are difficult to forecast, and improved well performance is the biggest of them all. But with our asset quality, we have the wind on our backs on that. So we're pretty optimistic as we look ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful color. And then, I guess, my follow-up, just kind of bigger picture. You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think, it was Slide 30 or so where you outlined the progression of proppant loading over time. I'm just curious, as we t
componenttext: Great. That's helpful color. And then, I guess, my follow-up, just kind of bigger picture. You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think, it was Slide 30 or so where you outlined the progression of proppant loading over time. I'm just curious, as we think about a reacceleration of activity from the industry over the coming years, I guess, in theory anyway, if oil prices go up, how would you think about proppant loading as cost inflation comes back into the picture? Meaning, is it harder to carry such high proppant loads without the big benefit of cost inflation that was seen from the cyclical pressures, if that makes sense?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. I'm not sure I fully understand the question. Are you saying as far as availability?
componenttext: This is Joe. I'm not sure I fully understand the question. Are you saying as far as availability?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like would you not have increased proppant loading to the extent that you have were it not for the cyclical benefits you've gotten from improved pricing from service vendors, such that if things move the opposite way theoretically, we expect some inflatio
componenttext: Like would you not have increased proppant loading to the extent that you have were it not for the cyclical benefits you've gotten from improved pricing from service vendors, such that if things move the opposite way theoretically, we expect some inflation down the road. Would proppant loading be an area where you would reduce well costs going -- at some point in the future [indiscernible]

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been such that we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total overall cost have come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus Q1, in
componenttext: I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been such that we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total overall cost have come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus Q1, in Q2, we pumped about, as a company, 21% more fluid and 12% more sand, yet our crude well frac cost was maybe down 10%. It all comes down to what John just said earlier. It's going to be a matter of economics. So if these prices do creep up, or the cost do creep up, we're always going to be looking at, for that job, what will it cost? What are the results we expect to achieve pumping that job? And does it merit going at the larger job or should we deviate somewhere plus or minus from there in design? So it's kind of a tough question to answer other than to tell you that we're constantly looking at current costs. We're constantly working hard to keep them low and we're constantly focused on rate of return.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last couple of
componenttext: Yes. That's the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last couple of years. But we've got the right wins, and I'm very confident we have the right wins, and its after-tax rate of return. And so yes, in answer to your question, some of the aggressiveness that we've had in adding to our proppant certainly has been facilitated by how low our cost structure has been. And if we have a pressure, either through commodity pricing or service cost, we're going to look at that on a rate of return basis and to find the optimal solution. We don't look at production rates and say, the highest production rate is our best solution. We always, always at Cimarex, look at rate of return on the investment it required. So I have a lot of confidence in free markets. If market forces cause us to find a different path forward, I think, our focus on rate of return is exactly the way to navigate that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: For Tom and John, I guess, I'm curious, you guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil window in Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down on the gas window in the southwest portion of the play, and then, obviously, in between the 2 extremes. I gue
componenttext: For Tom and John, I guess, I'm curious, you guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil window in Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down on the gas window in the southwest portion of the play, and then, obviously, in between the 2 extremes. I guess, Tom, based on the running list of operated and non-operated results and then the associated rates of return for all of those wells, what portion of the play do you feel consistently is at the top of the list based on rate of return?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide 21, certainly, there's a little area where those -- lot of stars cluster. It's right about where our pilot project has the arrow going through, it's near the Alma pi
componenttext: Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide 21, certainly, there's a little area where those -- lot of stars cluster. It's right about where our pilot project has the arrow going through, it's near the Alma pilot, certainly on Gumby pilot. That is a tremendous little soft area within the play. Cimarex has an outstanding well in there. Other operators do as well and that's certainly a really, really attractive part of the play, comparing the play overall. Now I will say, if you go up to where we've our Peterson well, that is emerging as really, really nice part of the play. You've seen the Peterson results. I will say, we're very pleased with our acreage position, our team has done a nice job of building a position up there, so we have really, really nice exposure there. But John, do you want to comment about the play in general?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties there, Kingfisher, Blaine, Canadian, we had a number of wells as our competitors had a number of really good wells, and that area still holds up as a very good area.
componenttext: Just to follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties there, Kingfisher, Blaine, Canadian, we had a number of wells as our competitors had a number of really good wells, and that area still holds up as a very good area. But without a doubt, this more Western Blaine area where our Peterson well is and some of our competitor wells have recently come on, it's starting to rise right up to the top there. It's an interesting area and I'm really, really proud of our team because that's an area where early on in this play, we got out there and grabbed some really good acreage at a really good price. That's really given us that nice yellow position we have where the Peterson well is located. So that's kind of in a broader way where most of the best returns that we see so far, but I don't think this story is done. I think there's still -- I'm fascinated, everyday another well comes on and we are surprised. Just the other day, another well came on in an area that we didn't think would be prospective and we are quickly looking at it and asking ourself, okay, what's going on there. So there's a lot of chapters to this story left to play out here in the Meramec for sure.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, since you mentioned it, can you kind of walk through the geologic differences between where that good Peterson well was in the Alma pilot and what you know today, I understand it's evolving, but kind of where you're at today?
componenttext: As a follow-up, since you mentioned it, can you kind of walk through the geologic differences between where that good Peterson well was in the Alma pilot and what you know today, I understand it's evolving, but kind of where you're at today?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different geologic setting for the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on what we
componenttext: It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different geologic setting for the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on what we call a updip position. And yet, we are seeing some really good frosty development in and around that Peterson area, which is leading to these really high IP rates we're seeing and leaning to the kind of results. So you may be sacrificing a little bit. I don't see that as a stack, meaning multilayer area in Peterson versus say, our Leon Gundy or even Alma area, but -- because you're not as thick, but boy, the rock looks pretty good there, though.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past, you've, and on this call as well, talked about Meramec variability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how has your thoughts evolved
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past, you've, and on this call as well, talked about Meramec variability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how has your thoughts evolved on variability across the play? And I guess, obviously, you have increased confidence with adding a second rig in there. But expectations in terms of variability as you move to different areas of the play, how have those changed and evolved, I guess, since last quarter and then, really, since last year?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we still we see the Meramec as highly variable. Perhaps one of the evolutions is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with landing zone and proper stimulation. One of the things that I think we've learned in
componenttext: Well, I think, we still we see the Meramec as highly variable. Perhaps one of the evolutions is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with landing zone and proper stimulation. One of the things that I think we've learned in the last year is that you cannot settle on a landing zone and carry that 6 or 8 miles and land a well in that same stratigraphic interval and expect comparable results. That said, what we're finding is the Meramec, because it is a series of prograding wedges, if you put yourself in a different wedge and find the right landing zone, you can find that you can overcome that variability. So we still see it as a highly variable play. I think, there are some announcements out of our competitors, that's adjusted to that. But we're soldiering on and we really like it. John, do you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the viability and how we adapt to it. And then, change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think, what -- really, in our vernacular, what it means is we will tear it differently. We'
componenttext: Yes. I think, what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the viability and how we adapt to it. And then, change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think, what -- really, in our vernacular, what it means is we will tear it differently. We'll have some areas that will be a certain part that we'll look at it from a way we want to drill it and frac it, and other areas would be different. It's not like our -- I would argue, our Woodford shale, it's a very consistent frac design, we want to deploy across all of that shale. It's a very homogeneous interval. That's not true in the Meramec. In the Meramec, you've got to adjust. And I think, over time, we're understanding what's required to get the kind of returns that we like across the breadth of our acreage. And again, the story will continue to evolve. And I'm sure, based on what I've seen, I think, our results will continue to get better as we get better understanding of this rock and what's going on here.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, it's important. We're speaking for Cimarex here. And some of our own style is overprinted on this. I think, some of our competitors have spoken about it as being a more uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they may be
componenttext: And I think, it's important. We're speaking for Cimarex here. And some of our own style is overprinted on this. I think, some of our competitors have spoken about it as being a more uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they may be talking about a different issue than we are. If you're saying it's a play where all the broad areas is developing top tier economic returns over broad areas, you can drill and get really good results on average, yes, it's a fairly uniform play. But I'll contrast the Meramec with the Woodford shale. The Woodford shale, we fairly early on and particularly with our own stimulations, got to a point where we think we understand the regional consistency. We can drill a well anywhere in our asset and fairly accurately predict the yield. And we're fairly comfortable at a fairly high-level making decisions. When we go to the Meramec, I will tell you that John and I get pretty into the weeds on looking at that stratigraphy, looking at landing zones, talking about completion styles because it is very variable. And as far into it as we are, it is still, in our opinion, a fascinating and challenging scientific project.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree. We had very stimulating meetings with every Meramec well we drill. And there isn't -- every Meramec well, in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Everyone, it's different in how we land it. It's different how we frac it. And I think that's go
componenttext: I agree. We had very stimulating meetings with every Meramec well we drill. And there isn't -- every Meramec well, in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Everyone, it's different in how we land it. It's different how we frac it. And I think that's going to continue for quite a while here until, finally, we settle in, in different areas or tiers as to what's best practice. And -- but we're getting there and I think that's what you're hearing from us is that we're getting more confident in how to plan those wells now going forward.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious, I saw the -- with the rig additions here, in the past, you guys have kind of outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of these things. I guess, one, and it's really kind of a 2-part question, is the 5 ri
componenttext: Curious, I saw the -- with the rig additions here, in the past, you guys have kind of outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of these things. I guess, one, and it's really kind of a 2-part question, is the 5 rigs -- does the 5 rigs sort of adequately answer what you would like to learn in early 2017? If not, what sort of shortfall is there? And 2, how do you sort of marry that now? I don't see any incremental activity going to the Cana just yet. And you do have a premier guest asset now with the strip, well above 3 into 2017. How do you marry an asset that's ready for full field development with attractive economics now versus trying to find all this knowledge in your other plays?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy trying to juggle everything you just described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of the kind of returns, espec
componenttext: This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy trying to juggle everything you just described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of the kind of returns, especially now that we look at it as a long lateral development. And again, keep that in mind, everything up-to-date in Cana has been 5,000 feet, but given the continuity of our acreage that we, along with our AMI partner, Devon, have, we, together, are starting to have those discussions over long lateral development. And indeed, I think, you will hear from us in the coming quarters start talking more about where that next development will take place for us. This well we're about to bring on is pretty exciting. It's more liquid rich part of the Cana-Woodford shale. I'm also excited because our partner there, Devon, has drilled 4 2-mile lateral, so we'll get a chance to see those in the development phase, how they look. And we have a wonderful position between the two of us just north of that, that we call the 13 8 area that we definitely see a long lateral development, it's just a question of the two of us coming together at some point and planning that out and then we'll see when that starts. So you're absolutely right. Cana looks very good, but it's also a matter of how do you get that funded versus everything else that we're trying to answer in the Meramec and in the Wolfcamp and every other play we have. The other comment I want to make real quick is we really did a lot early in this year with our spacing pilots. And yes, we don't have a lot to talk on just yet, but we put a lot of capital early in the year in these pilots in the Wolfcamp and in the Meramec, and that's really going to set us up very well for the coming years when we start moving to full-scale development where we get the kind of confidence to deploy those large amount of capital, say, in the Wolfcamp or the Meramec like we are already today for the Woodford, and that's just going to put even more pressure on Tom to open up the first ring and let us spend more money as we get there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just to add on to what John said. We are really high in the Woodford. And you're right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford. It's a good question. But part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodford is w
componenttext: David, just to add on to what John said. We are really high in the Woodford. And you're right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford. It's a good question. But part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodford is we need to understand that Meramec, so that when we develop out here, we really exploit this resource in the most prudent fashion. We have to understand how many landing zones we have. We have to understand the full potential of the Meramec. The thing we absolutely do not want to do is go into Cana-Woodford development and then find out that the Meramec was left behind, and that if we come in and get it later, we have a real production interference and disruption. So part of our aggressiveness in testing the Meramec is to set ourselves up for codevelopment between the Woodford and the Meramec, and we still have a lot of things to learn. So we're high on the Woodford, probably higher today than we've ever been.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question for today comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our final question for today comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
