was pretty impressive, got a pretty impressive oil cut there, and I'm wondering if there's  
any influence from having 2 zones producing there as opposed to, say, targeting the  
Meramec kind of theoretically oilier area?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, all I'll say there is there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us  and our competitors. I think, at last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite  frankly, we have an interest in most of them, so we'll be an avid watch
componenttext:
Well, all I'll say there is there's a lot of spacing pilots that are being drilled by us  
and our competitors. I think, at last count, there were 10 of them, I believe. And quite  
frankly, we have an interest in most of them, so we'll be an avid watcher of those results  
as well as our own pilot that we'll be starting completions on here soon. I don't know  
that we ourself fully understand the full STACK potential of this play, I guess, to use  
that acronym. We just don't know yet. We feel pretty good where we put our Leon Gundy that  
there's enough thickness there to justify the 2 layers within the Meramec with the 1 layer  
in the Woodford. And we're very -- we have high expectations for that pilot. Beyond that,  
I don't know how much more you can go beyond that, and time will tell. And then, you can  
also argue, how will it vary based on -- maybe that's what you're driving at -- versus the  
hydrocarbon component that is as I get into a more oilier window, can I stack more or not,  
or vice versa? Those are the things we just don't know yet for this play.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of variables here, updip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure. We  will study every well on the trend, and I will tell you that we keep a fairly evergreen  list where we look at every well and rank them by their rate of return. A
componenttext:
There's a lot of variables here, updip, downdip, oil, gassy, pressure, non-pressure. We  
will study every well on the trend, and I will tell you that we keep a fairly evergreen  
list where we look at every well and rank them by their rate of return. And we focus on  
rate of return. And that's what we're going for. And so we've talked in the past, we have  
a bias towards pressure, we have a bias towards deliverability, but our real bias is  
towards rate of return. And if we were to look at rate of return, this map would be  
contoured a little differently. And we're pretty excited about the potential before us.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons, Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons, Piper Jaffray.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, with these very strong well results, do you see this lowering your threshold oil and  gas price necessary to move beyond 5 rigs if you wanted to add some? So essentially, if  the old number say was $50, does it move down to $45? Or likewise, on g
componenttext:
Tom, with these very strong well results, do you see this lowering your threshold oil and  
gas price necessary to move beyond 5 rigs if you wanted to add some? So essentially, if  
the old number say was $50, does it move down to $45? Or likewise, on gas, does it move,  
say, to below $3. Just want to get your thoughts around that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question. And I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story.  And you can go back to what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's  changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance impr
componenttext:
Well, that's a great question. And I'll say this. Certainly, this is an evolving story.  
And you can go back to what we said a quarter ago or 2 quarters ago, and the world's  
changed just in the last 3 or 6 months. Certainly, with our performance improvements, our  
cost reductions and certainly, that LOE reduction is really an important part of this  
story. Our breakeven cost have come way down, and that's true both in the Anadarko and in  
the Delaware Basin. So I will say that Cimarex looks pretty, pretty good in the mid-40s,  
$2.50 to $3 gas environment. We have tremendous returns throughout our portfolio and we  
are achieving fully burdened results that are historically high within our program. So  
it's not so much -- in answering your question, it's not so much about price as it is  
stability. We want to manage our balance sheet. We watch our cash flow and we're  
absolutely committed to be disciplined and keep the health of this company second to none.  
And so what we're looking for isn't necessarily an absolute price signal as it is price  
stability. And ramping up our capital as we did is probably, to us, a strong vote of  
confidence on our assets. And we think that if prices were to stable at $45 and the $2.50  
to $3 gas range, we've got a great landscape ahead of us. And I've said in the past, we're  
not waiting for the rescue boat to save us. Our challenge to the organization was to  
figure out how to make a living in this environment. And I will say that our organizations  
has respond to that call in every way, both in increased well performance and decreased  
costs and lease operating. So we're in pretty good shape if we see stability.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. That's excellent color. My follow-up is just to make sure I heard this  correctly in the prepared remarks. So you're targeting 15% growth in oil production from  Q2 to Q4, and that's based on your acceleration?
componenttext:
Excellent. That's excellent color. My follow-up is just to make sure I heard this  
correctly in the prepared remarks. So you're targeting 15% growth in oil production from  
Q2 to Q4, and that's based on your acceleration?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that was my foot in my mouth. Joe said 12% to 17%.
componenttext: Well, that was my foot in my mouth. Joe said 12% to 17%.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're in the middle.
componenttext: You're in the middle.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the midpoint of our range. But Joe, why don't you handle that.
componenttext: Yes, that's the midpoint of our range. But Joe, why don't you handle that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That is quite simply a byproduct of us seeing our intel project in the Permian come  on here in Q3 and in Q4, as well as the oil that's associated with our Anadarko Basin  completions. Now the real wild card there is timing because in late Q3, ea
componenttext:
Yes. That is quite simply a byproduct of us seeing our intel project in the Permian come  
on here in Q3 and in Q4, as well as the oil that's associated with our Anadarko Basin  
completions. Now the real wild card there is timing because in late Q3, early Q4, we've  
got a fair number of wells scheduled to come on, and a week or 2 slip here can really  
impact those numbers. But the way we forecasted it, we could be anywhere from 12% to 17%  
higher combined in our total company oil production.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Magee from GMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Magee from GMP Securities.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between the short  and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's still fairly early on, but I was wondering  if you think there will be any material differences in overall retu
componenttext:
I appreciate all the color you've provided on the production differences between the short  
and long laterals in the STACK. And I know it's still fairly early on, but I was wondering  
if you think there will be any material differences in overall returns between the longer  
laterals in the deeper overpressure window versus the more shallow regular pressure  
window, and if you think the longer laterals seem to make sense in both areas?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. I guess, I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that  incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of  return we achieve, and we've demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But a
componenttext:
This is John. I guess, I'll take a stab at that. In general, we do believe that  
incremental capital you spend on a longer lateral is well worth it relative to the rate of  
return we achieve, and we've demonstrated that throughout our portfolio. But again, it's  
fair to say, the majority of our portfolio is in pressured rock, and that's where most of  
our experience. We do not have a lot of experience in drilling long laterals in lower  
pressured -- close to normal pressure type rocks. And something else also that happens.  
We've talked a lot about this. Once you move up in that normal pressured part of the play,  
more oilier play, you're also talking about a part of the play were it's shallower, so  
your cost to get there, the vertical part of it, is very inexpensive. You don't need that  
extra string of pipe, you drill it very quickly. And a lot of times, when we think about  
long laterals, we love them because it's pretty expensive for us to get there, to get to  
the target, so once we're there, we want to stay there as long as we can. In fact, I would  
argue, our drilling department wants to know why we stop at 10,000 feet. And in some ways,  
internally, we talk about that. But the big difference is when you go updip, it's pretty  
cheap to get down there to get to the zone. So then, you got to ask yourself,  
operationally, does that extra 5,000 feet really gain you a lot or not. And we just don't  
have a lot of experience with that. I'll be honest with you. All our experience has been  
in the pressure but we're watching it very, very carefully ourselves. As Tom said, we're  
always looking across the fence and asking ourself, maybe, maybe in that shallow or normal  
pressure, maybe 5,000 is a better way to go than 10,000. I don't know that answer right  
now. We'll see over time.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just curious. Looking at the 4Q, implied 4Q rate. Just thinking about that level  as well as the commentary around the oil growth to the fourth quarter. What sort of  activity levels would you say are required to keep those levels at least fl
componenttext:
I guess, just curious. Looking at the 4Q, implied 4Q rate. Just thinking about that level  
as well as the commentary around the oil growth to the fourth quarter. What sort of  
activity levels would you say are required to keep those levels at least flat as we look  
towards 2017? And is your anticipation at this point, given the current strip, that you  
would actually still be pressing to grow those levels?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, why don't you handle that?
componenttext: Mark, why don't you handle that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Mark. It's a little early '17, too much guidance around '17, but as we've  now changed our plans to be going from 3 to 5 rigs, staying at 5 rigs through the  remainder of the second half of '16. If you go into '17, 5 to 7 rigs, I woul
componenttext:
Michael, this is Mark. It's a little early '17, too much guidance around '17, but as we've  
now changed our plans to be going from 3 to 5 rigs, staying at 5 rigs through the  
remainder of the second half of '16. If you go into '17, 5 to 7 rigs, I would call, is a  
pretty good place, we could be flat to growing slightly into '17. Again, lots of work  
still needs to be done. We still need to get comfortable with where the commodity's at and  
all those kinds of caveats, Michael. But 5 -- we're exiting in a very good pace into '17.  
And I think a 5- to 7-rig program would keep us flat or grow slightly.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. What I might elaborate on there is that our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty  high level, company-wise, and it's going into '17. So there's a couple ways of looking at  it. On a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking
componenttext:
This is Joe. What I might elaborate on there is that our Q4 projection puts us at a pretty  
high level, company-wise, and it's going into '17. So there's a couple ways of looking at  
it. On a year-over-year comparison, certainly, what Mark is talking about is doable. But  
we're going to get these oscillated production profiles with a lot of these infill  
projects. So for us to always -- and we've talked about this in, I think, our first  
quarter call. A lot of these perceptions that your exit rate has a lot to do with what  
your next year's average is going to be, I think, we all need to take a little bit of  
caution in that because we're going to see highs and lows and highs and lows as some of  
these big projects come online.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the challenges we face is we're in a constant inflection point with the quality of  our assets. And also, as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is we're just not that good  of forecasters on things that are difficult to forecast, and improve
componenttext:
One of the challenges we face is we're in a constant inflection point with the quality of  
our assets. And also, as Joe said, timing. Truth of the matter is we're just not that good  
of forecasters on things that are difficult to forecast, and improved well performance is  
the biggest of them all. But with our asset quality, we have the wind at our backs on  
that. So we're pretty optimistic as we look ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful color. And then, I guess, my follow-up, just kind of bigger picture.  You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think, it was Slide 30 or so where you  outlined the progression of proppant loading over time. I'm just curious, a
componenttext:
Great. That's helpful color. And then, I guess, my follow-up, just kind of bigger picture.  
You have a pretty compelling slide there. I think, it was Slide 30 or so where you  
outlined the progression of proppant loading over time. I'm just curious, as we think  
about a reacceleration of activity from the industry over the coming years, I guess, in  
theory anyway, if oil prices go up, how would you think about proppant loading as cost  
inflation comes back into the picture? Meaning, is it harder to carry such high proppant  
loads without the big benefit of cost deflation that was seen from the cyclical pressures,  
if that makes sense?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. I'm not sure I fully understand the question. Are you saying as far as  availability?
componenttext:
This is Joe. I'm not sure I fully understand the question. Are you saying as far as  
availability?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like would you not have increased proppant loading to the extent that you have were it not  for the cyclical benefits you've gotten from improved pricing from service vendors, such  that as things move in the opposite way, and theoretically, we expect
componenttext:
Like would you not have increased proppant loading to the extent that you have were it not  
for the cyclical benefits you've gotten from improved pricing from service vendors, such  
that as things move in the opposite way, and theoretically, we expect some inflation down  
the road. Would proppant loading be an area where you would reduce well costs going -- at  
some point in the future, you know what I mean by that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been  such that we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total  overall costs have come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus
componenttext:
I think so. With regard to well cost, we have been very fortunate that the market has been  
such that we've been able to increase our job sizes at the same time that our total  
overall costs have come down. As an example, if you just look at Q2 versus Q1, in Q2, we  
pumped about, as a company, 21% more fluid and 12% more sand, yet our per-well frac cost  
was maybe down 10%. It all comes down to what John just said earlier. It's going to be a  
matter of economics. So if these prices do creep up, or the costs do creep up, we're  
always going to be looking at, for that job, what will it cost? What are the results we  
expect to achieve pumping that job? And does it merit going with the larger job or should  
we deviate somewhere plus or minus from there in design? So it's kind of a tough question  
to answer other than to tell you that we're constantly looking at current costs. We're  
constantly working hard to keep them low and we're constantly focused on rate of return.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's that the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just  yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand  that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last
componenttext:
Yes. It's that the last point I want to jump in on. Joe does a great job tracking. Just  
yesterday, we were looking at our total well cost as measured by cents per pound of sand  
that we're pumping. And it's remarkable how far that's come in the last couple of years.  
But we've got the right lens, and I'm very confident we have the right lens, and its  
after-tax rate of return. And so yes, in answer to your question, some of the  
aggressiveness that we've had in adding to our proppant loads certainly has been  
facilitated by how low our cost structure has been. And if we have a pressure, either  
through commodity pricing or service cost, we're going to look at that on a rate of return  
basis and try to find the optimal solution. We don't look at production rates and say, the  
highest production rate is our best solution. We always, always at Cimarex, look at rate  
of return on the investment it required. So I have a lot of confidence in free markets. If  
market forces cause us to find a different path forward, I think, our focus on rate of  
return is exactly the way to navigate that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Guffey from Stifel.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: For Tom and John, I guess, I'm curious, you guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil  window, and Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down to a gas window in the southwest  portion of the play, and then, obviously, in between the 2 extremes.
componenttext:
For Tom and John, I guess, I'm curious, you guys have drilled the Meramec well on the oil  
window, and Kingfisher, also you've gone all the way down to a gas window in the southwest  
portion of the play, and then, obviously, in between the 2 extremes. I guess, Tom, based  
on the running list of operated and non-operating results and then the associated rates of  
return for all of those wells, what portion of the play do you feel consistently is at the  
top of the list based on rate of return?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide  21, certainly, there's a little area where those -- lot of stars cluster. It's right about  where our pilot project has the arrow going through, it's near the A
componenttext:
Well, yes, I'll answer that and then John will jump in. There's a -- as you look on Slide  
21, certainly, there's a little area where those -- lot of stars cluster. It's right about  
where our pilot project has the arrow going through, it's near the Alma pilot, it's near  
Leon-Gundy pilot. That is a tremendous little sub-area within the play. Cimarex has some  
outstanding wells in there. Other operators do as well, and that's certainly a really,  
really attractive part of the play, comparing the play overall. Now I will say, if you go  
up to where we've our Peterson well, that is emerging as really, really nice part of the  
play. You've seen the Peterson results. I will say, we're very pleased with our acreage  
position, our team has done a nice job of building a position up there, so we have really,  
really nice exposure there. But John, do you want to comment about the play in general?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties  there, Kingfisher, Blaine, Canadian, we had a number, as well as our competitors, had a  number of really good wells, and that area still holds up as a very goo
componenttext:
Just to follow-up on what Tom said. Early on, that kind of intersection of the 3 counties  
there, Kingfisher, Blaine, Canadian, we had a number, as well as our competitors, had a  
number of really good wells, and that area still holds up as a very good area. But without  
a doubt, this more Western Blaine area where our Peterson well is and some of our  
competitor wells have recently come on, it's starting to rise right up to the top there.  
It's an interesting area and I'm really, really proud of our team because that's an area  
where early on in this play, we got out there and grabbed some really good acreage at a  
really good price. That's really given us that nice yellow position we have where the  
Peterson well is located. So that's kind of in a broad way where most of the best returns  
that we see so far, but I don't think this story is done. I think there's still -- I'm  
fascinated, every day another well comes on and we are surprised. Just the other day,  
another well came on in an area that we didn't think would be prospective and we are  
quickly looking at it and asking ourself, okay, what's going on there. So there's a lot of  
chapters to this story left to play out here in the Meramec for sure.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow-up, since you mentioned it, can you kind of walk through the geologic  differences between where that good Peterson well was in the Alma pilot and what you know  today, I understand it's evolving, but kind of where you're at today?
componenttext:
As a follow-up, since you mentioned it, can you kind of walk through the geologic  
differences between where that good Peterson well was in the Alma pilot and what you know  
today, I understand it's evolving, but kind of where you're at today?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different geologic setting for  the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the  Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on w
componenttext:
It's just kind of hard to describe. You are in a little bit different geologic setting for  
the Peterson than where you are with the Alma. You're in a little bit thicker part of the  
Meramec with the Alma than you are in the Peterson, you're more on what we call an updip  
position. And yet, we are seeing some really good prospy development in and around that  
Peterson area, which is leading to these really high IP rates we're seeing and leading to  
the kind of results. So you may be sacrificing a little bit. I don't see that as a stack,  
meaning multilayer area in Peterson versus say, our Leon Gundy or even Alma area, but --  
because you're not as thick, but boy, the rock looks pretty good there, though.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past, you've, and on this call as well, talked  about Meramec variability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of  successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how has your thoughts ev
componenttext:
Okay. Great. And then, I guess, Tom, in the past, you've, and on this call as well, talked  
about Meramec variability. I guess, after the 2 new successful results and a flurry of  
successful competitor wells, I'm just curious, how has your thoughts evolved on  
variability across the play? And I guess, obviously, you have increased confidence with  
adding a second rig in there. But expectations in terms of variability as you move to  
different areas of the play, how have those changed and evolved, I guess, since last  
quarter and then, really, since last year?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we still we see the Meramec as highly variable. Perhaps one of the  evolutions is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with  landing zone and proper stimulation. One of the things that I think we've learn
componenttext:
Well, I think, we still we see the Meramec as highly variable. Perhaps one of the  
evolutions is that we think you have a great chance of overcoming that variability with  
landing zone and proper stimulation. One of the things that I think we've learned in the  
last year is that you cannot settle on a landing zone and carry that 6 or 8 miles and land  
a well in that same stratigraphic interval and expect comparable results. That said, what  
we're finding is the Meramec, because it is a series of prograding wedges, if you put  
yourself in a different wedge and find the right landing zone, you can find that you can  
overcome that variability. So we still see it as a highly variable play. I think, there  
were some announcements out of our competitors, that's adjusted to that. But we're  
soldiering on and we really like it. John, do you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the variability and  how we adapt to it. And then, change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think, what  -- really, in our vernacular, what it means is we will tier it differen
componenttext:
Yes. I think, what it means is we are getting more comfortable with the variability and  
how we adapt to it. And then, change the recipe, so to speak, in each area. I think, what  
-- really, in our vernacular, what it means is we will tier it differently. We'll have  
some areas that will be a certain part that we'll look at it from a way we want to drill  
it and frac it, and other areas will be different. It's not like our -- I would argue, our  
Woodford shale, it's a very consistent frac design we want to deploy across all of that  
shale. It's a very homogeneous interval. That's not true in the Meramec. In the Meramec,  
you've got to adjust. And I think, over time, we're understanding what's required to get  
the kind of returns that we like across the breadth of our acreage. And again, the story  
will continue to evolve. And I'm sure, based on what I've seen, I think, our results will  
continue to get better as we get better understanding of this rock and what's going on  
here.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, it's important. We're speaking for Cimarex here. And some of our own style is  overprinted on this. I think, some of our competitors have spoken about it as being a more  uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they
componenttext:
And I think, it's important. We're speaking for Cimarex here. And some of our own style is  
overprinted on this. I think, some of our competitors have spoken about it as being a more  
uniform play, and we don't mean to contradict that. I just -- they may be talking about a  
different issue than we are. If you're saying it's a play where over broad areas it's  
developing top tier economic returns, over broad areas you can drill and get really good  
results on average, yes, it's a fairly uniform play. But I'll contrast the Meramec with  
the Woodford shale. The Woodford shale, we fairly early on and particularly with our new  
stimulations, got to a point where we think we understand the regional consistency. We can  
drill a well anywhere in our asset and fairly accurately predict the yield. And we're  
fairly comfortable at a fairly high level making decisions. When we go to the Meramec, I  
will tell you that John and I get pretty into the weeds on looking at that stratigraphy,  
looking at landing zones, talking about completion styles because it is very variable. And  
as far into it as we are, it is still, in our opinion, a fascinating and challenging  
scientific project.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree. We had very stimulating meetings with every Meramec well we drill. And there  isn't -- every Meramec well, in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Every one, it's  different in how we land it. It's different in how we frac it. And I think
componenttext:
I agree. We had very stimulating meetings with every Meramec well we drill. And there  
isn't -- every Meramec well, in some ways, we -- there is no 1 template. Every one, it's  
different in how we land it. It's different in how we frac it. And I think that's going to  
continue for quite a while here until, finally, we settle in, in different areas or tiers  
as to what's best practice. And -- but we're getting there and I think that's what you're  
hearing from us is that we're getting more confident in how to plan those wells now going  
forward.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Deckelbaum from KeyBanc.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious, I saw the -- with the rig additions here, in the past, you guys have kind of  outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of  these things. I guess, one, and it's really kind of a 2-part question, is th
componenttext:
Curious, I saw the -- with the rig additions here, in the past, you guys have kind of  
outlined goals and you alluded to that before of how quickly you want to learn some of  
these things. I guess, one, and it's really kind of a 2-part question, is the 5 rigs --  
does the 5 rigs sort of adequately answer what you would like to learn in early 2017? If  
not, what sort of shortfall is there? And 2, how do you sort of marry that now? I don't  
see any incremental activity going to the Cana just yet. And you do have a premier gas  
asset now with the strip, well above 3 into 2017. How do you marry an asset that's ready  
for full field development with attractive economics now versus trying to find all of this  
knowledge in your other plays?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy trying to juggle everything you just  described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our  future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of the kind of returns,
componenttext:
This is John. Well, it certainly keeps us busy trying to juggle everything you just  
described. In regards to Cana, I'm just going to tell you, I'm extremely excited for our  
future drilling activity in Cana from the standpoint of the kind of returns, especially  
now that we look at it as a long lateral development. And again, keep that in mind,  
everything up-to-date in Cana has been 5,000 feet, but given the continuity of our acreage  
that we, along with our AMI partner, Devon, have, we, together, are starting to have those  
discussions over long lateral development. And indeed, I think, you will hear from us in  
the coming quarters start talking more about where that next development will take place  
for us. This row about to bring on is pretty exciting. It's a more liquid rich part of the  
Cana-Woodford shale. I'm also excited because our partner there, Devon, has drilled 4 2- 
mile laterals, so we'll get a chance to see those in the development phase, how they look.  
And we have a wonderful position between the two of us just north of that, that we call  
the 13 8 area that we definitely see a long lateral development, it's just a question of  
the two of us coming together at some point and planning that out and then we'll see when  
that starts. So you're absolutely right. Cana looks very good, but it's also a matter of  
how do you get that funded versus everything else that we're trying to answer in the  
Meramec and in the Wolfcamp and every other play we have. The other comment I want to make  
real quick is we really did a lot earlier this year with our spacing pilots. And yes, we  
don't have a lot to talk about them just yet, but we put a lot of capital early in the  
year in these pilots in the Wolfcamp and in the Meramec, and that's really going to set us  
up very well for the coming years when we start moving to full-scale development where we  
get the kind of confidence to deploy those large amount of capital, say, in the Wolfcamp  
or the Meramec like we are already today for the Woodford, and that's just going to put  
even more pressure on Tom to open up the purse string and let us spend more money as we  
get there.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, just to add on to what John said. We are really high on the Woodford. And you're  right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford. It's a good  question. But part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodfor
componenttext:
David, just to add on to what John said. We are really high on the Woodford. And you're  
right in your observation that, wait a minute, what about the Woodford. It's a good  
question. But part of the way that we are honoring the quality of the Woodford is we need  
to understand that Meramec, so that when we develop out here, we really exploit this  
resource in the most prudent fashion. We have to understand how many landing zones we  
have. We have to understand the full potential of the Meramec. The thing we absolutely do  
not want to do is go into Cana-Woodford development and then find out that the Meramec was  
left behind, and that if we come in and get it later, we have a real production  
interference and disruption. So part of our aggressiveness in testing the Meramec is to  
set ourselves up for codevelopment between the Woodford and the Meramec, and we still have  
a lot of things to learn. So we're high on the Woodford, probably higher today than we've  
ever been.

componenttext:

September. How many wells is that? And then you could talk a little bit about the  
completion design around that program?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, it's -- for us, it's 47 gross wells, 22 net wells, and we operate  the westernmost 2 sections. We will be coming into it with 1 frac crew in September. Devon  will match it up with 1 frac crew. Very quickly, we'll then have 2
componenttext:
Well, as I said earlier, it's -- for us, it's 47 gross wells, 22 net wells, and we operate  
the westernmost 2 sections. We will be coming into it with 1 frac crew in September. Devon  
will match it up with 1 frac crew. Very quickly, we'll then have 2 frac crews to finish  
out our 2 sections. And then, Devon, I think, has plans to bring in a second frac crew a  
little bit later in the year so they can get theirs done. Although, I think, theirs  
extends into next year, I'm not -- I don't recall. Does it, Mark?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, it does, John. Yes.
componenttext: Yes, I think, it does, John. Yes.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can also tell you that when we look at it, it is definitely more liquid rich than, say,  what we experienced in our previous row development. In fact, I asked the team the other  day, when we hit peak production, the net production we expect off tha
componenttext:
I can also tell you that when we look at it, it is definitely more liquid rich than, say,  
what we experienced in our previous row development. In fact, I asked the team the other  
day, when we hit peak production, the net production we expect off that row at peak will  
be about 49% gas, 34% NGLs and 17% oil. So kind of on a gas liquid basis, it's almost a  
50-50 split. And so again, that's why we're very encouraged. We think we're going to get  
very good returns out of this row. And as far as the completion itself, I think, Devon  
himself will speak to their wells. But for our wells, we are moving forward with the  
design that we deployed on the Armacost section. I think, if you refer to Page 30, we  
talked about that where we were up to 3,500 pounds per foot. We really, really like the  
results from the Armacost. In fact, we didn't even talk much about that, but we have a  
really nice slide showing how Armacost wells are behaving just as well as our other  
sections. And yet, we put an additional well within that section, new well. So we're able  
to get an extra well, and yet, still get similar results, meaning we're getting more  
reserves per section, out of that section. So we feel really good about that frac design.  
And that's what we intend on using going forward on our 2 operated sections.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext:

when you think about the Avalon. As you think about your Delaware Basin position, do you  
have a sense of how much of your acreage could be prospective for the Bone Spring, Avalon  
and Wolfcamp?

componenttextpreview: Sure. I would tell you that, certainly, all the acreage that we allude to on Slide 17, as  far as the 13,700 net acres of Avalon, have already -- Bone Spring, in fact, a lot of them  already have Bone Spring wells on them that we drilled in the past,
componenttext:
Sure. I would tell you that, certainly, all the acreage that we allude to on Slide 17, as  
far as the 13,700 net acres of Avalon, have already -- Bone Spring, in fact, a lot of them  
already have Bone Spring wells on them that we drilled in the past, some of them do, and  
certainly have Wolfcamp potential as well. Without a doubt, have Wolfcamp potential. And  
so that area alone in that part of Lea County definitely has all 3. And it's not just  
limited to those 3, there are multiple zones within each of those, both in the Wolfcamp  
and the Avalon, and potentially even in the Bone Spring. So it's a very, very target rich  
acreage position we have there. That again, it's HBP, it's not going anywhere, and yet, we  
recognize that there's a lot of potential there on that acreage. And again, this latest  
Avalon well just shows that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And please note, this event is being recorded.  Now I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Karen Acierno, Direc
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Cimarex Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And please note, this event is being recorded.  Now I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Karen Acierno, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, EVP of Explorations. And then Joe Albi, our C
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Today's prepared remarks will begin with an overview from our CEO, Tom Jorden, followed by an update on our drilling activities and results from John Lambuth, EVP of Explorations. And then Joe Albi, our COO, will update you on our operations including production of well costs. Our CFO, Mark Burford is also present to answer any questions. 
Yesterday afternoon, we posted an updated presentation to our website. We may be referring to this presentation during our call today. As a reminder, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements. A number of actions could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discussed. You should read our disclosures on forward-looking statements in our latest 10-K and other filings and news releases for the risk factors associated with our business. 
So that we can accommodate more of your questions during the hour we allotted for the call, I once again, ask that you limit yourselves to 1 question and 1 follow-up. Feel free to get back in the queue if you like. 
So with that, I'll turn it over to Tom.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. On the call today, John will walk us t
componenttext:
Thank you, Karen, and thanks to everyone who's participating in today's conference call. As always, we appreciate your interest and look forward to your questions during the question-and-answer portion of the call. 
On the call today, John will walk us through our recent results and describe our progress on the delineation projects that we have under way, and then Joe will follow John with a detailed operational overview. For the first time in a long time, our production came in below guidance. We average 947 million cubic feet equivalent per day in the third quarter, slightly below our guidance of 950 million to 980 million cubic feet per day. We expected third quarter to represent the low point in our production for the year. However, we faced delays in our completions, owing in large part, to the timing effect of our upsized simulations. We did not properly plan for significant impact or shedding on offset wells during completion operations, nor did we fully account for the 7 million cubic feet equivalent loss to higher ethane rejection. The combined effect of these factors caused us not only to miss on the third quarter, but to bring down the fourth quarter outlook as well. We don't like to miss our forecasts on any of these items and quite frankly, we need to do better. 
I think it's worthwhile to put the delay in our production trajectory into context. Cimarex responded swiftly and deliberately to the downdraft in commodity prices that reached its in February of this year. In the fall of 2014, we had 26 operated rigs range. We reached the low in summer of 2016 with 4 operated rigs. As we ramp our activity in the second half of 2016, a disproportionate amount of our operated and nonoperated drilling was on large multi-pud pilot development projects. This concentration of effort on a handful of large projects, put our production ramp at particular risk to timing delays. That said, we offer no excuses. We need to do a better job of risking these potential delays and building them into our forecasts. We've learned the hard way the wisdom of Yogi Berra, who said, "It's tough to make predictions especially about the future." 
Our 2016 exploration capital budget is now $785 million, that's up $35 million from previous estimates. The increase is tied primarily to the activity associated with rig additions this year, and approximately $15 million in seismic and acreage acquisitions we made in the third quarter. Even though our production ramp has been delayed into Q1 2017, much of the completion costs associated with this ramp will be incurred in 2016. 
In yesterday's release, we gave preliminary guidance for 2017. And I want to be clear that this is preliminary. We want to give some clarity on what 2017 looks for us, but these numbers for capital, for production, these are the baseline numbers. We certainly have tremendous wherewithal to accelerate. We'll enter 2017 with great momentum as the aforementioned deferred completions come roaring back. We currently model total production growth in 2017 to be 9% to 14% year-over-year with an overweight in oil production embedded in this growth. We also gave guidance on drilling and completion portion of our capital. Based on our current plans, we plan to invest $600 million in those activities next year. $600 million is within our cash flow for 2017 as we currently model it. So again, we think of this as a baseline. We have the ability to add activity as the year unfolds and in fact, we're currently looking hard at several projects we have in the drawing board. As always, we will give you an updated look at our capital plans in our next call, that will be in February, and that will include our total EMD expenditures as well as our first quarter 2017 production. By then, I expect to have tremendous clarity on additional projects and what it looks like as we move ahead on that baseline. 
Enough about production. I want to spend a few minutes talking about what we're really excited about. We continue to foresee the envelope in completion optimization and innovation. We are seeing outstanding results that have implications for well spacing and landing zones. In both the Delaware and Anadarko basins, we're planning pilots for 2017 that will test even tighter well spacing. These tests have tremendous implications for the depth and richness of our inventory. We built Cimarex on exploration, and we are hard at work, developing new ideas. We have challenged our organization to develop new play concepts and opportunities, where the cost of entry is low and real value is created for our shareholders. 
Our organization has responded accordingly, and we are working on a number of ideas that hopefully, will be subjects for future quarterly calls. Idea generation, execution and innovation have always been the heartbeat of Cimarex and it's what distinguishes us from an outstanding field of competitors. We are playing to our strength as we seek that proprietary edge that lets us slip in ahead of the crowd. We are some of the finest assets and one of the finest organizations in the business. Stay tuned. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to John to provide further color on our program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. Cimarex invested $175 million on exploration and development d
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with a quick recap of our drilling activity in the quarter before getting into some of the specifics of our latest results and more color on our remaining 2016 plans. 
Cimarex invested $175 million on exploration and development during the third quarter. About 61% was invested in the Permian region, with the rest going toward activities in the Mid-Continent region. Company-wide, we brought 42 gross, 17 net wells on production during the quarter. We had an average of 5 operated rigs running during the quarter. These rigs were busy working the whole acreage, in both the Wolfcamp and Meramec plays. 
We have recently added to 3 rigs, 1 in the Anadarko and 2 in the Delaware Basin, and we have plans to add another rig in Anadarko by year end. While we work through our completion backlog, we will pick up the pace on our drilling activity as we head into 2017. 
As planned, during the third quarter, we brought the 67,500-foot [ph] long lateral Upper Wolfcamp wells online that comprise our spacing pilot in the Upper Wolfcamp in Culberson County. These completions used about 2,400 pounds of sand per foot, while also incorporating design parameters, such as stage phasing, cluster count and cluster spacing from some of our more recent current well frac designs. These wells have been flowing back now for just over 90 days and yet, we still have not achieved a peak 30-day average rate. This result is not unexpected since it usually takes our Upper Wolfcamp wells much longer to clean up and reach their peak production rates relative to the lower Wolfcamp Culberson wells.  The result of the phasing pilot are especially meaningful, in light of a recent results to further delineate the Upper Wolfcamp interval and Culberson County. 
Earlier this year, we completed the King Ben [ph] 2045 [ph] state unit 2H which is located in the western half of our Culberson acreage. On our presentation, Slide 10 identifies location of the Kingben [ph] well. Before this well, most of our Upper Wolfcamp drilling had been in the southeastern part of our acreage. This 10,000-foot lateral had a 30-day peak average rate of 2,057 barrels of oil equivalent per day, of which 1,192 barrels or 58% was oil. The Kingben was completed with 1,700 pounds of sand per lateral foot, and came online in late April. In its first 180 days, the well has cumulative production of 308,000 barrels of oil equivalent, including 169,000 barrels of oil. This excellent delineation result opens up our acreage on the western half of Culberson County, where we plan to do further testing in 2017. 
We also just finished drilling in Upper Wolfcamp well, north of the Kingben well and Eddy County, which depending on results, could open up even more acreage for development in the Upper Wolfcamp. Completion of that well is planned to begin in mid-January. 
We completed 17 gross, 10 net wells in the Permian during the third quarter. Fourth quarter capital and pacing will be focused on completion activities and acreage obligations across our Wolfcamp position in both Culberson and Reeves County. We currently have 5 rigs running at the Delaware Basin. 
Now on to the Mid-Continent. You all recall we began drilling the latest development project on the east side of the Cannacord in the fourth quarter of 2015, of which Cimarex operates 2 sections. Completion of was began in mid-September with all of the Cimarex operated wells now completed and beginning early stages of flowback. These wells, along with partner operated wells, should be coming on production over the next 2 quarters. 
We also completed the Leon Gundy wells, our stacked/staggered Meramec Woodford pacing pilot. These wells were brought on production in mid-October, thus, it is too early to discuss any results. We look forward to discussing these wells in more detail on our next call. We also continue to book delineate and hold our Meramec acreage. With our most recent well results in this play performing as expected relative to our expectations. Of the 4 rigs we plan to operate in our Anadarko Basin next year, 3 of them will be dedicated to holding our Meramec acreage. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe Albi.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining us on our call today. I'll start first, with our third quarter production results, then go into some detail on our revised Q4 '16 forecast and the result in 2016 production outlook, and then with an underne
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and thank you, all, for joining us on our call today. I'll start first, with our third quarter production results, then go into some detail on our revised Q4 '16 forecast and the result in 2016 production outlook, and then with an underneath of it look at our forecasted late Q4 ramp-up of production, I'll give you a glimpse of our preliminary 2017 production outlook. I'll then finish up with just a few comments on LOE and service costs. 
As Tom mentioned with the reported net equivalent daily volume of 947 million a day, our third quarter production came in just shy of our guidance range of 950 to 980. 2 main factors came into play when comparing our actual results to our guidance: First, we saw an an anticipated net volume reduction of approximately 7 million a day, as a result of ethane reduction associated with the processing of our share of outside operated Mid-Continent gas during the quarter. And secondly, we experienced approximately 13 [ph] million a day of production downtime completion times and the shut in of the wells associated with those completions. These 2 factors alone a way to the midpoint of our guidance. 
If we look at Q3 by region, with the pickup of our Permian completion activity in mid-Q2, our third quarter Permian volume of 517 million a day was up 2% from Q2 '16, while our third quarter Mid-Continent volume of 427 million a day was down 2% from the second quarter, a result of our beginning of the year's slowdown of Mid-Continent completion activity which we just recently picked up, as John mentioned, appear in late Q3.
Looking forward, before touching on our fourth quarter guidance, I want to provide a little color on our frac fleet utilization strategy. To provide consistency in our frac fleet utilization and operational results and maintain full control of timing and scheduling of our frac operations, we've opted to retain a consistent number of fleets to complete our wells. With the fluctuating rig schedule and a good mix of multiple and good projects, we carefully planned our inventory so as to minimize adding and dropping in crudes. If we didn't add in drop crudes, we'd risk the ability to pick up the crudes and iron, of which we worked so hard to develop our operational efficiencies. Which means that when any completion operation takes longer than expected, either due to an operation or weather issue, or as a result of changing completion design on the to pump a larger, more time-consuming job, there's a domino effect on the timing of all completion operations following in queue. Our wood stay completion is a great example. When we provided Q3 guidance, the then planned drop size required an 18-day time period to complete each 3 well pad. Subsequent to providing guidance, we changed the job design which required a 30-day time period to pump, and pushed back other wells from projects in queue. We saw this in the Mid-Continent as well. And as a result, we pushed out first production for some significant wells and projects that were previously forecasted in that production in early Q4, now to come on later in Q4, and pushed others out into 2017.
So in a nutshell, at the total company level, we've moved a number of our significant completions into late Q4 and a total net wells previously slated for late Q4 into early 2017. With large anticipated production increases from our pilot and infill projects, simply sliding first production 2 to 4 weeks, has a big impact when projecting volumes for 12-week quarterly time period and as a result, our Q4 production forecast dropped from our last quarter estimate. 
We have a number of significant infill projects forecasted for Q4 in both the Permian and Mid-Continent. In the Permian, we've revised our first production timing for our Woodstate project in Reeves County, with first production now forecasted for late November, December, early December, versus our last quarter estimate of October. With the revised completion timing, we've also moved first production for 5 net Permian wells, including  production from our Timtim project into early 2017. 
Similarly, in the Mid-Continent, revised timing for frac operations has pushed out the timing for first production from our East Cana infill project, with our operated [indiscernible] sections now scheduled to come online in November and December, and our nonoperated projects sections now forecasted to come on in the December to early 2017 time frame. As a result, 5 [ph] projected net Mid-Continent wells have also moved into 2017. So when the dust settles, our updated Q4 production guidance now sits at 945 million to 985 million a day, with a vast production ramp forecasted for the latter half of the quarter. With the increase, we're projecting December total company net equivalent volumes to be in excess of 1 Bcf a day. 
As Tom mentioned, we have put together a 9-rig plan for 2017, funded comfortably with projected 2017 cash flow projections using our current strip. But the carryover of our Q4 '16 completion activity and the anticipated ramp-up in associated production into 2017, we're projected a preliminary estimate of 1.05 to 1.1 Bcfe a day for our full year 2017 production. As compared to the midpoint of our current 2016 full year production guidance, this represents a 9% to 14% increase in production during 2017. 
As Tom did, I want to again emphasize as well, this is a very preliminary plan. The plan can change as a result of many factors, including changes in commodity prices and/or changes in any of our activity levels, our project selection and the timing of our capital deployment. 
Shifting gears to OpEx. We posted another nice guidance with our third quarter LOE, and we owe it all again to our production group's continued efforts to reduce operating cost structure. We commend our efforts and with our focus, we continue to realize significant cost reductions during the quarter, seeing some nice reductions in equipment and maintenance, contract labor and rentals in particular. As a result, Q3 lifting costs came in at $0.61 per Mcfe at the low end of our guidance range of $0.60 to $0.75, down 6% from Q2, and down 27% from the $0.83 we've posted in, for an average, in 2015. 
After incorporating our continued cost control efforts and the fluctuating nature of workover expenses, we're projecting our remaining lifting costs to be in the $0.60 to $0.70 range. 
And finally, some comments on drilling and completion costs. We continue to see our drilling costs coming [ph] remain relatively in check, and have seen completion costs components, for the most part, level off. That said, we're beginning to feel upward pressure on completion costs with any increase most likely to occur after the beginning of the year. With that, we continue to focus on efficiencies on the drilling side by cutting down drilling days, and on the completion side, by optimizing our completion design, optimizing our water sourcing and optimizing our pumping operations. 
With our costs in check, our generic well AFEs are flat to last quarter in the Permian. Our current Bone Spring 1 mile lateral AFEs are ranging $4.7 million to $5.1 million. That's flat last quarter but down 6% from earlier in the year. In the Wolfcamp, with larger completions and current -- our current generic 2-mile lateral coal Wolfcamp AFE continues to run in the $10.2 million to $11.2 million range, that again is flat to last call, but down 5% from Q4 '15, and down 23% from late 2014.
With our larger frac designs, our Cana core 1 mile lateral Woodford AFE continues to run in the range of $7.1 million to $7.5 million. That's up from the $6.6 million to the $7 million range we quoted with smaller frac survey in the year but were down 10% from late 2014. 
And finally, as we continued to experiment with frac design, our current 2-mile Meramec AFEs are running in the range of $10.5 million to $12 million, with the frac design really being largest cost variable in the total well costs for our Meramec wells. 
So in closing, we had another good quarter. We continue to make strides, reduce our operating cost structure, we've stayed focus on efficiencies to reduce and optimize total well costs, and we continue to make good progress, maximizing the productivity and profitability of our wells. Although we've seen our completion timing push out first production for a number of our bigger projects, due primarily to pumping bigger and bigger jobs, we're very pleased about our well results and for that matter, we're very pleased with our entire program. 
So with that, I now turn the call over to Q&A.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Arun Jayaram of JP Morgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Arun Jayaram of JP Morgan.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, Tom, is just thinking about the '17, call it preliminary outlook. A couple of questions around that. One, is if you look at your spending in the quarter, you've spent $175 million, and if you annualize that, you'd be at $700 million and
componenttext: My first question, Tom, is just thinking about the '17, call it preliminary outlook. A couple of questions around that. One, is if you look at your spending in the quarter, you've spent $175 million, and if you annualize that, you'd be at $700 million and your rig activity is ramping. So I'm just trying to put that into context relative to an initial DNC spend of $600 million because it does look like you're accelerating from that $175 million that you spent in Q3?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. [indiscernible] give you an overview answer, then I'm going to turn it over to Mark for the detail. The quarterly spending is really a function of drilling rigs but also completion timing, and it's driven not only by the pad development timing, but t
componenttext: Yes. [indiscernible] give you an overview answer, then I'm going to turn it over to Mark for the detail. The quarterly spending is really a function of drilling rigs but also completion timing, and it's driven not only by the pad development timing, but there's also a fair amount of nonoperated timing. That preliminary $600 million is an annualized rate if we kept those 9 rigs running throughout the course of the year. Quarterly spendings can fluctuate depending on how that gets bunched up. So Mark, do you want to add to that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. Arun, we have choppiness in our capital spend levels with the amount of completions we have in any one quarter. You actually have seen in the fourth quarter applied guidance has a quite an uplifting in capital cost for completions, whic
componenttext: Yes, that's right. Arun, we have choppiness in our capital spend levels with the amount of completions we have in any one quarter. You actually have seen in the fourth quarter applied guidance has a quite an uplifting in capital cost for completions, which we will have, a number of completions occurring in the fourth quarter, a lot of them later in the quarter. But you'll see an upward kick in 2017. And as Tom says, it's a 9-rig program, time with the capital and completion dollars in the capital program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Arun, and just to finish that thought. We're feeling really solid about the quality of our returns, the quality of our program and the things that we want to accomplish. So even though I know oil markets are a little nervous here at the last week, we
componenttext: Yes. Arun, and just to finish that thought. We're feeling really solid about the quality of our returns, the quality of our program and the things that we want to accomplish. So even though I know oil markets are a little nervous here at the last week, we're feeling a little better about some of the fundamentals. And so our bias, as we sit today and again, this is just today, but our bias is going to lean forward on that capital number. And we're looking at a lot of things that we want to get done and we'd like to get them done sooner rather than later. So I think there's a pretty good chance we'll be giving meaningful updates here in the next call.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just elaborate on that point. because the initial, again, understanding it's initial but right now if you look at our forecast and consensus, it's between $1 billion to $1.1 billion of EBITDA. So but the number that you put out there
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just elaborate on that point. because the initial, again, understanding it's initial but right now if you look at our forecast and consensus, it's between $1 billion to $1.1 billion of EBITDA. So but the number that you put out there last night would suggest quite a bit of free cash flow generation. So I'm just trying to understand is if you guys are thinking -- how you plan to balance growth versus potential free cash flow? And is there an intention as we think about modeling for next year to spend your cash flow, as you know this is a market that is a rewarding growth to a decent extent?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a remarkable reward with the remarkable awards. There's a pretty big difference with spreadsheet and an iron deployed in the ground. And we're poised for increased activity. We have lots of things to do. And our bias is going to be -- we don't have
componenttext: Well, a remarkable reward with the remarkable awards. There's a pretty big difference with spreadsheet and an iron deployed in the ground. And we're poised for increased activity. We have lots of things to do. And our bias is going to be -- we don't have a good interest in keeping our cash in our balance sheet. Our bias is going to be to activity. And we focus on the returns on that investment and as you all know, you all get tired, I sound like a broken record, growth is a nice outcome of really good, prudent investments. Now we're feeling pretty confident about those investment opportunities. Mark, do you want to comment on that?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Arun, as we've talked in the past over the last 6 months and we've continued to watch stabilization and commodity prices, it's been seeing some more stabilization occurring lately, but obviously, even more recently, there's been some more pressure on
componenttext: Yes. Arun, as we've talked in the past over the last 6 months and we've continued to watch stabilization and commodity prices, it's been seeing some more stabilization occurring lately, but obviously, even more recently, there's been some more pressure on oil recently with some of the oil pack discussions. But certainly with street forecast probably embeds a low mid-$50 oil price, is that kind of environment starts to play out into '17 and we're kind of comfortable that's good price to be working off as far as capital generation, certainly won't increase our capital level.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Arun, we, I would say from my viewpoint, I have a strong bias to spend our cash flow. And if we have any kind of signals of stability, and we think we're seeing those signals and we talked a lot about structural reset and end markets, and we feel lik
componenttext: Yes. Arun, we, I would say from my viewpoint, I have a strong bias to spend our cash flow. And if we have any kind of signals of stability, and we think we're seeing those signals and we talked a lot about structural reset and end markets, and we feel like we're starting to see that. And so our bias is going to be to spend our cash flow and possibly, that cash in our balance sheet is going to be invested. So we're looking at it carefully. It's a good question and you're right on point with the way we're viewing that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Drew Venker of Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: So on the '17 program, the capital plan indicates to me, at least, a very big uptick in capital efficiency, and I think that's clearly occurred on the well productivity side, is there an element of cost improvements at the well [ph] level for the further efficiencies that Joe talked about? And I did catch that you said costs really haven't gone down in 3Q [ph], so I was hoping you could provide some color there?

componenttext: Yes. Mark, why don't you take that capital efficiency, and in know Joel, you may some comments on costs.
