componenttext: Sorry if I missed this, but what is your preliminary guidance on other spending besides the $600 million for D&C? So in 2016, you're spending about $175 million on infrastructure and leasehold and capitalized interest and capitalized G&A and other? So what's the guidance for that -- those same items for 2017?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, it's Mark. We will give out guidance for other components in the February call. But you are on the point as far as what we're incurring for our other capital for this year. And so we still like to make some assumptions -- leasehold assumptions as far
componenttext: Joe, it's Mark. We will give out guidance for other components in the February call. But you are on the point as far as what we're incurring for our other capital for this year. And so we still like to make some assumptions -- leasehold assumptions as far as leasehold acquisition we want to build into our budget into those components and production capital will have to be settled out as well. But we'll make that -- those guidance figures when we give our February guidance. And also to make a point on the runway, the $600 million which we did give guidance, is drilling and completion capital only. And actually, as Arun actually asked earlier, that $175 million is total capital, which is not comparable to the $600 million of drilling completion capital. We actually incurred $125 million of drilling completion capital in the third quarter. That's the comparable number to the $600 million. So the run rate is for drilling and completion only of $600 million, and that's for the 9-rig program.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell of Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Campbell of Tuohy Brothers.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not to put a damper on wanting to spend more, but I actually thought 9% to 13% 2017 growth on a flat spend was rather impressive. Can you characterize what portion of the growth is completion carryover from 2016, maybe improved year-over-year well perform
componenttext: Not to put a damper on wanting to spend more, but I actually thought 9% to 13% 2017 growth on a flat spend was rather impressive. Can you characterize what portion of the growth is completion carryover from 2016, maybe improved year-over-year well performance or other factors like more efficient D&C?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a hard number to dissect, which is the component of carryover completion capital. We will be having a nice ramp into the fourth quarter from the wells that are completing. By December, as Joe mentioned, our exit rate would be over 1 Bcf a day. So w
componenttext: That's a hard number to dissect, which is the component of carryover completion capital. We will be having a nice ramp into the fourth quarter from the wells that are completing. By December, as Joe mentioned, our exit rate would be over 1 Bcf a day. So we're going to have a nice ramp going into next year. But dissect what component of next year is volume contribution is from carryover activity versus an improved performance is hard to dissect that.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, there are some. Clearly, we've borrowed a little from '16 into '17 in our capital spending level, but it's not a bunch. We just haven't calculated that, so.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, there are some. Clearly, we've borrowed a little from '16 into '17 in our capital spending level, but it's not a bunch. We just haven't calculated that, so.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joe. What I'd say there is that Q3, 947, and I mentioned December [indiscernible]. So there's 50 million a day of brand new production just entering 2017, and there's still a real climb into the first quarter with the other carryover that I mentio
componenttext: This is Joe. What I'd say there is that Q3, 947, and I mentioned December [indiscernible]. So there's 50 million a day of brand new production just entering 2017, and there's still a real climb into the first quarter with the other carryover that I mentioned, the 10 wells coming into 2017. So I wouldn't be surprised if we dissect it, but there's a fair percentage that is carryover.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe another way to think of it is maybe getting out over our skis too early, but just from -- based on what you're thinking about now, if you did do a 9-rig program, if that's what it ultimately ended up being, could you create similar growth in 2018?
componenttext: Maybe another way to think of it is maybe getting out over our skis too early, but just from -- based on what you're thinking about now, if you did do a 9-rig program, if that's what it ultimately ended up being, could you create similar growth in 2018?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On a 9-rig program and a similar type growth into '18, I think, would be difficult.
componenttext: On a 9-rig program and a similar type growth into '18, I think, would be difficult.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: But again, that's -- we haven't really gone in detail there. The thing that we like where we sit right now is we look at our assets, at current conditions, we're in an environment where spending within cash flow, we can generate growth and great profitabi
componenttext: But again, that's -- we haven't really gone in detail there. The thing that we like where we sit right now is we look at our assets, at current conditions, we're in an environment where spending within cash flow, we can generate growth and great profitability. And that's something that a couple of years ago, if you'd said -- $50 oil environment, was that a possibility? We would have been pretty challenged to say yes, but it's truly a testament to quality of our assets and what our organization has done in innovation on our stimulation. We're also getting our cost structure down, the LOE decrease is significant to us and what it does to our margins. So yes, just leaning in your opening question, we're pretty pleased with what the landscape looks to us as we model outyears.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Grigel of Macquarie.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the 2017, to hit one last item. On the non-op spend, some of your partners have talked about what could be a pretty material ramp in 2017 in the rig count. How do guys think about that, and how much of that has been factored into that $600 million
componenttext: Just on the 2017, to hit one last item. On the non-op spend, some of your partners have talked about what could be a pretty material ramp in 2017 in the rig count. How do guys think about that, and how much of that has been factored into that $600 million?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. First of all, to simply say, in the Permian, we don't have a lot of non-op that necessarily drives our program. We're basically 100% operators on those acreage, besides the Culberson JDA with Chevron. But in Culberson, we are the operator si
componenttext: This is John. First of all, to simply say, in the Permian, we don't have a lot of non-op that necessarily drives our program. We're basically 100% operators on those acreage, besides the Culberson JDA with Chevron. But in Culberson, we are the operator since we dictate the budget there. The bigger issue clearly is in Anadarko. First off, of course, we have an AMI partnership with Devon, and we work hand-in-hand. We're constantly feeding each other exactly our plans. And so we're able to easily put that into our budget forecasting. The area where it gets a little more cloudy, especially in the Meramec, is, yes, all of a sudden, we're getting hit with a lot of outside operated wells scattered throughout that play, a lot of activity that has caused probably a little bit more capital than we originally planned, but it's not a huge component. But we'll certainly -- we will be accounting for that going into next year as well. I'll point out, again, just like what I said early in the Permian, what you'll see shake out in Anadarko is once everybody kind of gets to the position of holding their acreage, then you get into where people start doing acreage swaps or trying to block up. And then that gives you greater control again over your capital plans. So in the short, we do account for it. We recognize it, but I don't see it as being a major component or something that's going to completely lead to a large outspend for us.

componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful. And then just a follow-up on the Permian side. You guys mentioned in the presentation that you're reevaluating 28,000 acres in Ward County. Could you provide some more color about what the reevaluation process is?

componenttext: Well, this is Tom. We talked about that. We do have some new ideas in Ward. Ward again is looking very interesting to us. And all I can say there is stay tuned. We had said in past years that Ward was challenged for a lot of reasons, not the least of which is some of the prior development. That we've taken [ph] new idea in order for Ward to be at the front of our play, front burner. And right now, it's front burner.

componenttext: Well, it's kind of all the above, and we're having to test some things. So we'll commenting on that in our future calls.

componenttextpreview: I guess, just on the '17, I know we'll get more color in February, but there's $700 million of cash in the balance sheet. So as we think about your potential desire, so when we do see some stability to kind of lean in, is all of that on the table, or how
componenttext: I guess, just on the '17, I know we'll get more color in February, but there's $700 million of cash in the balance sheet. So as we think about your potential desire, so when we do see some stability to kind of lean in, is all of that on the table, or how should we think about the magnitude of potential outspend?

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's all on the table. We raised our capital to bring our net asset value forward, and that still was sitting there waiting to do. Now we'll probably deploy that over a couple of years. I don't think you'd see us say, hey, Katie bar the doors, we're
componenttext: Well, it's all on the table. We raised our capital to bring our net asset value forward, and that still was sitting there waiting to do. Now we'll probably deploy that over a couple of years. I don't think you'd see us say, hey, Katie bar the doors, we're going to run through that money in 1 year. But I think that is certainly there, poised for meaningful acceleration. And that's our bias. I mean that's what we want to do. We have no interest in keeping cash in our balance sheet.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Hanson of MorningStar.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Hanson of MorningStar.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just thinking about the mix there of long versus kind of "short laterals" as we head into 2017. I guess all else equal, is your preference for long laterals? I think you said that in the past. But as we think about the 2017 plan, kind of 1 versus 1.5 vers
componenttext: Just thinking about the mix there of long versus kind of "short laterals" as we head into 2017. I guess all else equal, is your preference for long laterals? I think you said that in the past. But as we think about the 2017 plan, kind of 1 versus 1.5 versus 2-mile laterals, if you could comment on that, that would be great.

headline: Cimarex Energy Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is John. It's very simple, if the acreage is there and it allows us to, we always plan to go 2 miles. It's just that simple. We're that convinced that our best rate of returns that we can achieve is by drilling that 2-mile lateral. Quite frankly
componenttext: Yes. This is John. It's very simple, if the acreage is there and it allows us to, we always plan to go 2 miles. It's just that simple. We're that convinced that our best rate of returns that we can achieve is by drilling that 2-mile lateral. Quite frankly, I have some in drilling who want to go longer than 2 miles. And we talk about even doing that. And we may eventually test longer than 2-mile lateral. But the simple answer is if the acreage allows us -- and fortunately, the majority -- the vast majority of our acreage allows us, then it is our preference to go long. The only time you're going to see us consciously choose not to drill a long lateral is like some of these spacing pilot tests, where we're trying to get vital information on how tight to put the wells next to each other. And quite frankly, the length of the lateral doesn't really dictate that result. And so in that regard, we kind of see it as an efficient way to spend our capital is just to do it as 5,000 and get the result and then leverage that quickly to 10,000-foot laterals in development. So I guess, the simplest answer is, yes, our bias in any opportunity or any chance is to go long with our wells. And almost, the vast majority of all the wells that we'll drill in '17 will be extended laterals in both basins.

componenttext: No, thank you, Karen. I just want to thank you for your interest. We're pretty excited about the landscape ahead of us, and we really do look forward to our next call. I want to thank everybody.
